Nicaragua refrained from signing because the punishments outlined in the climate agreement for non-complying nations were not harsh enough.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Mr. Trump, who had promised during his campaign to withdraw from the accord, saw the climate accord as a job-killer. Obama, however, saw the transition to renewable energy sources as a job creator. But in his statement, he suggested that the world's climate future might not be in the government's control anyway.Â¶"Simply put, the private sector already chose a low-carbon future," Obama wrote.  "And for the nations that committed themselves to that future, the Paris Agreement opened the floodgates for businesses, scientists, and engineers to unleash high-tech, low-carbon investment and innovation on an unprecedented scale." Â¶He also said that it was U.S. leadership on the world stage -- his administration's -- that made the Paris agreement possible. And what made that leadership possible, he added, "was America's private innovation and public investment in growing industries like wind and solar â€“ industries that created some of the fastest new streams of good-paying jobs in recent years."

title: Trump Paris Agreement pullout riles Europe, thrills nationalists
author: Jacqueline Alemany
content: Â¶The nationalist wing of the administration can add a point to the scoreboard after a messy and public months long battle inside the White House: President Trump, against the wishes of the rest of the world, defiantly quit the Paris Agreement on climate change on Thursday in the Rose Garden.Â¶"I am fighting every day for the great people of this country," Mr. Trump announced. "Therefore, in order to fulfill my solemn duty to protect America and it's citizens, the U.S. will withdraw from the paris climate accord." Â¶"But we will start to negotiate and we will see if we can make a deal that's fair. And if we can, that's great. And if we can't, that's fine," he added. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The President's inclination was always to pull out of the Agreement, according to sources inside the White House. Â¶But in a White House divided, the influential voices that ultimately pushed Mr. Trump to execute his campaign promise to exit the Agreement included Senior Advisor Steve Bannon, Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt, and Myron Ebell, a former Trump transition official and climate change skeptic. Twenty-one Republican Senators also called on Mr. Trump make a "clean exit" from the accord in two-page letter sent to the White House last week.Â¶Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Ivanka Trump, National Economic Council director Gary Cohn and several CEOs urged Mr. Trump to remain in the 195-nation pact. Mrs. Trump was integral to creating a semblance of a process, facilitating meetings on both sides of the aisle in order to better inform the President's decision making, according to a White House spokesperson.Â¶Faulting the Obama administration for a "poorly negotiated deal," ultimately, the White House argues that remaining in the deal serves little to improve the climate, decapitates the U.S. coal industry, imposes unrealistic targets on the U.S. â€” but not on countries like China and Indiaâ€” and would cost the economy almost $3 trillion over several decades and 6.5 million industrial jobs. Â¶"The Paris Climate Accord is simply the latest example of Washington entering an agreement that disadvantages the U.S. leaving American workers, who I love, and tax payers to absorb the cost in terms of lost jobs and lower wages and vastly diminished economic reduction," Mr. Trump said. Â¶The rules of the pact, however, prevent Mr. Trump from formally exiting the Paris Agreement for another four years.Â¶Article 28 of the Agreement stipulates that the U.S. cannot withdraw from the agreement until three years from the date of entry â€“ November 4th, 2016 -- and a withdrawal mandates a one-year notice period. A majority of Americans do not want the U.S. to exit the Paris Agreement.Â¶Jean-Claude Juncker, the President of the European Union, seized on this clause on Wednesday and mocked Mr. Trump's "America First" impulses.Â¶"So this notion, 'I am Trump, I am American, America First and I'm going to get out of it' â€“ that won't happen," Mr. Juncker said. "We tried to explain that to Mr. Trump in Taormina in clear German sentences. It seems out attempt failed, but the law is the law and it must be obeyed."Â¶The administration could very well expedite the process and exit the Agreement in only one year if Mr. Trump decides to exit the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the underlying structure that facilitates international cooperation on climate change.Â¶"Pulling out of the UNFCCC is the quickest path to removing America from a costly, unworkable, and ineffective agreement that President Trump correctly said should be cancelled," the conservative Heritage Foundation argued in a report.Â¶The administration is still working on specifics to exit the plan but, as of Thursday, it will "cease all implementation of the non-binding Paris Accord and the draconian and financial economic burdens the agreement imposes on our country," Mr. Trump said. Â¶"This includes ending the implementation of the nationally determined contribution and the green climate fund which is costing the U.S. a vast fortune," he added. Â¶Reverberations from Mr. Trump's decision were felt around the world, further unsettling allies after his appearances at the G7 and G20 summits of rich nations, followed by an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal from National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster and Senior Advisor Gary Cohn that candidly outlined the administration's transactional worldview.Â¶"The president embarked on his first foreign trip with a clear-eyed outlook that the world is not a 'global community' but an arena where nations, nongovernmental actors and businesses engage and compete for advantage," Cohn and McMaster wrote.Â¶World leaders did not hold back. On Thursday morning, before Mr. Trump's formal announcement, Germany and China pledged to continue to fight climate change. At a joint news conference with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, German Chancellor Angela Merkel praised China for becoming "a more important and strategic partner."Â¶"We are living in times of global uncertainty and see our responsibility to expand our partnership in all the different areas and to push for a world order based on law," she said.Â¶Andrew Light, a Senior Fellow at the World Resources Institute and a Former Climate Change Official from the State Department, told CBS News that withdrawing from the Paris Agreement will not only have severe diplomatic blowback, but will hand the Chinese more "influence on a silver platter."Â¶"Why would you willingly give put that leadership for what will come across as narrow ideological victory for a very small part of the White House?" Light said.Â¶The most immediate effect, Light argued, is the shadow this decision casts over American businesses.Â¶"It's going to hurt us economically as well because it'll make us harder for American businesses to compete in the clear energy marketplace if the federal government isn't setting up deals to compete in that marketplace," he said. Â¶An army of business leaders, from inventor and entrepreneur Elon Musk to Apple CEO Tim Cook, protested the decision. Twenty-four corporations including Apple, Facebook, Microsoft, and Unilever, penned an op-ed that ran in major U.S. newspapers, urging Mr. Trump to remain in the Agreement.Â¶"As businesses concerned with the well-being of our customers, our investors, our communities, and our suppliers, we are strengthening our climate resilience, and we are investing in innovative technologies that can help achieve a clean energy transition," the ad reads. "For this transition to succeed, however, governments must lead as well."Â¶Major energy corporations such as ExxonMobil, Chevron and BP also support the agreement, although coal companies do not. Â¶Leading up to the announcement, it was business as usual for a White House with a President who thrives on controversy and chaos. Mr. Trump himself indulged in the suspense of his announcement on Twitter of Wednesday night, teasing Thursday's announcement.Â¶ "I will be announcing my decision on Paris Accord, Thursday at 3:00pm. The White House Rose Garden. MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!" he tweeted. Â¶Noticeably missing from the process, as headlines continued to outpace a formal decision, was any regard for normal diplomatic protocols. Diplomats around D.C. scrambled to get a firm answer on what Mr. Trump's plans were before he announced them.Â¶"I don't know if it's complicated for partners or if its just disorganization within the White House itself," one Western diplomat reasoned.Â¶"In a formal discussion we had with some people from the National Security Council, they don't think the president is going to change. He is not used to an administrative process. He doesn't understand the need for bureaucracy, so now the administration is trying to adapt to the president [rather] than adapt the president to the bureaucracy," the diplomat concluded.

title: Trump pulls out of climate deal
author: Rebecca Shabad
date:
Updated on:  June 2, 2017 / 2:19 PM
      / CBS News
content: Â¶The U.S. is pulling out of the Paris climate agreement, President Trump announced Thursday in the White House Rose Garden.  Â¶"In order to fulfill my solemn duty to protect America and its citizens, the United States will withdraw from the Paris climate accord," Mr. Trump said, and instead, he said that the U.S. will "begin negotiations to reenter either the Paris accord or really a entirely new transaction" on terms that he said are fair to U.S. businesses, workers and taxpayers.Â¶"So we're getting out, but we will start to negotiate and we will see if we can make a deal that's fair. And if we can, that's great, and if we can't, that's fine," he added.Â¶Pulling out of the agreement -- one of President Obama's major achievements in office -- could take up to three years to carry out. The decision was long-awaited, given that Mr. Trump promised on the campaign trail last year to withdraw from the pact. CBS News' Major Garrett confirmed Wednesday that the president was expected to pull out.Â¶The president claimed Thursday that the agreement "disadvantages" the U.S. and is "very unfair, at the highest level, to the United States."  Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶"I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris," Mr. Trump said.    Â¶He warned that the current agreement blocks the development of clean coal in America and said that the deal represents a "massive redistribution of U.S. wealth to other countries." He offered to sit down with Democratic leadership in Congress to help renegotiate a "better deal."  Â¶"It's time to exit the Paris accord," Mr. Trump said, adding that it's time to pursue a new deal that protects the environment, the U.S. and its people. Â¶The U.S. will now be one of only three countries out of 197 nations that isn't signed onto the agreement, with the other two being Nicaragua and Syria.  Â¶The pact is aimed at combating climate change around the world and helping nations adapt to its effects by requiring countries to present plans to reduce carbon emissions. Specifically, it requires countries to set their own targets for reducing emissions by 2020. The Obama administration, for example, had committed the U.S. to reducing carbon emissions by 26 to 28 percent by 2025. The agreement also established a $100 billion fund to help vulnerable countries deal with the effects of climate change. Â¶In a statement Thursday, Obama touted the benefits of the Paris agreement and blasted Mr. Trump's leadership. Â¶"The nations that remain in the Paris Agreement will be the nations that reap the benefits in jobs and industries created," Obama said. "I believe the United States of America should be at the front of the pack. But even in the absence of American leadership; even as this Administration joins a small handful of nations that reject the future; I'm confident that our states, cities, and businesses will step up and do even more to lead the way, and help protect for future generations the one planet we've got." Â¶Last October, Obama celebrated the news that the agreement would take effect November 4. Â¶"Today the world has officially crossed the threshold for the Paris Agreement to take effect," he said from the Rose Garden. "Today the world meets the moment and if we follow through on the commitments this Paris Agreement embodies, history may well judge it as a turning point for our planet." Â¶During the presidential campaign, Mr. Trump pledged to withdraw from the agreement, arguing at a North Dakota rally, "This agreement gives foreign bureaucrats control over how much energy we use on our land, in our country." The president has previously called climate change a "hoax," tweeting in 2012, ""The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive." Â¶Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wisconsin, applauded the president for withdrawing from what he called a "raw deal for America," arguing that it would have "driven up the cost of energy, hitting middle-class and low-income Americans the hardest." Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, also praised the move, saying that Mr. Trump has "reiterated his commitment to protecting middle class families across the country and workers throughout coal country from higher energy prices and potential job loss.   Â¶Besides Obama, other key Democrats lambasted Mr. Trump for pulling out of the deal.  Â¶Former Vice President Al Gore, who made the climate change documentary "An Inconvenient Truth," said that removing the U.S. from the agreement is a "reckless and indefensible action." Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-New York, posted a tweet showing a fake cover of a newspaper.  Â¶#BreakingNews on #ParisClimateAgreement pic.twitter.com/KS1Twn5Xb3Â¶After the announcement Thursday, Tesla CEO Elon Musk followed through on his threat to leave the White House advisory councils he had been serving on. 	Â¶Am departing presidential councils. Climate change is real. Leaving Paris is not good for America or the world.Â¶CBS News' Stefan Becket contributed to this report.

title: China vows to stick to Paris climate deal
content: Â¶BEIJING -- Chinese Premier Li Keqiang vowed to work with the European Union to uphold the Paris climate accord Thursday, saying that fighting climate change was a "global consensus" and an "international responsibility."Â¶Speaking in Berlin about the Paris climate deal, he said that, "China in recent years has stayed true to its commitment."Â¶Without mentioning the U.S. specifically, he said China has been "actively promoting the Paris agreement and we were one of the first countries to ratify the Paris agreement."Â¶He added, "Fighting climate change is a global consensus, it's not invented by China... and we realize that this is a global consensus agreement and that as a big developing nation we should shoulder our international responsibility."Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who has in the past even been dubbed the "climate chancellor" for her efforts to fight global warming, welcomed Li's remarks at their joint press conference. Â¶Other European leaders were more explicit in expressing their fears that the U.S. government may abandon international measures against climate change. Â¶"Please don't change the (political) climate for the worse," European Council President Donald Tusk tweeted. Â¶.@realDonaldTrump please don't change the (political) climate for the worse.Â¶British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said Britain would continue to press the U.S. to reduce dangerous emissions even if Trump pulls out. Â¶The Kremlin said Russia was committed to the agreement. Speaking to reporters, a spokesman for President Vladimir Putin, Dmitry Peskov, said that Russia "thinks highly" of the accord and there was no alternative to it. But he added that its implementation would not be as effective "without the key signatories."Â¶Martin Schulz, a former European Parliament president who is hoping to unseat Merkel in Germany's upcoming general election, said he hoped Trump would think better of withdrawing from the accord. If the U.S. does leave, he said, the Europe Union should seek ways to balance out the economic advantage that U.S. companies might have from the absence of climate regulations. Â¶"Those who want to export their goods and services to our market also have to accept our standards," he said.Â¶During a trip to Europe this week, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed India's commitment to fighting climate change and said it would be a "crime" to spoil the environment for future generations.Â¶President Donald Trump is expected to announce his decision on whether to abandon the Paris climate accord Thursday afternoon. Abandoning the pact would isolate the U.S. from a raft of international allies who spent years negotiating the 2015 agreement to fight global warming and pollution by reducing carbon emissions in nearly 200 nations.Â¶I will be announcing my decision on Paris Accord, Thursday at 3:00 P.M.  The White House Rose Garden.  MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!Â¶While traveling abroad last week, Trump was repeatedly pressed to stay in the deal by European leaders and the Vatican. Withdrawing would leave the United States aligned only with Russia among the world's industrialized economies.Â¶While not mentioning the U.S. by name, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying told reporters overnight that climate change is a "global challenge" that no country can ignore, and that her country would work with the European Union to uphold the deal, even if the U.S. pulls out.Â¶"No matter whether other countries' positions may change, we will continue to uphold" a model of sustainable development, Hua said at a regularly scheduled news conference.Â¶When asked about whether China had spoken to the Trump administration about the climate agreement, she said, "China and the United States have close communications about a wide variety of topics, and of course, this includes the issue of climate change." Â¶China is the top emitter of man-made carbon dioxide emissions, and the United States is second. Both were key to reaching an agreement at Paris in 2015, which came into force in November and aims to keep global warming below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit compared with pre-industrial times.Â¶Trump claimed before taking office that climate change was a "hoax" created by China to hurt the U.S. economy, an assertion that stands in defiance of broad scientific consensus.Â¶In March, he signed an executive order to roll back Obama-era policies regulating carbon emissions. Trump said he wanted to create more coal mining jobs, though industry analysts say demand is likely to decline as the price of solar, wind and other alternatives falls.Â¶Scientists say Earth is likely to reach more dangerous levels of warming sooner if the U.S. retreats from its pledge because America contributes so much to rising temperatures. Calculations suggest withdrawal could release up to 3 billion additional tons of carbon dioxide a year - enough to melt ice sheets faster, raise seas higher and trigger more extreme weather.

title: Global reaction pours in as Trump nears climate deal decision - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- During a photo op with the leader of Vietnam Wednesday, President Trump was asked if he is going to pull out of the Paris climate accord.Â¶"You're going to find out very soon," Mr. Trump said.Â¶He seemed to suggest he still hasn't made up his mind.Â¶"I'm hearing from a lot of people, both ways," he said.Â¶But CBS News confirms that the president has started to tell confidants he will withdraw from the agreement. Reports to that effect ricocheted around the globe, drawing criticism from world leaders.  Â¶"Climate change is a global challenge. No country can place itself outside of this," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying said in a daily news briefing.Â¶On Thursday, the BBC reported that China and the European Union were drafting a joint statement to be delivered after an EU-China summit in Brussels on Friday. In it, the two powers will reportedly say the Paris climate agreement is "an imperative more important than ever."Â¶"The EU and China are joining forces to forge ahead on the implementation of the Paris agreement and accelerate the global transition to clean energy," EU Climate Commissioner Miguel Arias CaÃ±ete told the Guardian newspaper. Â¶The prime minister of India said it would be a "crime" to spoil the environment for future generations.Â¶Finland's prime minister said climate change won't be reversed "by closing your eyes."Â¶In Berlin, the head of the European Commission lectured Mr. Trump that "not everything in international agreements is fake news."Â¶Only two nations -- Syria and Nicaragua -- oppose the climate accord.Â¶During the campaign, Mr. Trump dismissed the scientific consensus that rising temperatures are caused primarily by fossil fuels like coal and oil. Â¶But even most major American businesses -- from Exxon to Apple -- support the agreement.Â¶Brian Deese, who was President Obama's point person on the Paris accord, says it's not just about the environment -- it's about the economy.  Â¶"Across the globe we have a competition for who's going to be the clean energy superpower of the 21st century and who is going to gain the economic benefits from doing that," Deese said. "But we can't win if we step off the playing field and disengage all together."Â¶There is still some uncertainty about the president's decision. Sources say the president has discussed the possibility of renegotiating the agreement, but it's not clear that the rest of the world would go along.

title: Elon Musk says he'll leave Trump advisory councils if U.S. withdraws from Paris climate deal
content: Â¶Tesla CEO Elon Musk says he'll leave the White House advisory councils he serves on if President Trump withdraws from the Paris climate agreement, an announcement Mr. Trump is expected to make soon.Â¶Don't know which way Paris will go, but I've done all I can to advise directly to POTUS, through others in WH & via councils, that we remainÂ¶Asked what he'd do if the president walked away from the climate deal, Musk tweeted that he'd leave the councils on which he serves.Â¶Will have no choice but to depart councils in that caseÂ¶Musk, the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, serves on Mr. Trump's business advisory council, manufacturing jobs council and his infrastructure council.Â¶President Trump has already told close friends and confidants of his plans to withdraw from the climate deal, and he has also discussed with senior White House staff attempting to renegotiate the Paris climate protocols on reducing greenhouse gas emissions â€“ with an eye to making them less onerous to U.S. industry.Â¶Asked about the Paris climate agreement during a meeting with Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc, the president said he would be making a decision soon, though he declined to say which way he is leaning.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶"Heard from a lot of people. Both ways," he told reporters. He declined to answer a question about whether he believes climate change is a hoax.Â¶Mr. Trump also tweeted Wednesday morning that he will have a formal announcement on the decision "over the next few days."

title: Paris climate agreement: What you need to know
author: Stefan Becket
date:
Updated on:  June 1, 2017 / 4:27 PM
      / CBS News
content: Â¶President Trump announced the U.S. will withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, the 2015 landmark international accord aimed at combating climate change. Â¶Speaking in the White House Rose Garden Thursday, Mr. Trump said the U.S. would "begin negotiations to reenter either the Paris accord or really an entirely new transaction on terms that are fair to the United States."Â¶The move deals a significant blow to efforts to slow the rise of global temperatures and reduce carbon dioxide emissions. Mr. Trump framed his decision as motivated by economics, saying the Paris agreement harms U.S. businesses and workers "to the exclusive benefit of other countries."Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Why is Mr. Trump pulling out of the agreement, and what does such a decision mean for the future of efforts to combat climate change? Here's a rundown of what the deal actually is, why Mr. Trump opposes it and what effects the U.S. pulling out could have.Â¶The Paris climate accord, known as the "Paris Agreement" by the United Nations, is an international agreement reached in 2015 aimed at reducing carbon emissions, slowing rising global temperatures and helping countries deal with the effects of climate change.Â¶Under the terms of the agreement, signatories committed to "holding the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2Â°C above pre-industrial levels and pursuing efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial levels."Â¶The deal requires countries to set their own targets for reducing emissions by 2020. The Obama administration committed the U.S. to reducing carbon emissions by 26 to 28 percent by 2025.Â¶The agreement also established a $100 billion fund to help vulnerable countries deal with the effects of climate change.Â¶The final text of the agreement was adopted at the Conference of Parties to the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, known as COP21, in December 2015. The U.S., which took the lead in negotiating the deal, signed onto the agreement in April 2016, along with China, the European Union and 171 other nations. China and the U.S. account for nearly 40 percent of global carbon emissions. Â¶The agreement took effect in November of that year, after nations accounting for 55 percent of global emissions ratified the treaty. As of May 2017, 147 parties have ratified the agreement, out of 195 who signed onto the accord. Â¶The Obama administration committed the U.S. to the agreement without seeking ratification in the Senate, meaning Mr. Trump can withdraw support unilaterally. The U.S. joins Nicaragua and Syria as the only countries not participating in the agreement.Â¶Mr. Trump repeatedly called climate change a "hoax" during the presidential campaign. As president, he has taken significant steps to roll back Mr. Obama's climate change agenda. In March, Mr. Trump signed an executive order scrapping the Obama administration's "Clean Power Plan," which mandated steep reductions in greenhouse gas emissions by power plants.Â¶The president vowed a year ago to "cancel" the Paris Agreement as president, but his administration repeatedly delayed making a final decision on the matter. As recently as last week, a senior White House official told reporters Mr. Trump was "evolving" on the issue of climate change after meeting with world leaders who encouraged him to preserve the accord. Secretary of Defense James Mattis said in an interview on "Face the Nation" Sunday that Mr. Trump was "wide open" to leaders' points of view on the Paris Agreement.Â¶But pulling out of the agreement is popular with Mr. Trump's political base, many of whom are skeptical of the science underlying climate change policy. Critics of the accord say the limits on emissions place an onerous and disproportionate burden on American businesses (although other business leaders disagree).Â¶The process of the U.S. withdrawing from the agreement could take at least three years, and scientists warn such a decision could have dire consequences for the planet.Â¶The Associated Press recently asked two dozens climate scientists what would happen if the U.S. reneges on its commitments under the Paris Agreement. They said that doing so would make it much more difficult to prevent crossing a dangerous threshold in global temperatures.Â¶Withdrawing from the deal could result in an additional 3 billion tons of carbon dioxide being released into the atmosphere each year, speeding up the rate of rising sea levels and melting ice sheets. The U.S. could contribute to an increase of as much as 0.3 degrees Celsius in global temperatures by the end of the century if if abandons the deal, according to one simulation.Â¶"The U.S. matters a great deal," Climate Interactive co-director Andrew Jones told the AP. "That amount could make the difference between meeting the Paris limit of two degrees and missing it."

title: President Trump expected to withdraw from Paris climate agreement
date:
Updated on:  May 31, 2017 / 4:03 PM
      / CBS News
content: Â¶President Donald Trump is expected to withdraw from the Paris climate accord, CBS News White House Correspondent Major Garrett confirms. Â¶Mr. Trump has already told close friends and confidants of his plans, and he has also discussed with senior White House staff attempting to renegotiate the Paris climate protocols on reducing greenhouse gas emissions â€“ with an eye to making them less onerous to U.S. industry.Â¶Asked about the Paris climate agreement during a meeting with Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc, the president said he would be making a decision soon, though he declined to say which way he is leaning.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶"Heard from a lot of people. Both ways," he told reporters. He declined to answer a question about whether he believes climate change is a hoax. Â¶Mr. Trump also tweeted Wednesday morning that he will have a formal announcement on the decision "over the next few days."Â¶I will be announcing my decision on the Paris Accord over the next few days. MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!Â¶First reported by Axios, Mr. Trump made his decision to withdraw from the agreement, according to two sources that have direct knowledge of the decision. Â¶Details on just how exactly the U.S. will be withdrawing are still being worked out by a team that includes EPA administrator Scott Pruitt. Â¶A full, formal withdrawal could take up to three years to execute, unraveling one of former President Barack Obama's major achievements in office to reduce the impacts of climate change. Â¶Mr. Trump had initially delayed his decision on whether or not to withdraw during his first foreign trip overseas, where he met with other G-7 leaders.Â¶Following the summit, German Chancellor Angela Merkel suggested the meeting had served as something of a wakeup call. G-7 leaders were unable to reach unanimous agreement on climate change after Mr. Trump said he needed more time to decide whether to back a key climate accord.Â¶"The times in which we can fully count on others are somewhat over, as I have experienced in the past few days," Merkel told the crowd of some 2,500 that gathered to hear her and Bavarian governor Horst Seehofer.Â¶"And so all I can say is that we Europeans must really take our destiny into our own hands," she said, according to the dpa news agency. Â¶According to his top economic adviser Gary Cohn, Mr. Trump's views on climate change were "evolving," but Mr. Trump's delay in formally deciding whether or not to stay involved in the accord forced G-7 leaders to declare the U.S. is "not in a position to join the consensus" around the agreement.Â¶More recently, Defense Secretary James Mattis told CBS News' John Dickerson that he was part of some of the discussions in Brussels when talks of climate change came up. Â¶"The president was open, he was curious about why others were in the position they were in, his counterparts in other nations. And I'm quite certain the president is wide open on this issue as he takes in the pros and cons of that accord," said Mattis. Â¶Only two other nations currently do not support the climate deal: Nicaragua and Syria. Â¶A U.S. withdrawal puts the U.S. in an isolated position in the world on climate change, as 195 countries signed the Paris agreement, which went into effect last year, and 147 nations have ratified it, CBS News' Pamela Falk reports. Â¶On Tuesday the U.N. Secretary-General sent a less-than-subtle warning to Mr. Trump, saying that if one country decides to leave a void in leadership, he can guarantee someone else will occupy it. Â¶"Get on board or get left behind," Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said in a speech to business and academic leaders in New York, Falk reports. "Those who embrace green technologies will set the gold standard for economic leadership in the 21st century."

title: Sea change: How the Dutch confront the rise of the oceans - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶Windmills are more than just a traditional part of the Dutch landscape; they have played a key role in the war the Dutch have been waging against the ocean for the past thousand years. Our Cover Story is reported by Martha Teichner:Â¶The windmills at Kinderdijk were built nearly 300 years ago, to pump water out of the surrounding farmland. But the Dutch have been outsmarting the water that's everywhere around them for a thousand years,  Â¶It is a matter of survival. Twenty-six percent of the country is below sea level. Â¶A massive storm surge barrier called the Maeslantkering, or Maeslant Barrier, was completed in 1997, to protect Rotterdam, Europe's largest port. It's equal in size to two Eiffel Towers, on their sides. Â¶"This Maeslant Barrier is really here to safeguard us for the future," said Henk Ovink. He is water envoy for the King of the Netherlands -- a water ambassador, if you will.Â¶The Dutch are the world's go-to water management experts. Ovink spent two years working in areas hit by Superstorm Sandy. "I said [to them], 'Did you think of preventing the disaster?' And they were like, 'Preventing the disaster? No, we couldn't. No, we have to make sure that we respond faster.' And I said, 'But suppose that there is no disaster because you prepared better?'"Â¶Who doesn't know the fable about the little Dutch boy who plugged the hole in a dike with his finger and saved his country? Â¶What really happened taught the Netherlands about preparedness.  A ferocious North Sea storm in January 1953 flooded 500 square miles and killed more than 1,800 people. The Dutch built themselves a fortress of flood protection.Â¶Today, the Netherlands considers itself protected against a 10,000-year storm, in part thanks to research done by Deltares, a gee-whiz kind of place, with the largest wave machine in the world. Â¶At their experimental facility, they can test structures that protect against the coast from ocean waves. Â¶Deltares has worked with clients in 140 different countries, including the United States. Ap van Dongeren, a coastal flooding expert with Deltares, says all of their designs are assuming a rise in sea levels. "And that will come with higher waves, so you have to figure that all into your design," he said. Â¶Sea levels in Holland are expected to rise more than three feet by the end of the century. This projection prompted the Dutch government -- so used to walling water out at all costs -- to rethink, and let the water in instead.Â¶"For the Dutch, this is a revolution -- the idea that you're safer by lowering the dikes? This is extraordinary," said journalist Tracy Metz. Â¶In her latest book, Metz, a longtime Netherlands resident, tells the story of how the farmers of Overdiepse Polder voluntarily agreed to give up their land so that it could become a spillway for a nearby river when it floods, in order to protect cities and towns downstream. Â¶For Nol Hooijmaiers, it was a sacrifice with a silver lining. Huge mounds were constructed, so that he and a few of his neighbors were able to build brand new farms high above the floodplain. Â¶"So you're happy, not angry?" aske dTeichner.Â¶"Everybody is happy, ja," he replied. Â¶Learning to accommodate water has led to innovation, for example: The Sand Engine (Zandmotor), a 24-million-ton pile of sand dumped off Holland's south coast. Nature was the engine that spread it into a flood barrier and a beach. Â¶Jim Murley, the man in charge of confronting Miami-Dade County's water issues, and who has consulted Dutch engineers, says parts of the Dutrch model are applicable elsewhere. "Just the way they go about thinking about managing water, how they use their land, creates a mindset," he said.Â¶In South Florida, flooding has become a regular occurrence. According to current estimates, sea levels here will rise as much as six feet by the end of the century. At stake: trillions of dollars of real estate and more than seven million lives.Â¶So at a vulnerable Miami waste water treatment plant, critical infrastructure is being rebuilt higher. Â¶"We want to be sure that this facility will withstand a storm surge," Murley said. Â¶In Miami Beach, streets are being raised 2.5 feet. A new art museum in downtown Miami is designed so flood water can flush through its foundation.Â¶Murley said, "We're starting to think about how we might develop in the future, if we were having to live with water like the Dutch are."Â¶Like Rotterdam, where there is a floating conference center surrounded by floating trees; and Amsterdam, with its whole neighborhood of floating houses.Â¶Jasper Dykshoorn and his wife, Sietske Jacobs, bought theirs five months ago.Â¶Teicher asked, "It's weird having the water right out the window?"Â¶"Yeah, it is," Jacobs replied. "But on the other hand it isn't. You're in a house."Â¶She doesn't mind that the baby's crib is under water. The house is moored to a dock. So if the water level rises, so does the house.Â¶To Dykshoorn, as a Dutchman, the water is a fact of life -- no more, no less. "It's in our veins, basically," he said. Â¶      For more info:

title: Climate talks begin amid question: Where does the U.S. stand?
content: Â¶BONN, Germany â€” Despite uncertainties about whether the United States will remain committed to the Paris climate accord under President Donald Trump, envoys convened talks Monday in Germany on implementing the details of the deal to combat global warming.Â¶During ten days of talks in the western city of Bonn, officials will try to agree on how to implement the 2015 Paris Agreement to cut carbon emissions, a treaty that former U.S. President Barack Obama's government played a leading role in forging.Â¶The Paris accord calls for limiting the global average temperature increase since the industrial revolution to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit or less â€” a goal that has been called ambitious.Â¶Patricia Espinosa, head of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change that is hosting the Bonn talks, said it was important to make progress on the nuts and bolts of the agreement before November's annual climate summit. Her agency's budget is also up for discussion.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Espinosa refused to comment on the impact of a possible U.S. withdrawal from the talks or even the entire climate change accord.Â¶"I would rather wait until a decision has been taken," she said.Â¶U.S. officials had planned to meet Tuesday in Washington to discuss whether to withdraw from the Paris deal that Trump has said he would "cancel" â€” or find a way to back away from emissions targets set by the Obama administration. However, CBS News has confirmed the meeting has been postponed, with one administration official citing scheduling conflicts.Â¶According to White House officials, first daughter and presidential adviser Ivanka Trump intends to meet with Cabinet officials and department heads to discuss whether to abandon or stick with the treaty.  Her meetings with EPA administrator Scott Pruitt and Sen. Lisa Murkowski were just some of the discussions she is holding over the next two weeks as part of her White House "listening tour."Â¶Murkowski, a Republican, has supported efforts to reduce carbon emissions, while Pruitt has expressed doubt about scientific findings on the causes of climate change.Â¶Fiji, which holds the presidency of the upcoming climate summit, said it was important to press ahead with the talks.Â¶"Irrespective of the position of particular countries, I think it's very important that we continue to move this process forward," said Fiji envoy Nazhat Shameem Khan. "That's the short answer to the issue about the United States."

title: Antarctica's penguins are in trouble, new report shows
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶In the rapidly warming Antarctic, two species of penguins are in dramatic decline. Â¶Thatâ€™s the news out of a new study published by Oceanites, a nonprofit organization that closely monitors penguins and other Antarctic seabirds, in collaboration with researchers from NASA and Stony Brook University in New York.Â¶Relying on satellite photos and on-the-ground analysis from more than 660 sites across the frozen continent, the study paints a broad picture of the health of several Antarctic penguin species: the AdÃ©lie, chinstrap, emperor, and gentoo. Like endangered polar bears, penguins have come to represent vulnerability in the face of rapidly unfolding climate change.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The report looked specifically at the Antarctic Peninsula, which has warmed by a year-round average of 5 degrees Fahrenheit in the past 60 years. Â¶There, two species â€” AdÃ©lie and chinstrap penguins â€” were reported to be in severe decline. Meanwhile, gentoo penguins appeared to be adapting to changing circumstances. Â¶â€œIn one generation, I have personally witnessed the precipitous decline of once abundant AdÃ©lie and chinstrap penguin populations,â€ Oceanites founder and president Ron Naveen said in a statement. â€œThese iconic birds are literally canaries in the coal mine. They provide critical insights into the dramatic changes taking place in the Antarctic.â€Â¶The researchers theorize that gentoo, AdÃ©lie and chinstrap penguins might be adapting differently to changes in their food supplies. Left without the same supplies of krill, a small crustacean, gentoo penguins appear to be supplementing their diet by eating more fish. AdÃ©lie and chinstrap penguins, however, do not demonstrate the same behaviors. Â¶Researchers also pointed to the collapse of sea ice, which penguins require to hunt from, as a root cause for the declining numbers.Â¶The AdÃ©lie penguin appears healthier in other parts of the Antarctic that have not experienced such significant changes from rising temperatures, like East Antarctica and the Ross Sea, researchers said.Â¶Global warming is transforming Antarctica, one of the most remote places on Earth, as sea ice melts, leaving more open water than ever before. Â¶Antarcticaâ€™s ice shelves â€” the powerful structures that act as buffers preventing glaciers and ice streams from spilling out into the sea â€” are also in decline. Antarcticaâ€™s Larsen-A and Larsen-B ice shelves have already collapsed, and new satellite images show massive cracks in the Larsen-C ice shelf. Â¶And of course, itâ€™s not just a problem of the southern hemisphere. Last year, NASA described the melting ice in the Arctic as the â€œnew normal.â€

title: Check out Antarctica's growing ice shelf crack from space
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Satellites are bearing witnesses to a massive, steadily growing crack in Antarcticaâ€™s Larsen-C ice shelf.Â¶Ice shelves are extremely vulnerable to climate change. Two other portions â€” known as the Larsen-A and Larsen-B ice shelves â€” already collapsed in 1995 and 2002, respectively. Â¶Using images captured by their satellites, European Space Agency (ESA) scientists are watching the Larsen-C crack worsen in slow motion. They combined several radar images to create the following interferogram image of the ice shelf, with its growing crack visible on the right-hand side. ESA says the interferogram measures surface deformation of the ice along the line where itâ€™s splitting apart, which may not be visible on the surface.Â¶When the ice shelf ultimately breaks, it will create one of the largest icebergs ever recorded, according to the ESA. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Antarcticaâ€™s ice shelves are crucial to global environmental stability because they act as buffers, holding back Antarctic glaciers and ice streams from spilling out into the sea. Â¶Rising temperatures and increased water flow could eventually cause Antarcticaâ€™s ice shelves to collapse entirely, triggering dangerous sea level rise across the world. Sea level rise is a major risk factor this century: according to projections from NOAA, global sea levels are expected to rise between one foot and 8.2 feet by the year 2100. Â¶In a study published last week, scientists explained that Antarcticaâ€™s ice shelves are even more vulnerable to melting and collapse than previously thought due to the unexpectedly widespread free-flowing water recently seen across the continent. Â¶Global warming is transforming the Arctic, with effects that include significantly warmer temperatures, declining amounts of sea ice, and more open water in previously frozen areas with each passing year. Â¶The ice shelves â€œact as a safety band,â€ the ESA explained. â€œIf lost, it could be the point of no return.â€

title: Mike Bloomberg, Carl Pope say jobs come from clean energy, not coal - on "CBS This Morning" - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶A new CBS News poll shows a majority of Americans have a pessimistic view about prospects for the environment, with 57 percent believing it will be worse for the next generation. Only 12 percent believe the environment will be better than it is today. Â¶But a new book by former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Charles Pope, former executive director of the Sierra Club, offers a more optimistic view. Itâ€™s called â€œClimate of Hope: How Cities, Businesses, and Citizens Can Save the Planetâ€ (St. Martinâ€™s Press). Â¶On â€œCBS This Morningâ€ Monday, Bloomberg said that leadership in finding solutions to environmental problems may come down to the foresight of cities, rather than federal or state governments. Â¶â€œLocal governments influence how we get around, what fuels we can burn, whether or not we are compliant with the rules,â€ he said. â€œPeople who want to live cleaner, breathe cleaner air, drink more pure water, have a better economy, itâ€™s in the cities where they can change things.â€ Â¶He said the book was a reaction to pessimism about government action â€” or perceived inaction.  â€œCarl and I got together and said, â€˜Everybodyâ€™s so pessimistic, but we really are making a big difference.â€™ We are going to meet the COP21 goals without any help from the federal government, basically,â€ he said, referring to targets for reducing greenhouse gases set in the Paris climate accords. Â¶Pope added, â€œIn fact, the United States has reduced its carbon emissions by a larger ratio than any other major industrial nation. Weâ€™ve already accomplished two-thirds of what President Obama promised to accomplish by 2025, and this is being driven by public sentiment at the local level, by leaders from cities and by innovation by American businesses.â€ Â¶When co-anchor Norah Oâ€™Donnell asked about two of the worldâ€™s largest polluters, China and India, Bloomberg responded, â€œChina, in all fairness, is one of the countries that is working the hardest to clean things up. Why? Because you canâ€™t see across the street, the pollution is so bad. Theyâ€™ve woken up and said, â€˜We just are not going to stay in power unless we do something.â€™ And so they are closing coal-fired power plants, they are closing cement plants, they are closing steel plants, and moving them away from the cities.â€ Â¶â€œAnd India just announced that they will not build any more coal-fired power plants for the next decade,â€ said Pope. â€œTheyâ€™ve put a complete suspension on starting new coal-fired power plants, because in India right now if you put out a bid, solar comes in first, wind comes in second, coal comes in a poor third, in terms of cost.â€ Â¶â€œWe are now at a point at which alternative means of creating energy are lower than fossil fuel?â€ asked co-anchor Charlie Rose. Â¶â€œCleaner means cheaper,â€ Pope said. â€œCheaper equals cleaner. Thatâ€™s what clean energy has become.â€ Â¶Bloomberg also condemned President Trumpâ€™s rollback of pollution controls for mining companies, which the president called â€œjob-killing.â€  â€œIf we start putting the tailings of these coal mines into the rivers â€”which an EPA regulation just got rolled back and will now permit â€” people downstream are going to all of sudden wake up one day and find they and their kids have been poisoned,â€ Bloomberg said.   Â¶Mr. Trump, who is seeking to cut the Envrionmental Protection Agencyâ€™s budget by about one-third, promised to end a supposed â€œwar on coalâ€ and bring back jobs for unemployed coal miners. Â¶â€œUnfortunately for people who work in the coal injury, technology is devastating them,â€ Bloomberg said. â€œBack in 1925, there were 800,000 people that worked in coal; in 1980 there were 250,000. Today thereâ€™s 55,000 â€” and production has gone up. Itâ€™s all technology thatâ€™s destroying jobs. Â¶â€œWe canâ€™t just sit here and say â€˜woe to usâ€™ or â€˜woe to the coal miners.â€™ Weâ€™ve got to do something. And what you have to do is help them train for other jobs because those [coal] jobs arenâ€™t going to come back.â€ Â¶â€œBut you have an administration in Washington that says itâ€™s going to reduce the standards from the EPA, that itâ€™s going to withdraw from the Paris agreement,â€ said Rose. Â¶â€œHopefully that wonâ€™t happen,â€ Bloomberg said. â€œHopefully theyâ€™ll get some sense and say, â€˜Look, Americaâ€™s going to meet its goals anyway. It would send a bad message. Letâ€™s go along to try to work from within rather than from without.â€™ Â¶â€œBut no matter what they do, we are going toward a world where coal is going to be less-used, where fewer people are going to be working in the industry, and weâ€™ve got to find ways to get jobs for people not just in this industry but in lots of industries around the world being pushed out by technology. And you donâ€™t do it by going and creating jobs you donâ€™t need; you have to create jobs we need. Â¶â€œA good example is, we have lots of soldiers, veterans. Weâ€™ve got take care of them. Weâ€™ve got to find jobs for veterans. But you donâ€™t go start a war to give them jobs. You find things that they can do and that we need in society and there are ways to do that.â€ Â¶Pope said, â€œLetâ€™s look at the reality: We didnâ€™t make America great by keeping buggy whips going in the 1920s. We made America great by building the worldâ€™s greatest auto industry. We have the opportunity to build the worldâ€™s greatest clean energy industry. We ought to be embracing the future. Already clean energy employs five times as many people as natural gas, coal, and oil combined. So there are hundreds of thousands of jobs in the clean energy industry. There can be millions, and cities are competing with each other to see who can get the most of them. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s great about cities. They compete to move forward, not to look backward.â€ Â¶      For more info:

title: March for Science global rally takes aim at Trump, environmental cuts - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶WASHINGTON, D.C. -- Itâ€™s been 47 years since the first â€œEarth Dayâ€ and today it was observed around the world with a focus on science.Â¶Rallies and marches were held in more than 600 cities -- from New York, Chicago and Washington -- to London, Berlin and Sydney, Australia.Â¶The officially titled â€œMarch for Scienceâ€ was not billed as a political event -- but many who marched said they were concerned about threatened cuts to research programs, especially those aimed at fighting climate change.Â¶There was plenty of H20 on this wet, dreary day in the nationâ€™s Capital, but the rain did not seem to dampen the spirit of the crowd.Â¶Clinical psychologist Tim Truemper came from Salisbury, North Carolina.Â¶CBS News asked specifically what makes him worried?Â¶â€œClimate changes is my biggest concern,â€ Truemper said. â€œWe canâ€™t stall our progress any more in this area.â€Â¶Kristin Sanborn from New Jersey senses a change in climate â€¦ for science.Â¶â€œIâ€™m here because Iâ€™m so upset because science seems under attack, facts seem under attack,â€ Sanborn said.Â¶Speakers at the rally spanned many disciplines.Â¶â€œWeâ€™re not politicizing science â€¦ weâ€™re defending itâ€ Dr. Jonathon Foley of the California Academy of Sciences said.Â¶And those of many ages also attended.Â¶What happened at today's #marchforscience? Tune in tonight to @CBSEveningNews @CBSNLive pic.twitter.com/qHXjHNaV7wÂ¶â€œWe cannot vote â€¦ but we will be heard,â€ a group of teenagers exclaimed on stage.Â¶The roster included crowd favorites like Bill Nye â€œThe Science Guy.â€Â¶â€œIâ€™m in the same place with Bill,â€ one girl screamed from the crowd.Â¶Gotta love it. Watch the reaction of 3 teenagers to the appearance of @BillNye at today's #marchforscience in DC. @CBSNLive @RobertPicardo pic.twitter.com/xH3kiVkpUdÂ¶â€œWe are going to save the world,â€ Nye shouted.Â¶The march was billed as a non-partisan defense of science. But some strongly attacked the policies of the Trump administration.Â¶Lillian Knipp, Kathy Ely and Lucia Teal live in Baltimore and spoke to CBS News.Â¶â€œWe were born in the â€˜50s, we grew up in the â€˜70s,â€ Knipp said. â€œWe watched progress, we were protesting back then, and weâ€™re too old for this. We should not be out here protesting for things we won in the â€˜70s and the â€˜80s.â€Â¶â€œWe were at the first Earth Day,â€ Ely said.Â¶On this 48th Earth Day, marchers turned out in communities large and small -- including a tiny contingent on the north pole.Â¶President Trump released a statement saying:Â¶My Administration is committed to advancing scientific research that leads to a better understanding of our environment and of environmental risks.Â¶I am committed to keeping our air and water clean but always remember that economic growth enhances environmental protection. Jobs matter!Â¶Mr. Trump said to remember that rigorous science depends not on ideology, but on a spirit of honest inquiry and robust debate.

title: March for Science protesters take to the streets to mark Earth Day
content: Â¶NEW YORK -- Scientists, students and research advocates rallied from the Brandenburg Gate to the Washington Monument on Earth Day, conveying a global message of scientific freedom without political interference and spending necessary to make future breakthroughs possible. Â¶The March for Science, coinciding with Earth Day, was set for more than 500 cities, anchored in Washington, D.C., and to be joined by dozens of nonpartisan scientific professional societies in a turnout intended to combine political and how-to science demonstrations. Â¶â€œWhen the first time in recorded history scientists have to get together to form a march in support of science, something serious is going on,â€ Rockefeller Universityâ€™s Erich Jarvis told CBS News chief medical correspondent Dr. Jon LaPook, who is covering the march in Washington. Â¶President Trump, in an Earth Day statement hours after the marches kicked off, said that â€œrigorous science depends not on ideology, but on a spirit of honest inquiry and robust debate.â€ 	Â¶Organizers portrayed the march as political but not partisan, promoting the understanding of science as well as defending it from various attacks. They cited proposed federal cuts to the National Institutes of Health totaling $6 billion, or 18 percent of the instituteâ€™s budget.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The marches also come at a time when Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the future of the planet. A CBS News poll found this week that just 12 percent of Americans believe the environment will improve for the next generation, while 57 percent said it will get worse.Â¶Here are the highlights from marches and Earth Day events around the globe.Â¶Thousands of people stood outside the Washington Monument amid bouts of downpours, listening to a mix of speeches and music. Speakers noted that President Trump was in the White House nearby, having canceled a weekend in New Jersey.  	Â¶This was the first protest for Jeannette Villabon and her son Nikko Chey of Stanhope, New Jersey. So Villabon went all out, donning a Tyrannosaurus rex costume and holding a sign that said: â€œHey tiny hands fund EPA study. Quit being cretaceous.â€  Â¶Mr. Trumpâ€™s â€œarchaic thinking is going to ruin us all,â€ Villabon said. Â¶Other signs were only slightly less pointed, such as â€œedit genes not the truth,â€ â€œdata not dogmaâ€  and â€œglobal warming is real. Trump is the hoax.â€ Signs and banners readied for the Washington rally reflected anger, humor and obscure scientific references, such as a 7-year-oldâ€™s â€œNo Taxation Without Taxonomy.â€ Taxonomy is the science of classifying animals, plants and other organisms.  Â¶ Why did the Dinosaur cross the road? To #MarchForScience. ğŸ˜‚Â¶A post shared by March for Science (Official) (@sciencemarchdc) on Apr 22, 2017 at 12:18pm PDTÂ¶The sign that 9-year-old Sam Klimas held was red, handmade and personal: â€œScience saved my life.â€ He had a form of brain cancer and has been healthy for eight years now. His mother, grandmother and brother traveled with him from Parkersburg, West Virginia. â€œI have to do everything I can to oppose the policies of this administration,â€ said his grandmother, Susan Sharp. Â¶ It might be raining, but that isn't stopping these women, and thousands of others, from joining the #marchforscience in D.C. today!Â¶A post shared by March for Science (Official) (@sciencemarchdc) on Apr 22, 2017 at 11:30am PDTÂ¶One of the organizers of the first Earth Day, Denis Hayes, said the crowd he saw on the National Mall in Washington appeared energized and â€œmagical,â€ almost like what he saw that first day 47 years ago.Â¶In Manhattan, the March for Science began with a rally at 10:30 a.m. near Columbus Circle at Central Park West. Â¶Thousands of participants walked down Broadway to midtown Manhattan, ending at West 52nd Street. A 1.6-mile stretch of Broadway was closed to cars for the march. Â¶Marchers held signs with slogans such as, â€œThe oceans are rising and so are we,â€ and, â€œDenial is not a policy,â€ CBS New York reports. Â¶Some marchers also held signs with a silhouette of President Donald Trump and messages such as â€œabsolute zeroâ€ and â€œblack hole.â€ Â¶Democratic Gov. Andrew Cuomo released a statement honoring Earth Day and noting the challenges facing the environment. Â¶â€œFrom combating climate change and reducing carbon emissions to safeguarding our coastal communities and strengthening resiliency in the face of extreme weather -- New York must continue to lead the way forward,â€ Cuomo said. Â¶ We drew massive crowds all across the world! @activistbarbie #MarchForScienceÂ¶A post shared by March for Science (Official) (@sciencemarchdc) on Apr 22, 2017 at 1:15pm PDTÂ¶The March for Science Los Angeles, under the slogan â€œScience, Not Silence,â€ was expected to be one of the largest of the approximately 500 being held nationwide at a time when federal funding for researching climate change and other initiatives is under threat.Â¶This is huge! #MarchForScienceLA has been marching by our spot for 37 minutes...and finally thinning out. #CBSLA @CBSLA pic.twitter.com/NV9xCvt4xDÂ¶Led by two electric massive electric Hummers, several thousand people marched in downtown Los Angeles. They chanted â€œMoney for science and education, not for wars and climate alterationâ€ and carried signs that read: â€œThere is no Planet Bâ€ and â€œThe Earth does not belong to man.â€Â¶â€œFacts matter,â€ local organizer Alex Bradley said in a prepared statement. â€œIn California, we use science to enable technology, spur innovation and create new industries and new jobs.â€Â¶A variety of beautification projects and community education events were planned, reports CBS Los Angeles. These range from a habitat restoration and creek cleanup by the Friends of Ballona Wetlands to the 28th annual Great L.A. River CleanUp.Â¶Marching in Sacramento, heading to the capital! #marchforscience #plantsci pic.twitter.com/KHMr8hZ31VÂ¶â€œWeâ€™ve gone through a time where we used to look up to intelligence and aspire to learn more and do more with that and intellectual curiosity ... And now weâ€™ve got a government that is saying that climate change is a Chinese hoax,â€ said Danny Leserman, 26, who was carrying a sign showing a sad polar bear wishing for more ice.Â¶At the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, hundreds of professors, researchers, engineers and ordinary citizens gathered on a lawn before marching across the city to a park.Â¶Many carried homemade signs that included, â€œThe oceans are rising and so are weâ€ and â€œA womanâ€™s place is in the lab!!â€Â¶The day kicked off around 10 a.m. in Grant Park with speeches from several prominent Chicago-land scientists, reports CBS Chicago. Shortly after, participants marched down Columbus Driver to the Field Museum, where more than 50 science-related non-profits and research groups were stationed for a three-hour expo.Â¶Chicago Police said more than 40,000 people participated.Â¶March for Science crowd as seen from Chopper 2. Tune in to @cbschicago at 5 p.m. for details #marchforscience pic.twitter.com/vooiceOFtiÂ¶â€œIn the last few months, a lot of the scientific community has felt like they maybe do need to start taking a stand. Science has always strived to remain non-political, non-partisan -- and weâ€™re still striving for that,â€ said Liz Homsey, a co-organizer. â€œEvery single scientist at this event feels that it is much more pro science than anti anything.â€Â¶Slowly making our way to museum campus.  #marchforscience @cbschicago pic.twitter.com/2HA7uldp8SÂ¶Scientists from across Massachusetts gathered on the Boston Common at 1 p.m. for a rally.Â¶Among those participating were scientists and researchers from Harvard University, MIT, Clark University, UMass-Lowell and Massachusetts General Hospital, reports CBS Boston.Â¶Speakers at the rally included former Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Gina McCarthy, who has been sharply critical of Trumpâ€™s efforts to unravel former President Barack Obamaâ€™s plan to curb global warming.Â¶Several thousand people participated in a march from the one of the Berlinâ€™s universities to the Brandenburg Gate landmark.  Â¶Meike Weltin is a doctorate student at an environmental institute near Berlin. She said she was participating because -- in her words -- â€œI think that politics need to listen to sciences.â€ Â¶Germanyâ€™s foreign minister, Sigmar Gabriel, has endorsed March for Science events across Germany. Gabriel says â€œfree research and teaching are the supporting pillars of an open and modern society.â€ Â¶Physicists, astronomers, biologists and celebrities gathered for a march past Londonâ€™s most celebrated research institutions. Supporters carried signs showing images of a double helix and chemical symbols.  Â¶The protest was putting scientists, who generally shy away from advocacy and whose work depends on objective experimentation, into a more public position. Â¶In Australia, protesters carried signs urging respect for both science and scientists.Â¶Celebrities also tweeted out their support for Saturdayâ€™s event.Â¶An #EarthDay message we can all agree on, from today's @Snapchat Earth Day story. pic.twitter.com/d4bjJI197RÂ¶A shout out to all those today who #MarchForScience. The truth is out there. Embrace it. Cherish it. Protect it.Â¶ @BillNye has a message for YOU! #MarchForScienceÂ¶A post shared by March for Science (Official) (@sciencemarchdc) on Apr 22, 2017 at 9:39am PDTÂ¶Gotta love it. Watch the reaction of 3 teenagers to the appearance of @BillNye at today's #marchforscience in DC. @CBSNLive @RobertPicardo pic.twitter.com/xH3kiVkpUdÂ¶#PeterCapaldi at the #ScienceMarch in London today ! #ScienceMarchLdn pic.twitter.com/w7SxQrocPsÂ¶Sending love and gratitude to everyone at the #MarchForScience today!!!!! Thank you for standing up for TRUTH.

title: "Bring it on": Students sue Trump administration over climate change - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶EUGENE, Ore. -- Avery McRae has been passionate about the environment for half a lifetime, and she's been worried about climate change since kindergarten.Â¶Now, at 11, she is really getting serious. She recently signed on to sue President Trump and the U.S. government.Â¶"Trump is not doing anything to help stop climate change," she says. "He's a climate change denier, and we're gonna prove that to the world!" Â¶McRae is one of 21 students suing the government claiming it is violating their constitutional right to a healthy planet by not doing enough to limit the use fossil fuels.Â¶The case, originally filed in Oregon in 2015, bears the name of lead plaintiff, Kelsey Juliana.    Â¶"It's a disgrace that the government has put its citizens and its younger generation into a position where we have to go to court," McRae says.Â¶The Justice Department tried to get it thrown out but instead, in November, U.S. District Court Judge Ann Aiken agreed to hear it. Â¶"My mom's like 'your case won, and you're gonna move forward,' and I screamed so loud," McRae says. "I was getting ready to cry, but I was like 'no, no, I've got to get back to class!'"Â¶The trial could start later this year, and 16-year-old Aji Piper says, "bring it on." He says he's not intimidated to take on the federal government along with major oil companies and lobbyists.Â¶"You have the biggest oil and gas companies against you, it's like, good -- let them be defeated in court."Â¶And though their lawsuit may seem like a long shot, who better to fight for the future than those who will be here to see it.

title: March for Science: Thousands of scientists plan to take to the streets on Earth Day - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- Tens of thousands of scientists plan to mark Earth Day on Saturday by marching in hundreds of cities across the country and around the world. Theyâ€™ll be protesting cuts to research and programs aimed at fighting climate change.Â¶The march comes as many Americans are pessimistic about the environment. A CBS News poll on Friday found just 12 percent believe the environment will improve for the next generation. Fifty-seven percent say it will get worse.Â¶Scientists have marched before, highlighting specific threats such as nuclear weapons and pollution. But Saturday marks the first time theyâ€™ve ever marched in defense of science itself, with more than 200 scientific organizations participating in about 600 marches around the world. Â¶Erich Jarvis studies the neurobiology of language at New York Cityâ€™s Rockefeller University. His entire research team is going to Saturdayâ€™s March for Science. Â¶â€œWhen the first time in recorded history scientists have to get together to form a march in support of science, something serious is going on,â€ Jarvis says. Â¶Whatâ€™s different now â€œis that the most powerful country in the world is attacking science, is attacking evidence-based logical thinking,â€ Jarvis says. â€œThat is a pretty serious attack not on just science but just on being human.â€Â¶Participants will range from geologists to geneticists, physicists to farmers, students to teachers.Â¶Their concerns include a proposed cut of $6 billion in funding for the National Institutes of Health; denial of what they see as established science, such as the threat of climate change; and a changing immigration policy. Foreign-born scientists fill nearly half of U.S. postdoctoral research positions. Â¶Cell biologist Lydia Villa-Komaroff is one of the coordinators. Villa-Komaroff says she worries that the definition of â€œfactâ€ has changed. Â¶â€œA fact is something which is testable and verifiable by a variety of means and a variety of people,â€ she says. â€œWeâ€™re confusing opinion and fact, beliefs and facts, and that is a mistake when the country decides where it should take certain policy decisions.â€Â¶And for those people who say, â€œoh, just stay in your lab. Science and politics do not mix,â€ Jarvis says that â€œif you cut the funding, I canâ€™t stay in my lab. So I gotta come out.â€Â¶For scientists like Jarvis to come out of their labs and march is a big deal. But the sentiment Iâ€™m hearing is, who better to defend science than the people who do it?

title: Water streaming across Antarctica surprises, worries scientists
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶In a unique study spanning the entire continent, scientists have found that water is gushing across Antarctica â€” more than they ever realized.Â¶The researchers from Columbia Universityâ€™s Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory have found significant drainage of meltwater flowing across the continentâ€™s ice sheets during summer in Antarctica. Until now, these streams of water were mainly associated only with Antarcticaâ€™s far north regions. Â¶The discovery of widespread streams across the continent is ominous news, indicating Antarcticaâ€™s ice may be much more vulnerable to melting than scientists predicted. Free-flowing water, which absorbs solar energy more than ice, puts nearby ice at greater risk of melting. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œI think most polar scientists have considered water moving across the surface of Antarctica to be extremely rare. But we found a lot of it, over very large areas,â€ Jonathan Kingslake, a glaciologist at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory and lead author of the study, said in a statement. Â¶â€œThis is not in the future â€” this is widespread now, and has been for decades,â€ he said. The research was published this week in the journal Nature.Â¶In the study, climate scientists carefully catalogued aerial and satellite images of Antarctica from 1947 to the present. The images helped them map 700 distinct systems of ponds, channels and streams across the continent, researchers said. They noted that thereâ€™s no clear evidence to suggest the number of meltwater drainages has increased over the time period they covered. But, this study provides a baseline for evaluating the spread of free-flowing water across the continent in the future. Â¶The meltwater appears to proliferate whenever Antarcticaâ€™s temperature creeps up, researchers said, a bad omen as the continent is expected to plunge deeper into global warming this century. Â¶Antarctica stands on the front lines of global warming, as rising temperature have wreaked havoc on the icy continent. Recent years have also transformed the Arctic, with significantly warmer temperatures, lower levels of sea ice, and more open water. Â¶Experts say Arctic warming creates a toxic feedback loop: as the Arctic continues to warm, it will release greater levels of the greenhouse gas methane, formerly locked in the frost, which in turn absorbs the sunâ€™s heat and further accelerates the warming of the planet. Last year, 2016, was the warmest year on record since official record keeping began in 1880, according to analyses from NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).Â¶The below video captures a meltwater stream flowing from Antarcticaâ€™s Nansen Ice Shelf into the ocean:Â¶â€œThese streams are something that require more investigation,â€ said Paul Mayewski, director of the Climate Change Institute at the University of Maine and a climatologist whoâ€™s done significant fieldwork in Antarctica. Mayewski was not involved in the study but called it â€œimpressive.â€Â¶What are the stakes? As meltwater drains across Antarctica, it flows into the crevices of the so-called â€œice shelvesâ€ that surround the continent, weakening those ice structures from within. Over time, free-flowing water could lead Antarcticaâ€™s ice shelves to collapse entirely, triggering dangerous sea level rise across the world. Â¶The Columbia University researchers expanded on these consequences in an accompanying study, also published in Nature.Â¶Sea level rise is expected to pose a massive threat to humankind this century. Global sea levels could rise between one foot and 8.2 feet by the year 2100, according to projections published by NOAA earlier this year. Though eight feet may not sound like a huge number, the consequences to human life would be devastating, as would the economic impact: researchers estimate that a rise of just six feet would be enough swallow up the homes of about six million Americans.Â¶For Mayewski, the new study is as a warning: that Antarcticaâ€™s ice sheets are more precarious than long thought. Â¶â€œCities preparing for a conservative view of sea level rise by 2100 may be underestimating the full potential,â€ he said.

title: Colorado climate diarist Billy Barr "wasnâ€™t out to prove anything" - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶GOTHIC, Colo. -- A springtime visit to Billy Barrâ€™s place in the Colorado Rockies is no simple journey. To avoid a three-mile cross country ski from the nearest paved road, first you need a forest service permit. Then you hitch a ride like ours, courtesy Dave Ochs and his Crested Butte Mountain Bike Association.Â¶But itâ€™s all worth it when you discover a remote cabin deep in the woods is home to one of the worldâ€™s most valuable â€“ and unexpected â€“ troves of scientific data.Â¶ â€œSo I came out late May, summer of â€˜72,â€ Barr said. â€œIt was such a mental relief just to have peace and quiet in my life.â€Â¶He lived in a shack that was 8 by 10 feet, he said. Â¶â€œThe wind would literally blow snow through the cracks,â€ Barr told CBS News correspondent John Blackstone.Â¶â€œYou came for the solitude, but you started to get a little bored?â€ Blackstone asked.Â¶â€œA bit of boredom, but a lot of it was justâ€¦ making my own activity,â€ Barr said.Â¶Since 1974, heâ€™s taken measurements twice a day, but it wasnâ€™t just the snow depth and when it melted. Using a hand-operated system he built himself, he also calculated how much groundwater that snow would produce when it melted. Â¶ When that wasnâ€™t enough to keep Barr busy, he started tracking wildlife and recorded it all by hand in a series of now-tattered notebooks.Â¶â€œYouâ€™ve gotta be a little obsessive though,â€ Blackstone said.Â¶â€œOh yeah!â€ Barr responded.Â¶In the early â€˜90s, scientist David Inouye from the neighboring Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory needed data for his research on wildflowers. He had heard about Barrâ€™s notebooks, but was shocked when he saw how comprehensive they were.Â¶ â€œI said, â€˜Billy! You know those data are really relevant to how the climate is changing, and how animals are responding to the changing climate,â€ Inouye said.Â¶ Barr said he had no idea his measurements would have any kind of long-term significance. Â¶â€œRemember this was mid-â€™70s, early-mid-â€™70s,â€ Barr said. â€œIf you asked me about climate change, I wouldâ€™ve said, yeah, it got warm, I took my sweater off. I mean, it meant nothing to me!â€Â¶ But now it means everything to the global scientific community, which has published his numbers in dozens of scientific papers. Â¶â€œOne of these days, Iâ€™ll read â€˜em! Yeah,â€ Barr said. â€œI wasnâ€™t out to prove anything. I just recorded the numbers.â€Â¶ â€œThis winter weâ€™ve had 21 record highs, last winter 17, the winter before, 36!â€ Barr said at his weather station.Â¶ Like most climate scientists, Barr is concerned by what his numbers show: temperatures are rising and snow is melting earlier each year.Â¶ â€œItâ€™s worrisome, obviously, itâ€™s not a good trend,â€ Barr said. â€œWill we lose water storage? Will drought increase? Will floods and famine increase?â€Â¶ But Barr leaves the answers to big questions like those to others. Heâ€™s content to do his part and head out into the wilderness, where thereâ€™s an infinite amount of data waiting to be collected.

title: Ahead of Earth Day, most Americans pessimistic about environmentâ€™s future
date:
Updated on:  April 21, 2017 / 12:52 PM
      / CBS News
content: Â¶By Jennifer De Pinto, Fred Backus, Kabir Khanna and Anthony Salvanto Â¶Few Americans expect the environment to be better for the next generation, a pessimism that has lingered for over a decade in this poll. Most (57 percent) say itâ€™ll get worse.Â¶And while protecting the environment is important to most Americans (89 percent), many feel doing so costs money and time â€“ which some (39 percent) say they simply donâ€™t have. Â¶So itâ€™s wealthier Americans who are more likely to report personally taking those steps.Â¶Thereâ€™s disagreement over recent actions by the Trump administration. Fifty-one percent say itâ€™s bad for the Trump administration to have lifted Obama-era environmental regulations, fearing that will cause more environmental harm, while 38 percent say lifting those restrictions is good, because it will make it easier for business to create jobs. Â¶Two-thirds of Americans rate the quality of the air and water where they live as at least somewhat clean, and almost no one feels theirs is very polluted, but few â€“ 28 percent - call it very clean. There are differences by where people live. Americans in rural areas -- 42 percent -- are more likely to say the quality of their air and water is very clean, compared to those in urban (25 percent) and suburban areas. Â¶More in CBS News PollsÂ¶Most Americans continue to believe that global warming exists, whatever the cause, and most believe that cause is mainly human activity. But partisanship dramatically affects these responses.Â¶Democrats are more than twice as likely as Republicans to say human activity is the main cause; most independents also cite human activity. Republicans are more divided over whether it is that or just natural patterns. Â¶Sixty-five percent of younger Americans say it is human activity. Fewer than half of seniors (42 percent) hold that view.Â¶Those who believe global warming is caused by human activity are more likely to say the environment will be worse for the next generation, and to think the recent rollback of regulations is a bad thing. Americans who say itâ€™s the earthâ€™s natural patterns are less pessimistic about the environment and support the recent lifting of environmental regulations.Â¶This poll was conducted by telephone April 11-15, 2017 among a random sample of 1,011 adults nationwide.  Data collection was conducted on behalf of CBS News by SSRS of Media, PA.  Phone numbers were dialed from samples of both standard land-line and cell phones.Â¶The poll employed a random digit dial methodology. For the landline sample, a respondent was randomly selected from all adults in the household. For the cell sample, interviews were conducted with the person who answered the phone.Â¶Interviews were conducted in English and Spanish using live interviewers.  Â¶The data have been weighted to reflect U.S. Census figures on demographic variables. Â¶The error due to sampling for results based on the entire sample could be plus or minus four percentage points. The error for subgroups may be higher and is available by request. The margin of error includes the effects of standard weighting procedures which enlarge sampling error slightly. Â¶This poll release conforms to the Standards of Disclosure of the National Council on Public Polls.

title: Scientists witness first modern case of "river piracy"
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” Scientists have witnessed the first modern case of what they call â€œriver piracyâ€ and they blame global warming. Most of the water gushing from a large glacier in northwest Canada last year suddenly switched from one river to another.Â¶That changed the Slims River from a 10-foot deep, raging river to something so shallow that it barely was above a scientistâ€™s high top sneakers at midstream.
