The melt from the Yukonâ€™s Kaskawulsh glacier now flows mostly into the Alsek River and ends up in the Pacific Ocean instead of the Arcticâ€™s Bering Sea.Â¶It seemed to all happen in about one day, last May 26, based on river gauge data, said Dan Shugar, a University of Washington Tacoma professor who studies how land changes. A 100-foot tall canyon formed at the end of the glacier, rerouting the melting water, Shugar and his colleagues wrote in a study published in Mondayâ€™s journal Nature Geoscience.Â¶The term â€œriver piracyâ€ is usually used to describe events that take a long time to occur, such as tens of thousands of years, and had not been seen in modern times, especially not this quickly, said study co-author Jim Best of the University of Illinois. Itâ€™s different from something like the Mississippi River changing course at its delta and it involves more than one river and occurs at the beginning of a waterway, not the end.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The scientists had been to the edge of the Kaskawulsh glacier in 2013. Then the Slims River was â€œswift, cold and deepâ€ and flowing fast enough that it could be dangerous to wade through, Shugar said. They returned last year to find the river shallow and as still as a lake, while the Alsek, was deeper and flowing faster.Â¶â€œWe were really surprised when we got there and there was basically no water in the river,â€ Shugar said of the Slims. â€œWe could walk across it and we wouldnâ€™t get our shirts wet. It was like a snake-shaped lake rather than a river.â€Â¶What had been a river delta at the edge of the Slims River had changed into a place full of â€œafternoon dust storms with this fine dust getting into your nose and your mouth,â€ Best said.Â¶The lack of water in the Slims wasnâ€™t because of changes in rainfall, Shugar said. They know that because itâ€™s a river fed mostly by glacial melt, not rain, and the Alsek increased in amounts similar to what disappeared from the Slims.Â¶The Kaskawulsh glacier covers about 9,650 square miles, about the size of Vermont. The front of the glacier has retreated nearly 1.2 miles since 1899, Shugar said.Â¶The scientists calculate that there is only a 1 in 200 chance that the retreating glacier and river piracy is completely natural without man-made global warming. They used weather and ice observations and a computer simulation that models how likely the glacier retreat would be with current conditions and without heat-trapping greenhouse gases.Â¶Several outside scientists praised the study as significant and sensible.Â¶â€œThis is an interesting study and reconfirms that climate change has large, widespread and sometimes surprising impacts,â€ Pennsylvania State University glacier expert Richard Alley, who wasnâ€™t part of the study, said in an email.

title: Mysterious new crack in Greenland glacier revealed in NASA photos
author: Kacey Deamer
content: Â¶There is a new crack in one of Greenlandâ€™s largest glaciers, and NASA researchers have captured the first images of the ice shelfâ€™s mysterious rift.Â¶Operation IceBridge, NASAâ€™s airborne survey of polar ice, recently completed a land-ice mission over northwest Greenland. During the mission, researchers flew over and photographed a new rift near the center of Petermann Glacierâ€™s ice shelf (the floating end of the glacier). In the survey photos, the new rift appears relatively close to a larger, known crack that is spreading toward the center of the ice shelf. [Images: Greenlandâ€™s Gorgeous Glaciers]Â¶Part of Petermann Glacierâ€™s ice shelf could break off if the two rifts intersect, but researchers with Operation IceBridge said in a post on Facebook that the â€œmedial flowlineâ€ (the flow of ice in the middle of the ice shelf) could keep the new rift from advancing.Â¶Petermann, one of Greenlandâ€™s largest glaciers, has shrunk in recent years. Previous rifts have resulted in massive icebergs breaking away from the glacier. In 2012, an iceberg the size of Manhattan broke away from the glacierâ€™s ice shelf. In 2010, another iceberg, this one four times the size of Manhattan, dropped, or calved, from Petermann. It was one of the largest ever recorded in Greenland, Live Science had reported.Â¶The glacierâ€™s new rift was discovered by Stef Lhermitte, an Earth sciences professor at Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands, while studying satellite images of the area, reported The Washington Post. Lhermitte provided coordinates of the chasm to Operation IceBridge so that researchers could conduct an aerial survey of the ice shelf.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œ[Itâ€™s] amazing to see the rift from nearby after studying it from space for several days,â€ Lhermitte told The Washington Post. â€œFrom these images alone, it is difficult to already say anything about what exactly caused the crack on this unusual spot.â€Â¶Glaciers typically crack along their sides. A rift in the center of the floating ice shelf could be due to the warming ocean waters beneath the shelf, Lhermitte hypothesized, according to The Washington Post.Â¶In other parts of the world, researchers have observed warm ocean waters that are melting ice shelves from below and weakening them at the center. A recent study of Antarcticaâ€™s Pine Island Glacier showed that subsurface cracks in the glacier were likely caused by melting underneath the floating ice shelf.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Scientists seek holy grail of climate change: Removing CO2 from the atmosphere
content: Â¶WADI ABDAH, Oman -- Deep in the jagged red mountains of Oman, geologists are drilling in search of the holy grail of reversing climate change: An efficient and cheap way to remove carbon dioxide from the air and oceans. Â¶They are coring samples from one of the worldâ€™s only exposed sections of the Earthâ€™s mantle to uncover how a spontaneous natural process millions of years ago transformed CO2 into limestone and marble. Â¶As the world mobilizes to confront climate change, the main focus has been on reducing emissions through fuel efficient cars and cleaner power plants. But some researchers are also testing ways to remove or recycle carbon already in the seas and sky. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The Hellisheidi geothermal plant in Iceland injects carbon into volcanic rock. At the massive Sinopec fertilizer plant in China, CO2 is filtered and reused as fuel. In all, 16 industrial projects currently capture and store around 27 million tons of CO2, according to the International Energy Agency. Thatâ€™s less than 0.1 percent of global emissions - but the technology has shown promise. Â¶â€œAny one technique is not guaranteed to succeed,â€ said Stuart Haszeldine, a geology professor at the University of Edinburgh who serves on a U.N. climate body studying how to reduce atmospheric carbon. Â¶â€œIf weâ€™re interested as a species, weâ€™ve got to try a lot harder and do a lot more and a lot of different actions,â€ he said. Â¶One such action is underway in the al-Hajjar Mountains of Oman, in a quiet corner of the Arabian Peninsula, where a unique rock formation pulls carbon out of thin air. Â¶Peter Kelemen, a 61-year-old geochemist at Columbia Universityâ€™s Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, has been exploring Omanâ€™s hills for nearly three decades. â€œYou can walk down these beautiful canyons and basically descend 20 kilometers (12 miles) into the earthâ€™s interior,â€ he said. Â¶The sultanate boasts the largest exposed sections of the Earthâ€™s mantle, thrust up by plate tectonics millions of years ago. The mantle contains peridotite, a rock that reacts with the carbon in air and water to form marble and limestone. Â¶â€œEvery single magnesium atom in these rocks has made friends with the carbon dioxide to form solid limestone, magnesium carbonate, plus quartz,â€ he said as he patted a rust-colored boulder in the Wadi Mansah valley. Â¶â€œThereâ€™s about a billion tons of CO2 in this mountain,â€ he said, pointing off to the east. Â¶Rain and springs pull carbon from the exposed mantle to form stalactites and stalagmites in mountain caves. Natural pools develop surface scum of white carbonate. Scratch off this thin white film, Kelemen said, and itâ€™ll grow back in a day. Â¶â€œFor a geologist this is supersonic,â€ he said. Â¶He and a team of 40 scientists have formed the Oman Drilling Project in order to better understand how that process works and whether it could be used to scrub the earthâ€™s carbon-laden atmosphere. The $3.5 million project has support from across the globe, including NASA. Â¶Carbon dioxide is the primary greenhouse gas driving climate change, which threatens political instability, severe weather and food insecurity worldwide, according to the United Nations climate body. Â¶Natural CO2 levels have risen from 280 to 405 parts per million since the Industrial Revolution, and current estimates hold that the world will be 6 C hotter by 2100. Â¶In 2015, 196 nations signed the Paris climate accords, agreeing to curb greenhouse gas emissions to levels that would keep the rise in the Earthâ€™s temperature to under 2 C. Â¶That has injected new urgency into the work underway in Oman, where Kelemanâ€™s team recently spent four months extracting dozens of core samples, which they hope to use to construct a geological history of the process that turns CO2 into carbonate. Â¶â€œItâ€™s like a jigsaw puzzle,â€ said Nehal Warsi, 33, who oversees the drilling process. Â¶Around 13 tons of core samples from four different sites will be sent to the Chikyu, a state-of-the-art research vessel off the coast of Japan, where Keleman and other geologists will analyze them in round-the-clock shifts. Â¶They hope to answer the question of how the rocks managed to capture so much CO2 over the course of 90 million years - and to see if thereâ€™s a way to speed up the timetable. Â¶Kelemen thinks a drilling operation could cycle carbon-rich water into the newly formed seabed on oceanic ridges far below the surface. Just like in Omanâ€™s mountains, the submerged rock would chemically absorb carbon from the water. The water could then be cycled back to the surface to absorb more CO2 from the atmosphere, in a sort of conveyor belt. Â¶Such a project would require years more of testing, but Kelemen hopes the energy industry, with its offshore drilling expertise and deep pockets, will take interest. Â¶â€œUltimately, if the goal is to capture billions and billions of tons of carbon, thatâ€™s where James Cameron comes in,â€ he said, half joking, referring to the â€œTitanicâ€ and â€œAvatarâ€ director who has also pioneered undersea technology. Cameron himself piloted a submersible to the deepest point on Earth in 2012 and retrieved samples while filming â€œDeepsea Challenge.â€ Â¶â€œHe hasnâ€™t responded to my messages yet,â€ Kelemen said.

title: World adds record amount of renewable energy capacity in 2016 -- now what?
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Green energy has hit a new milestone: The world added record levels of renewable energy capacity in 2016 despite an investment level that was 23 percent lower than the previous year, according to a new United Nations report. Â¶Globally, those low expenditures -- the lowest seen since 2013 -- were largely due to declining prices in renewable energy, a sign of vitality in the sector. For instance, the average dollar cost per megawatt for solar photovoltaics and wind energy dropped by more than 10 percent, according to the report. Â¶In total, the world spent $241.6 billion on renewable energy last year. (That excludes spending on â€œlarge hydro,â€ which largely refers to projects that use a dam and a reservoir to retain water from a river.)Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The report reflects an important moment, said David Konisky, associate professor at Indiana Universityâ€™s School of Public and Environmental Affairs.Â¶â€œIt reflects a slow but sustained trajectory towards cleaner sources of energy. It reflects the fact that the cost of renewable technologies are coming down pretty drastically,â€ Konisky said.Â¶Last yearâ€™s spending created 139 gigawatts of renewable energy infrastructure, 8 percent more than the amount of renewable capacity built in 2015. Â¶â€œThe report is a reminder that, if you set aside policy for a moment, there are factors in the marketplace which are continuing to push countries towards cleaner sources of energy,â€ Konisky said.Â¶Of course, market forces alone cannot create the conditions required for renewable energy transformation. Policy also matters.Â¶Since the election of President Trump, the U.S. has made a dramatic pivot from its global environmental agenda under President Obama. Â¶Earlier this week, the U.S. dealt a blow to international climate cooperation: Top officials from the â€œGroup of Sevenâ€ industrial nations reached a standstill in their attempts to draft a joint declaration due to a Trump administration review of climate policies. The final declaration was left incomplete. Â¶A longtime critic of the landmark Paris Agreement, Mr. Trump has vowed to withdraw from the global pact governing lower carbon emissions.Â¶Domestically, Environmental Protection Agency chair Scott Pruitt has ushered in a new chapter in the history of the EPA since his February confirmation, from reversing a key rule underpinning the Clean Water Act to clearing the way for the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. Before assuming leadership of the EPA, the former attorney general of Oklahoma made a name for himself among EPA opponents for suing the agency more than a dozen times. Recent emails unearthed by the Associated Press reveal Scott Pruittâ€™s strong ties to business leaders in the fossil fuel industry, an industry whose carbon emissions Pruitt is now charged with regulating.Â¶Reflecting global averages, the UN report painted a rosy picture of renewable energy infrastructure worldwide. However, the report also documented a significant slowdown in China, Japan and some emerging markets.Â¶In looking at the evolution of clean energy, Konisky emphasized the importance of examining multiple forces at play at the same time -- including political and market forces that may be counteracting each other. Â¶â€œFor the U.S., when you have policy moving in the opposite direction as the markets, it may slow down some of the de-carbonization and movement towards clean energy,â€ he said.

title: Dozens of icebergs drift into shipping lanes, causing Atlantic standstill
content: Â¶PROVIDENCE, R.I. â€” More than 400 icebergs have drifted into the North Atlantic shipping lanes over the past week in an unusually large swarm for this early in the season, forcing vessels to slow to a crawl or take detours of hundreds of miles.Â¶Experts are attributing it to uncommonly strong counter-clockwise winds that are drawing the icebergs south, and perhaps also global warming, which is accelerating the process by which chunks of the Greenland ice sheet break off and float away.Â¶As of Monday, there were about 450 icebergs near the Grand Banks of Newfoundland, up from 37 a week earlier, according to the U.S. Coast Guardâ€™s International Ice Patrol in New London, Connecticut. Those kinds of numbers are usually not seen until late May or early June. The average for this time of year is about 80.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In the waters close to where the Titanic went down in 1912, the icebergs are forcing ships to take precautions.Â¶Instead of cutting straight across the ocean, trans-Atlantic vessels are taking detours that can add around 400 miles to the trip. Thatâ€™s a day and a half of added travel time for many large cargo ships.Â¶Close to the Newfoundland coast, cargo ships owned by Oceanex are throttling way back to 3 or 4 knots as they make their way to their homeport in St. Johnâ€™s, which can add up to a day to the trip, said executive chairman, Capt. Sid Hynes.Â¶One ship was pulled out of service for repairs after hitting a chunk of ice, he said.Â¶â€œIt makes everything more expensive,â€ Hynes said Wednesday. â€œYouâ€™re burning more fuel, itâ€™s taking a longer time, and itâ€™s hard on the equipment.â€ He called it a â€œvery unusual year.â€Â¶Coast Guard Cmdr. Gabrielle McGrath, who leads the ice patrol, said she has never seen such a drastic increase in such a short time. Adding to the danger, three icebergs were discovered outside the boundaries of the area the Coast Guard had advised mariners to avoid, she said.Â¶McGrath is predicting a fourth consecutive â€œextreme ice seasonâ€ with more than 600 icebergs in the shipping lanes.Â¶Most icebergs entering the North Atlantic have â€œcalvedâ€ off the Greenland ice sheet. Michael Mann, director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University, said it is possible climate change is leading to more icebergs in the shipping lanes, but wind patterns are also important.Â¶In 2014, there were 1,546 icebergs in the shipping lanes â€” the sixth most severe season on record since 1900, according to the patrol. There were 1,165 icebergs in 2015 and 687 in 2016.Â¶The International Ice Patrol was formed after the sinking of the Titanic to monitor iceberg danger in the North Atlantic and warn ships. It conducts reconnaissance flights that are used to produce charts.Â¶In 104 years, no ship that has heeded the warnings has struck an iceberg, according to the ice patrol.

title: House climate change hearing devolves into name calling
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” Climate science and politics too often revert to name calling and bullying, which can get in the way of real work.Â¶That was the only thing House Science Committee members, three scientists who often clash with mainstream science, and a prominent climate scientist could agree to at a contentious hearing Wednesday.Â¶They couldnâ€™t agree on who was doing the name calling, though.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Republicans and three scientists invited by them to testify accused the mainstream climate scientist, Michael Mann of Pennsylvania State University, and major international science panels of trying to silence researchers who disagree about the magnitude of global warming.Â¶Mann, meanwhile, said he was harassed by people trying to stifle science.Â¶Mann and Republican Rep. Dana Rohrabacher of California both compared the other sideâ€™s behavior to repression in the former Soviet Union under Josef Stalin. Mann first raised the Stalin analogy, then Rohrabacher used the comparison four times after that to talk about Mann and other mainstream climate scientists.Â¶â€œFor scientists to call names to beat someone into submission, thatâ€™s a Stalinist tactic,â€ Rohrabacher said.Â¶Former Georgia Tech climate scientist Judith Curry, who often clashes with mainstream science, said she was the victim of â€œgutter tacticsâ€ by â€œscientists who demonize their opponents.â€Â¶She pointed to the way she and Mann have clashed, saying the Penn State professor wrongly called her a climate denier, when she acknowledges that the world is warming and humans play a role. She disagrees with mainstream climate science over implications of global change, how much the world is warming, how much is human-caused, and its certainty.Â¶At first Mann said he didnâ€™t call Curry a denier. But in his written not oral testimony he called Curry â€œa climate science denier.â€ Mann said thereâ€™s a difference between denying climate change and â€œdenying established scienceâ€ on how much humans cause climate change, which he said Curry did.Â¶Mann said the chance that humans are causing less than half of the global warming now going on is less than 1 in 10,000, citing an international panel of scientists convened by the United Nations. Curry disagreed, insisting itâ€™s not clear. â€œI just donâ€™t know how much is human versus how much is natural,â€ she said.Â¶When pressed by Rep. Barry Loudermilk (R-Ga.) on whether humans are mostly to blame, Mann replied: â€œI go with physics. You can go with opinion.â€Â¶The American Meteorological Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science both said in email statements to The Associated Press that the overwhelming scientific evidence is clear that global warming is primarily caused by humans.Â¶Republican committee Chairman Lamar Smith of Texas, a lawyer, said, â€œmuch of climate science today appears to be based more on exaggerations, personal agendas and questionable predictions than on the scientific method.â€Â¶Led by Representative Smith, the House Science Committee opposed the Obama administrationâ€™s efforts to regulate the gas, oil and coal industries and reduce carbon emissions.Â¶The panel of three scientists who often clash with mainstream science and Mann was not representative of the peer reviewed research in the field, which overwhelmingly finds climate change to be real, human caused and a problem, Democrats said.Â¶Though climate headlines tend to focus on places like Antarctica, where global warming is rapidly transforming the physical environment, climate change is upending the U.S., too.Â¶Earlier this month, doctors representing 11 top medical societies lobbied in Washington for more aggressive action against climate change, which they said poses an immediate health threat to millions of Americans, citing problems such as widespread heart and lung disease associated with air pollution and increased mortality from floods and other extreme weather events. Â¶The U.S. is already setting twice as many daily heat records as cold records, and research suggests breaking heat records will become more and more routine as man-made climate change worsens.Â¶Retired Adm. David Titley, now a Penn State meteorology professor, said in an email to the AP that scientists should boycott House hearings because it is a â€œcharadeâ€ and perpetuates the myth that there is a legitimate scientific debate on the issue.Â¶Democratic Rep. Don Beyer of Virginia asked, â€œWhy canâ€™t we all just get along?â€ and then answered his own question: â€œItâ€™s because the stakes are so large.â€

title: Rugged Antarctica shows its ice in new 3D map
author: Stephanie Pappas
content: Â¶A new three-dimensional view of Antarctica shows off the southernmost continent in all of its rugged glory.Â¶Created by satellite data collected by the European Space Agencyâ€™s CryoSat, the map can be downloaded at a University of Leeds website and will soon be hosted at the portal for the United Kingdomâ€™s Center for Polar Observation and Modelling (CPOM).Â¶â€œWe used around 250 million measurements taken by CryoSat between 2010 and 2016 to create the most comprehensive picture of Antarctic ice elevation currently available,â€ Tom Slater, a researcher at the center, said in a statement.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶CryoSat uses radar altimeter to measure ice-sheet thickness at the North and South Poles. This method involves beaming radio waves toward the ground from a satellite and measuring the time it takes for the reflected waves to bounce back. The instrument aboard the CryoSat satellite is the first of its kind designed for monitoring ice, according to the ESA; it can also measure sea level. [Images of Melt: Earthâ€™s Vanishing Ice]Â¶The measurements are useful to scientists who are trying to understand changes in the Antarctic ice sheet, including where increased snowfall is causing accumulating ice and where melting and iceberg calving are causing ice losses.Â¶â€œThis should benefit not only studies of the Antarctic ice sheet, but also projections of future sea-level rise,â€ Andrew Shepherd, the director of CPOM, said in a statement.Â¶As the climate warms, Antarcticaâ€™s ice is changing. In 2002, the Larsen B ice shelf collapsed spectacularly, and a massive rift in the Larsen C ice shelf is threatening to do the same to that floating ice. When floating ice shelves collapse, they do not raise sea levels by themselves, but their loss does remove a barrier to the flow of land-based ice into the oceans.Â¶Scientists have observed a trend toward melting on the land-based West Antarctica ice sheet in recent years, according to the National Snow and Ice Data Center. The data from East Antarctica has been trickier to interpret, with some research finding that the region was adding ice because of increased snowfall. (Warm air can hold more moisture, so as the globe warms, precipitation might increase in some areas.) Because of the balancing act between ice loss in the west and ice gains in the east, there has been a long-running scientific controversy over whether the continent as a whole is losing or gaining ice.Â¶Alarmingly, field scientists recently discovered huge craters called moulins on East Antarcticaâ€™s Roi Baudouin ice shelf. The melt features had never been seen before on an ice shelf. Research published in the journal Nature Climate Change in December 2016 on the moulins and new satellite data found that East Antartica may be more vulnerable to melt than previously believed.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Climate change-driven famine poses global security threat
author: Pamela Falk
content: Â¶UNITED NATIONS -- The emergency relief coordinator for the United Nations is warning of the worst famine since the world organization was founded in 1945. It is putting an estimated 20 million lives immediately at risk, and while war is exacerbating the disaster in places like South Sudan, Stephen Oâ€™Brien says the primary culprit is climate change. Â¶Drought and acidification of the oceans is at a crisis point. Drinking water is sparse, animals are dying, and populations are on the move, desperate to find food. Â¶As the U.N. warns the window is fast closing to avert a massive human tragedy, the Trump Administration is rolling out its new energy independence order to change the U.S. approach to climate change and reverse some of the previous administrationâ€™s climate regulations.Â¶More in Famine and droughtÂ¶ 	 	 U.N. Secretary General Antonio Guterres has said the agencies rushing to help people staring down starvation need to raise $4.4 million by the end of this month for the four countries at highest risk; Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen.Â¶ 	 	 â€œBy 2040, 1 in 4 children -- 600 million children -- will live in areas of extremely high water stress,â€ Anthony Lake, Executive Director of U.N. childrenâ€™s agency UNICEF says in a new report, â€œThirsting for a Future.â€Â¶ 	 	 â€œThe effects of climate change reduce the quantity and quality of water, causing rising temperatures, help bacteria and other pathogens to flourish, and disappearing glaciers leave land dry and arid,â€ Lake says.Â¶ 	 	 The effects of climate change -- and drought in particular -- are already affecting 1.4 million children who face imminent risk of death from severe acute malnutrition as the famine spreads. In Ethiopia alone, the UNICEF report says, â€œwe anticipate that more than 9 million people will be without safe drinking water in 2017.â€Â¶ 	 	 At the beginning of June, the U.N. will host the Ocean Conference at U.N. Headquarters in New York to try to mobilize scientists to address famine caused by climate change. Â¶U.N. Climate Executive Secretary Patricia Espinosa and Melanne Vereer, Executive Director of Georgetownâ€™s Women, Peace and Security program, wrote this week that â€œclimate change is a security threat and a vulnerability multiplier.â€ Â¶They argue that the danger is most present in a handful of North African nations where the inability to find water for subsistence farmers is leading many into a poverty trap. Â¶Michael Sandler, U.S. Fund for UNICEFâ€™s content director, says climate change and famine are intertwined not only in the four countries already experiencing or threatened by mass-hunger, but in places like Kenya and Uganda, where refugees fleeing drought are pouring in.  Â¶In Senegal this week, U.N. Deputy Secretary-General Amina J. Mohammed explained why helping the victims -- particularly the younger victims -- of climate change-induced famine is not just a matter of charity, but security. Â¶â€œA disengaged population of youth is prone to large-scale migration and susceptible to radicalization,â€ she said.

title: Renowned climate scientist worries about intimidation, lack of govt. funding - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶SAN FRANCISCO -- Climate scientist Ben Santer has long believed that with temperatures rising and glaciers melting, climate change denial would melt away.Â¶â€œBoy how naive were we,â€ he said. Â¶Now heâ€™s faced with a new president raising old doubts that climate change is a hoax.Â¶â€œImagine you spend your entire life trying to do one thing â€¦ and then someone comes along and says everything youâ€™ve done is a hoax or a conspiracy â€¦ or is worthless. What do you do with that?â€ Santer said.Â¶In the 1990â€™s, Santer became one of the first scientists to analyze all the climate data and reach what at the time was a startling conclusion: â€œThe balance of evidence suggests a discernible human influence on global climate. And like it or not, I was the guy who carried the can for that finding,â€ he said.Â¶Santer wrote an open letter to then-President elect Trump, urging him not to listen to â€œignorant voices.â€ He says scientists have proven again and again that arguments made by climate change deniers are wrong.Â¶â€œThese â€˜zombie argumentsâ€™ take on a life of their own, once theyâ€™re they keep on coming back. And you canâ€™t slay them,â€ he said.Â¶â€œItâ€™s not a hoax. This matters to every American.â€Â¶Now, climate change funding is on the federal chopping block. Â¶â€œIf funding goes away, it will be difficult for me to do my job,â€ Santer said. Â¶Difficult, he says, but not impossible, since much of Santerâ€™s research at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory is covered by grants. What worries him more, he says, is a new climate of intimidation.Â¶â€œThereâ€™s been a statement, get with the program or get out.  If the program is to advance ignorance, then Iâ€™m not with the program,â€ he said.

title: Trump scraps Clean Power Plan: What that means for Earth
author: Laura Geggel
content: Â¶President Donald Trump signed an executive order Tuesday to dismantle the Clean Power Plan.Â¶The plan, which President Barack Obamaâ€™s administration put into effect in 2015, was designed to cut power plant emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas that is warming the planet. The Clean Power Plan requires that, by 2030, the power sectorâ€™s CO2 emissions be brought down to 32 percent below their 2005 levels, according to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).Â¶EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, who previously challenged the legality of the plan when he was Oklahomaâ€™s attorney general, recently said on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week with George Stephanopoulosâ€ that the rollback would be both â€œpro-growth and pro-environment.â€ But what are the scientific consequences of discarding the plan? [The Year in Climate Change: 2016â€™s Most Depressing Stories]Â¶For starters, without the mandate to lower CO2 emissions, Americaâ€™s electrical power industry could continue to emit high levels of CO2, said Ken Kimmell, the president of the Union of Concerned Scientists, a science advocacy group. The industryâ€™s current CO2 emissions equate to 30 percent of the annual such emissions for the country, and higher levels of CO2 in the atmosphere are linked to climate change, he said.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The Clean Power Plan was the nationâ€™s first limit on CO2 from power plants, Kimmell told Live Science. Â¶EPA officials had said they expected the plan to help the country meet its goals as outlined in the Paris Agreement, a 2015 deal in which 195 countries pledged to reduce CO2 emissions. But Pruitt said the plan was not tied to the Paris deal.Â¶â€œThe Clean Power Plan is not tethered to the Paris accords,â€ he told Stephanopoulos.Â¶However, the new administration doesnâ€™t appear to have a replacement for the Clean Power Plan, Kimmell said.Â¶â€œTheyâ€™re just going to repeal it, so thatâ€™s a big problem,â€ Kimmell said.Â¶In addition to warming the planet, outdoor air pollution is tied to a number of maladies, including death. In the United States, the plan was projected to prevent 3,600 premature deaths; 1,700 heart attacks; 90,000 asthma attacks; and 300,000 missed workdays and school days, the EPA said.Â¶The plan would have helped the nation move away from burning coal and toward â€œcleaner sources, like [natural] gas, and even really clean sources, like renewable energy, such as wind and solar,â€ Kimmell said. â€œThere are significant health benefits when you switch from a dirty resource like coal to cleaner resources.â€ [8 Ways Global Warming Is Already Changing the World]Â¶During the second presidential debate in the 2016 campaign, Trump mentioned the use of â€œclean coalâ€ technology. This technology doesnâ€™t yet exist, experts have told Live Science.Â¶The idea behind such technology is to find a way to capture CO2 and other pollutants from power plants before those materials enter the atmosphere. But developing this technology costs money, meaning power plants likely wonâ€™t do it unless the government motivates them, Edward Rubin, a professor of engineering and public policy at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, told Live Science in October 2016.Â¶â€œFrom everything Iâ€™ve read about Mr. Trumpâ€™s view of climate change, I suspect he would not be a proponent of policies to reduce carbon emissions drastically,â€ Rubin said at the time.Â¶Federal policy isnâ€™t the only force driving the development of clean energy in the U.S. State legislatures across the country have put forth hundreds of bills supporting clean energy, according to InsideClimate News. For instance, politicians in almost a dozen states have sponsored bills that would expand renewable electric power, InsideClimate News reported.  Â¶But some of these bills face opposition from other state politicians, and from groups such as the American Legislative Exchange Council, Americans for Prosperity, the Heartland Institute, and utility and fossil fuel companies, InsideClimate News reported.Â¶Overall, policies that protect the environment thrive when the federal government supports them, Kimmell said. For instance, â€œsince 2007, our electricity consumption has stayed flat even while the economy has grown,â€ he said.Â¶This happened, in part, because of the governmentâ€™s efforts to promote energy-efficient products, especially through its Energy Star program, which labeled energy efficient appliances such as LED light bulbs, dishwashers and â€œrefrigerators that use 80 percent less energy than their predecessors,â€ Kimmell said.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Trump signs executive order dismantling Obama environmental regulations
author: Jacqueline Alemany
content: Â¶ President Trump signed a sweeping executive order on Tuesday to begin the process of dismantling environmental regulations implemented under the Obama administration to aggressively fight climate change.  Â¶Mr. Trump hailed it as â€œthe start of a new era in American energy productionâ€ in remarks before signing the Energy Independence executive order at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). His order aims to unwind the core of President Obamaâ€™s 2013 Climate Action Plan. The order â€œdirects the EPA to suspend, revise, or rescind the Clean Power Plan.â€ The Clean Power Plan limits carbon emissions at coal-fired power plants. Â¶Mr. Trumpâ€™s executive order also lifts the moratorium on federal coal leasing, rescinds restrictions on hydraulic fracking, and eliminates the National Environmental Policy Act, a set of guidelines for agencies to consider climate change into their decision making process. Â¶More in Trump's First 100 DaysÂ¶â€œMy administration is putting an end to the war on coal -- going to have clean coal, really clean coal,â€ Mr. Trump declared.    Â¶The executive order also mandates that every agency conduct a 180-day review that identifies all regulations and rules that â€œimpedeâ€ energy production. Mr. Trump plans to use the reports to craft his administrationâ€™s â€œAmerica Firstâ€ energy blueprint to serve what the administration calls the â€œtwin goalâ€ of protecting the environment and  strengthening the economy by promoting energy production. Â¶The president said the order would â€œreverse government intrusionâ€ and â€œcancel job-killing regulations.â€Â¶The senior administration official said Mr. Trump aims to â€œstrengthen the nationâ€™s energy security by reducing unnecessary regulatory obstacles that restrict the responsible use of domestic energy resources.â€Â¶Critics argue that Mr. Trumpâ€™s anti-climate change initiatives that resist transitioning from coal and gas to clean energy will in fact hurt the economy.  Â¶â€œThe best way to protect workers and the environment is to invest in growing the clean energy economy that is already outpacing fossil fuels, and ensuring no one is left behind,â€  Michael Brune, the executive director of the Sierra Club, wrote in a statement. â€œAt a time when we can declare independence from dirty fuels by embracing clean energy, this action could only deepen our dependence on fuels that pollute our air, water and climate  while making our kids sicker.â€ Â¶During the Trump administrationâ€™s review of President Obamaâ€™s Clean Power Plan, the White House is also rolling back the federal regulation of methane emissions from the oil and gas industry.  Â¶The senior White House official said that the president and the administration accept the scientific view of climate change but they disagree with the Obama administration over policy prescriptions.  Â¶There is no mention of the Paris Agreement on climate change, from which Mr. Trump has previously said he would withdraw. Roughly 200 countries agreed to the climate plan that cuts greenhouse gases, but the senior administration official says that they have not made a final decision on the matter.

title: Trump executive order will dismantle Obama environmental regulations
author: Jacqueline Alemany
date:
Updated on:  March 28, 2017 / 3:31 AM
      / CBS News
content: Â¶President Trump will sign a sweeping executive order on Tuesday to begin the process of dismantling environmental regulations implemented under the Obama administration to aggressively fight climate change.  Â¶The Energy Independence executive order, which Trump will sign at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), attacks the core of President Obamaâ€™s 2013 Climate Action Plan. A senior White House official said Monday that the order â€œdirects the EPA to suspend, revise, or rescind the Clean Power Plan,â€ adding that the EPA would â€œproceed in a manner that upholds the rule of lawâ€ and would continue to abide by the Clean Air Act.  Â¶The executive order also mandates that every agency conduct a 180-day review that identifies all regulations and rules that â€œimpedeâ€ energy production. Mr. Trump plans to use the reports to craft his administrationâ€™s â€œAmerica Firstâ€ energy blueprint to serve what the administration calls the â€œtwin goalâ€ of protecting the environment and  strengthening the economy by promoting energy production. Â¶More in Trump's First 100 DaysÂ¶According to the senior administration official, Mr. Trump aims to â€œstrengthen the nationâ€™s energy security by reducing unnecessary regulatory obstacles that restrict the responsible use of domestic energy resources. This order will help keep energy and electricity affordable, reliable, and clean in order to boost economic growth and job creation.â€ Â¶Scott Pruitt, the head of the EPA, echoed the Trump administrationâ€™s â€œpro-growth and pro-environment approach to how we do regulation in this countryâ€ on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ on Sunday. Â¶But critics argue that Mr. Trumpâ€™s anti-climate change initiatives that resist transitioning from coal and gas to clean energy will in fact hurt the economy.  Â¶â€œThe best way to protect workers and the environment is to invest in growing the clean energy economy that is already outpacing fossil fuels, and ensuring no one is left behind,â€  Michael Brune, the executive director of the Sierra Club, wrote in a statement. â€œAt a time when we can declare independence from dirty fuels by embracing clean energy, this action could only deepen our dependence on fuels that pollute our air, water and climate  while making our kids sicker.â€ Â¶Mr. Trumpâ€™s executive order also lifts the moratorium on federal coal leasing, rescinds restrictions on hydraulic fracking, and eliminates the National Environmental Policy Act, a set of guidelines for agencies to consider climate change into their decision making process.Â¶While the Trump administration initiates a review of President Obamaâ€™s Clean Power Plan, the White House is lifting the moratorium on federal coal leasing, and rolling back the federal regulation of methane emissions from the oil and gas industry.  Â¶The senior White House official said that the president and the administration accept the scientific view of climate change but they disagree with the Obama administration over policy prescriptions.  Â¶There is no mention of the Paris Agreement on climate change, from which Mr. Trump has previously said he would withdraw. Roughly 200 countries agreed to the climate plan that cuts greenhouse gases, but the senior administration official says that they have not made a final decision on the matter.

title: Arctic sea ice dwindles to record low for winter
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- The frigid top of the Earth just set yet another record for low levels of sea ice in what scientists say is just the latest signal of an overheating world.Â¶The National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado says the Arctic this month set a record low for winter peak sea ice area: 5.57 million square miles (14.42 million square kilometers). Â¶Thatâ€™s about 35,000 square miles (97,000 square kilometers) â€” an area about the size of Maine â€” below 2015â€™s record. Last year had a shade more than 2015, but nearly a tied record.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶This puts the Arctic in a â€œdeep holeâ€ as the crucial spring and summer melt season starts and more regions will likely be ice-free, said Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado, which released the findings Wednesday.Â¶â€œItâ€™s a key part of the Earthâ€™s climate system and weâ€™re losing it,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™re losing the ice in all seasons now.â€Â¶The record ice melt comes at the end of a season marked by unusually warm temperatures in the Arctic. During Christmas week, the North Pole soared to about 50 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than normal, a weather pattern Paul Mayewski, professor at the University of Maineâ€™s Climate Change Institute, described as â€œremarkable.â€Â¶At the other end of the world, Antarctica, where sea ice reaches its lowest point of the year in March, also hit a record low mark. Antarctic sea ice varies widely unlike Arctic sea ice, which has steadily decreased.Â¶The ice data center measures how wide sea ice extends based on satellite imagery. Itâ€™s harder to measure the thickness and overall volume, but data from the University of Washington show that as of late last month ice volume levels were down 42 percent from 1979, said polar science center chief Axel Schweiger.Â¶Several scientists called the sea ice loss disturbing.Â¶â€œItâ€™s evidence that the climate at the top of the world continues to change faster than anywhere else on Earth with impacts to us that are still frankly unknown,â€ Pennsylvania State University meteorology professor and retired admiral David W. Titley, said in an email.Â¶Scientists blame a combination of natural random weather and man-made global warming from the burning of coal, oil and gas. The winter of 2016-2017 was unusually toasty and the Arctic saw three â€œextreme heat waves,â€ Serreze said.Â¶A new study earlier this month in the journal Nature Climate Change found that natural causes can explain between 30 and 50 percent of plunging September sea ice lows, while Serezze and others give climate change an even bigger role in sea ice loss.Â¶A relatively new idea â€” that still divides meteorologists â€” links the shriveling ice cap at the North Pole to a weaker polar vortex and weak and ambling jet stream, which can mean more extreme weather for a good part of the rest of the world.Â¶â€œRecent cold spells and big snowstorms that we have experienced over the past few winters have occurred when the polar vortex is weak,â€ top winter weather forecaster Judah Cohen, of the private Atmospheric Environmental Research in Lexington, Massachusetts, said in an email.Â¶Itâ€™s not just the weather.Â¶As more regions become free of ice, shipping lanes will open in the Arctic, there will be more drilling for oil and gas and more overall economic activity. And that may mean rising tensions between countries over newly available resources, Serreze said.Â¶â€œThe Arctic is the canary in the climateâ€™s coal mine,â€ said Texas Tech climate scientist Katharine Hayhoe. â€œWhat happens in the Arctic doesnâ€™t stay in the Arctic. This entire planet is interconnected.â€

title: Climate change is killing this remnant of the Ice Age
author: Brian Kahn
content: Â¶Humans are in the process of changing the planet in a way that hasnâ€™t happened in 2.6 million years.Â¶For eons, the Laurentide Ice Sheet has been a fixture of North America. At its peak, it covered the majority of Canada and sent icy tendrils down across the Midwest and Northeast, covering Chicago, New York and Toronto in a mile or more of ice. It helped carved mountains as it advanced, and it filled the Great Lakes as it receded at the end of the last Ice Age.Â¶About 2,000 years ago, the ice sheet remnants reached equilibrium on Baffin Island, Canadaâ€™s largest island, now dubbed the Barnes Ice Cap. But that equilibrium has been disrupted by human-driven climate change.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶A new study shows that the last vestige of the once-mighty ice sheet faces near certain death, even if the world rapidly curtails its carbon pollution. The results indicate the Arctic has entered a state nearly unheard of since the Pliocene, an epoch when the Arctic was largely free of ice.Â¶â€œThis is the disappearance of a feature from the last glacial age, which would have probably survived without anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions,â€ said Adrien Gilbert, a glaciologist at Simon Fraser University in British Columbia, Canada and lead author of the new study.Â¶The Barnes Ice Cap covers an area about the size of Delaware. After reaching a near steady state 2,000 years ago, the ice cap began shrinking in the late 1800s, with a marked increase in its decline since the 1990s. That coincides with the rapid rise in human carbon pollution, which has also driven a roughly 1.8 degree Fahrenheit increase in the global average temperature over that period.Â¶But researchers can look back much deeper into the ice capâ€™s history using other clues. The new research, published on Monday in Geophysical Research Letters, looked at an array of amazingly named cosmogenic radionuclides in bedrock around the ice cap to tease out when the ground was free of ice.Â¶Cosmogenic radionuclides are isotopes that form when exposed to cosmic rays. That can only happen when the ground isnâ€™t covered by ice, giving researchers a way to see how rare the current shrinking ice cap is.Â¶Their findings show that there were two periods where ice extent was roughly as tiny as it is now. Both periods came hundreds of thousands of years ago and were due to natural changes in the earthâ€™s tilt and orbit that helped warm the planet.Â¶Todayâ€™s rapid change is different because human carbon pollution is the main driver of the unrelenting warmth in the region, which is warming twice as fast as the rest of the world. The findings indicate that the Arctic likely hasnâ€™t been this warm in 2.6 million years.Â¶Looking into the future using climate models, sustained warming almost certainly spells doom for the ice sheet. On our current trajectory of carbon pollution, the research indicates that the ice cap is likely to disappear in the next 300 years. Thatâ€™s a geological blink of an eye for an icy legacy that stretched across millions of years.Â¶Even under a best-case scenario, with human carbon pollution peaking in 2020 and decreasing rapidly thereafter, the ice cap will still likely melt away in the next 500 years.Â¶â€œTheir study convincingly reveals that the Barnes Ice Cap will likely disappear within 300 years, taking with it the last remnants of the Laurentide Ice Sheet that once blanketed northern North America some 20,000 years ago,â€ Alex Gardner, an ice researcher at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said while lauding the state of the art ice modeling effort.Â¶The findings underscore the wealth of alarming information coming out of the Arctic. Sea ice is set to hit a record-low maximum for the third year in a row, warm air has repeatedly cranked up the thermostat this winter and forests are burning at an unprecedented pace.Â¶The fate of the Barnes Ice Cap is similar to other land ice across the region, including the monstrous Greenland ice sheet. Their melt will help fuel sea level rise around the globe.Â¶â€œIf it was just the Barnes Ice Cap that melted, there would be little need for coastal communities to worry,â€ Gardner said. â€œUnfortunately the Barnes Ice Cap will not respond in isolation. As the atmosphere and oceans warm in the coming decades, ice sheets and glaciers will retreat globally resulting in massive transfers of ice into the oceans, raising sea levels by multiple feet by 2100.â€Â¶You May Also Like:Â¶Originally published on Climate Central.

title: World needs dramatic energy shift from fossil fuels, studies warn
content: Â¶BERLIN â€” The world must swiftly shift energy production away from fossil fuels if it is to prevent a dangerous increase in global temperatures, according to separate reports released Monday by two international agencies.Â¶Both reports concluded that fundamentally changing the way power is produced would require considerable investment â€” though there were would also be savings due to improvements in energy efficiency.Â¶The International Energy Agency and the International Renewable Energy Agency were asked to outline scenarios that would keep global average temperature increases below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, compared with preindustrial times.Â¶To ensure a two-thirds chance of that happening, the IEA said, â€œwould require an unparalleled ramp up of all low-carbon technologies in all countries.â€Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Ambitious measures would include â€œthe rapid phase-out of fossil fuel subsidies, CO2 prices rising to unprecedented levels, extensive energy market reforms, and stringent low-carbon and energy efficiency mandates would be needed to achieve this transition,â€ it said.Â¶â€œSuch policies would need to be introduced immediately and comprehensively across all countries,â€ the IEA added.Â¶The IRENA report concludes that â€œearly action is criticalâ€ and failure to act swiftly will only increase costs further down the line.Â¶The IRENA scenario also predicts that more jobs will be created than lost.Â¶The two reports also differ on the extent to which fossil fuels would continue to be used, especially cleaner options such as natural gas.Â¶The reports were released ahead of a meeting on energy and climate change in Berlin, expected to attract more than a thousand participants.Â¶The meeting, organized by Germany, comes at a time of uncertainty about the role the United States will play in international efforts to limit global warming. U.S. President Donald Trump has pledged to roll back climate commitments made by the Obama administration.

title: Watch out: Mammals shrink when Earth heats up
content: Â¶Global warming shrank certain animals in the ancient past, and scientists worry it could happen again.Â¶Warm-blooded animals got smaller at least twice in Earthâ€™s history when carbon dioxide levels soared and temperatures spiked as part of a natural warming, a new study says.Â¶University of New Hampshire researcher Abigail Dâ€™Ambrosia warned that mammals â€” but not people â€” could shrivel in the future under even faster man-made warming.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œItâ€™s something we need to keep an eye out for,â€ said Dâ€™Ambrosia, who led the new work. â€œThe question is how fast are we going to see these changes.â€Â¶Three different species shrank noticeably about 54 million years ago when the planet suddenly heated up. One of them â€” an early, compact horse â€” got 14 percent smaller, going from about 17 pounds to 14.6 pounds, according to an analysis of fossil teeth in Wednesdayâ€™s journal Science Advances .Â¶â€œThese guys were probably about the size of maybe a dog, then they dwarfed,â€ said Dâ€™Ambrosia. â€œThey may have gone down to the size of a cat.â€Â¶Another creature that contracted was a lemur-like animal thatâ€™s the earliest known primate. It shrank about 4 percent; while it may not seem like much, itâ€™s noticeable because studies of the animal over millions of years showed it was usually getting bigger over time, Dâ€™Ambrosia said.Â¶Previous studies have documented a similar shrinking of mammals, including another early horse ancestor, during an earlier warming about 56 million years ago. Scientists and farmers have also long tracked animals, such as cows, that shrink and give less milk during hotter stretches.Â¶This latest work shows heating and shrinking are connected over millions of years.Â¶â€œThese results are very significant because they provide another independent test of whether climate drives changes in body size in mammals,â€ said Jonathan Bloch, curator of vertebrate paleontology at the Florida Museum of Natural History, who wasnâ€™t part of the study. â€œIf we start to see patterns repeat themselves, we can learn from that. And what we learn from these lessons will certainly be important as we think about the possible response of plants and animals to future climate change.â€Â¶Both Dâ€™Ambrosiaâ€™s study and that of the earlier warming are based on fossils recovered from the Bighorn Basin of Wyoming. Dâ€™Ambrosia said itâ€™s unlikely that the shrinking only happened there.Â¶In hotter climates, mammals and other warm-blooded animals need to shed heat so they shrink. Smaller animals have more skin â€” or fur â€” per pound than bigger animals so more heat can escape, making them better adapted for warmer climate. Larger animals do better in the cold because they have less skin per pound and keep their heat.Â¶The bigger natural warming â€” 56 million years ago â€” saw temperatures rise 9 degrees or more probably from giant belches of methane from dead plants and animals that had accumulated on the sea floor, said Princeton University climate scientist Michael Oppenheimer.

title: Extreme coastal flooding will become the new normal in Europe, study says
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Extreme coasting flooding â€” the kind that typically hits Europe once a century â€” could happen as often as once a year as global warming intensifies, researchers warn. Â¶Scientists from the European Commissionâ€™s Joint Research Centre considered factors like sea level rise, tides, waves, and storm surges to predict changes in â€œextreme sea levelsâ€ by 2100 under a few different scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions.Â¶Their conclusion is grim: flooding events once considered exceptional are poised to increase in frequency and push the infrastructures built to protect coastal communities past their breaking points, researchers said. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The study was released this week in the journal Earthâ€™s Future, published by the American Geophysical Union.Â¶The extreme coastal flooding is expected to vary considerably across Europe, according to the new projections. Â¶Northern Europe is poised to be hit especially hard. Coastal communities along the Mediterranean and the Black Sea could see exceptional coastal flooding events several times a year. Along the North Sea and the Atlantic coasts of the U.K. and Ireland, sea levels could rise nearly 1 meter (3 feet). The researchers predicted lower but still serious increases in flooding along the Norwegian and Baltic Seas.Â¶The new study leverages new research into â€œwave energy fluxâ€ â€” that is, the energy that sea waves carry to the coastline. Â¶Extreme waves are expected to carry up to 30 percent more energy by 2100, researchers project. The more energy carried by waves, the stronger they become. Â¶Of course, Europe is not the only continent that should be concerned about sea level rise. Much of the U.S. is also at risk.Â¶In January, a report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA) warned that nearly all of the U.S. coastline is more vulnerable than the global average if severe scenarios for sea level rise come to pass this century.Â¶Coastal communities along the Northeast and western Gulf of Mexico are especially in danger, according to NOAA. Â¶Scientists say the growing risk of coastal flooding is a result of climate change, and a prime example of the interconnectedness of environmental trends across the planet. Rapidly melting ice sheets in Greenland and Antartica, fueled by warming oceans, are among the factors accelerating sea level rise around the world.

title: War on global warming only way to save world's coral, study says
content: Â¶SYDNEY -- Reducing pollution and curbing overfishing wonâ€™t prevent the severe bleaching that is killing coral at catastrophic rates, according to a study of Australiaâ€™s Great Barrier Reef. In the end, researchers say, the only way to save the worldâ€™s coral from heat-induced bleaching is with a war on global warming. Â¶Scientists are quick to note that local protection of reefs can help damaged coral recover from the stress of rising ocean temperatures. But the new research shows that such efforts are ultimately futile when it comes to stopping bleaching in the first place. Â¶â€œWe donâ€™t have any tools to climate-proof corals,â€ said Terry Hughes, director of the ARC Center of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies in Australia and lead author of the study published on Thursday in the journal Nature. â€œThatâ€™s a bit sobering. We canâ€™t stop bleaching locally. We actually have to do something about climate change.â€ Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Across the world, scores of brilliantly colored coral reefs once teeming with life have in recent years become desolate, white graveyards. Their deaths due to coral bleaching have grown more frequent as ocean temperatures rise, mainly due to increasing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The warner water stresses corals, forcing them to expel the colorful algae living inside them, which leaves the corals vulnerable to disease and death. Given enough time, bleached coral can recover if the water cools, but if the temperature stays too high for too long, the coral will die. Â¶Preserving coral reefs is crucial, given we depend on them for everything from food to medical research to protection from damaging coastal storms. Â¶Scientists and policymakers have thus been scrambling to find ways to prevent bleaching. Last year, for example, Hawaiian officials proposed several measures they hoped would fight bleaching on the stateâ€™s reefs, such as limiting fishing, establishing new marine protected areas and controlling polluted runoff from land. The question was whether such efforts could provide the corals any resistance to bleaching, or just help them recover. Â¶The researchers conducted aerial and underwater surveys of the Great Barrier Reef, which has experienced three major bleaching events, the worst of which occurred last year. The scientists found that the severity of bleaching was tightly linked to how warm the water was. In the north, which experienced the hottest temperatures, hundreds of individual reefs suffered severe bleaching in 2016, regardless of whether the water quality was good or bad, or whether fishing had been banned. That means even the most pristine parts of the reef are just as prone to heat stress as those that are less protected. Â¶Prior exposure to bleaching also did not appear to provide any protective benefit to the coral. The scientists found that the reefs that were highly bleached during the first two events, in 1998 and 2002, did not experience less severe bleaching last year.  Â¶Ultimately, the study concluded, saving reefs from the ravages of bleaching requires urgent action to reduce global warming. Â¶â€œI think itâ€™s a wake-up call,â€ Hughes said. â€œWeâ€™ve been hoping that local interventions with water quality and fishing would improve the resistance of the corals to bleaching. We found no evidence that thatâ€™s actually true, at least during a very severe event.â€ Â¶The study shows that older ways of thinking about reef management, such as reducing river runoff, are now moot points when it comes to preventing bleaching, said Kim Cobb, a climate scientist and coral researcher at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta. Â¶â€œIt all seems so quaint now, really,â€ said Cobb, who wasnâ€™t part of the study. â€œA future that we thought was decades coming is basically here.â€ Â¶The research also illustrated the gravity of the situation facing the 1,400-mile Great Barrier Reef. The team found 91 percent of the reef has been bleached at least once during the three bleaching events. Even more alarming, Hughes said, is that a fourth bleaching event is already underway. Corals need years to recover from bleaching, so back-to-back events increase the possibility that the bleached coral will die. Â¶â€œThis is the first time the Great Barrier Reef has not had a few years between bleaching events to recover,â€ Dr. Neal Cantin from the Australian Institute of Marine Science said, after Australiaâ€™s lead management agency for the reef confirmed on Friday that, for the second consecutive year, mass coral bleaching is devastating the Great Barrier Reef. Â¶The study shows that very intense coral bleaching events are no longer isolated and are happening more regularly, said coral reef scientist Julia Baum of Canadaâ€™s University of Victoria. That assertion has been further bolstered by the Great Barrier Reefâ€™s latest bleaching event, which began a few weeks ago and which Baum says has stunned scientists. Â¶â€œNone of us were expecting the water to be heating up again right now,â€ Baum said. â€œI think itâ€™s beyond what any of us could have imagined. Itâ€™s our worst nightmare.â€ Â¶In 2015, UNESCO placed the Great Barrier Reef on its watchlist due to concerns about the Australian governmentâ€™s handling of the site.

title: What would the U.S. look like without the EPA?
author: Michael Dhar
content: Â¶Acid rain devouring New England forests. Homes built on toxic sites. Unswimmable rivers and cities cloaked in smog. The United States looked very different before the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) arrived, but a recent Congressional bill calls for the agencyâ€™s abolition. So Americans may wonder: What would life be like without the EPA?Â¶In its 47 years of operation, the EPA has achieved dramatic improvements in the cleanliness of the nationâ€™s air and water, among other accomplishments, said Sara Gregg, an associate professor of history and environmental studies at the University of Kansas. To accomplish this, however, the agency has imposed numerous regulations on industry, making itself a frequent target of critics. Last month, Congressman Matt Gaetz, R-Florida, gave those criticisms stark expression in a bill calling for the agencyâ€™s abolition on Dec. 31, 2018.Â¶In an email to fellow representatives about the bill, Rep. Gaetz said, â€œThe American people are drowning in rules and regulation,â€ the New York Daily News reported. â€œAnd the Environmental Protection Agency has become an extraordinary offender.â€ (The congressmanâ€™s office did not respond to a request for comment.) [10 Ways the EPA Has Protected Earth and You]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶President Donald Trump similarly suggested abolishing the agency during the presidential campaign, and his administration has proposed cutting the EPAâ€™s staff by one-fifth and its budget by 25 percent, The Washington Post reported.Â¶These proposals ignore the reasons the agency was created, said James Salzman, a professor of environmental law at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Removing federal oversight and entrusting environmental regulation solely to the states would return the country to a failed status quo, Salzman said.Â¶â€œWeâ€™ve been there. It was called the 1960s, and it didnâ€™t work very well,â€ he said.Â¶Before the EPAâ€™s establishment in 1970, the country experienced a series of environmental crises, Gregg said. Famously, the Cuyahoga River in Ohio caught fire â€” multiple times â€” due to pollution. Acid rain was destroying New England forests. The 1972 Federal water pollution control act amendment declared that the nationâ€™s rivers and streams were not fishable or swimmable, and must be cleaned up by 1982, Gregg said.Â¶â€œCongress acknowledged â€¦ that it was not safe to put your body into the water,â€ she said.Â¶Archived pictures from the 1960s and 1970s show how bad the air had gotten, with New York covered in smog, Gregg added. Louisville, Kentucky, too, wore a shroud of smog like those that cloak cities like New Delhi and Beijing today, reported Popular Science.Â¶â€œI think about â€¦ the photographs that show oil spills that were unaddressed, or the products of tanneries or lumberyards or paper production that flowed into the rivers and lakes and streams of the nation,â€ Gregg said. â€œI think about â€¦ factories spewing a range of chemicals that nobody actually understood.â€ [The 10 Worst Oil Spills]Â¶The EPA, in conjunction with legislation like the Clean Water Act and Clean Air Act, addressed those catastrophes by various means, such as requiring scrubbers in coal-fired power plants and regulating the dumping of chemicals.Â¶In doing so, the EPA accomplished what the states themselves couldnâ€™t, Salzman said. Because pollution has no respect for political boundaries, a federal agency was needed, he said. That acid rain eating its way through New England trees, for example, came from pollution spewed by Midwestern coal plants. [In Photos: The Worldâ€™s 10 Most Polluted Places on Earth]Â¶â€œFor a variety of reasons, states were just not willing to make the tough decisions to dramatically reduce pollution,â€ Salzman said.Â¶The EPA, however, not only consolidated various agencies and efforts related to environmental protection, but also recognized the flow of pollution across spaces, Gregg said.Â¶â€œAnd I canâ€™t quite wrap my mind around the idea that somehow [this flow of pollution] can be overcome by the abolition of a national-level agency,â€ she said.Â¶Today, the EPAâ€™s work has continued to transform the country, Salzman said.Â¶â€œThe results have been extraordinary, by any measure,â€ he said. â€œOur air is cleaner to breathe. ... Our waters are much cleaner. Our hazardous waste is much more safely treated and managed. And this has led to direct benefits in public health that, when quantified, are worth many billions of dollars.â€Â¶Air quality, in particular, represents an enormous environmental-health achievement, said Tracey Holloway, a professor of environmental studies at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.Â¶â€œA lot of people donâ€™t realize that air pollution in the United States is a success story,â€ she said. â€œWe have some of the healthiest air in the world, especially considering that we use more energy than anywhere else.â€ [5 Ways Climate Change Will Affect Your Health]Â¶This has meant longer lives and fewer cases of asthma attacks and respiratory diseases, she said. Since the enactment of the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990 alone, pollution reductions avoided 160,000 premature deaths; 130,000 heart attacks; and millions of cases of respiratory problems, a 2011 EPA study estimated.Â¶The agencyâ€™s work has led to similar improvements in water quality, Salzman said. Other EPA efforts include the study of industrial chemicalsâ€™ health effects; the Superfund program, which allows for the cleanup and emergency evacuation of toxic sites; and the administration of the popular Energy Star program, which certifies energy-efficient appliances for consumers.Â¶Rep. Gaetzâ€™s bill, of course, would not travel back in time and prevent the EPAâ€™s birth. So would abolishing the EPA now immediately return the U.S. to the 1960s? Thatâ€™s unlikely, Gregg said, because the nationâ€™s industries have â€œinternalized the understanding that pollution does not pay in the United States.Â¶â€œItâ€™s not as though retrofitted coal plants would pare out their scrubbers, which theyâ€™ve invested millions of dollars in,â€ she said. â€œIt just doesnâ€™t work that way.â€Â¶In the long term, though, conditions will degrade as new production facilities come online without regulations, she said. And some 2,000 or so new industrial substances would arrive every year without any understanding of their health risks, Popular Science reported. The country and the agency, too, still have work to do on understanding and combating pollution, particularly for ozone and particulate matter, according to a 2014 NASA report on air quality.Â¶And without the EPAâ€™s abilities to quickly assess environmental hazards, future environmental disasters would be worsened, The Washington Post reported. A proposed 42-percent budget cut to the EPAâ€™s research division already makes that a danger, the Post reported.Â¶In the end, the EPA is unlikely to face flat-out abolition, Salzman said, because all federal environmental legislation assumes the existence of the EPA for enforcement. So eliminating the agency would require rolling back those laws, too, which is unlikely, he said.Â¶â€œItâ€™s hard for me to imagine that there would be public support to rewrite all of our major environmental laws,â€ he said.Â¶Budget cuts, however, and efforts to return regulation to the states, are very real possibilities, Gregg said. Long-established efforts, like those mandated by the Clean Water Act, should be more resistant to proposed cuts, but newer programs, like environmental-justice efforts could disappear, she said. (These efforts aim to make environmental protection equitable for all people, according to the EPA.) Radon testing, lead cleanup and industrial-site cleanup are also at risk, Grist magazine reported.Â¶Gaetzâ€™s bill still stands as a symbolic criticism, representing charges that the agency stifles the economy, though research doesnâ€™t support that idea, Salzman said. The economic benefits of the 1990 clean air amendments, for example, would outpace losses by a factor of 30 by 2020, the 2011 EPA study estimated.Â¶â€œThe EPA was created to protect the environment for all of us, not to kill jobs,â€ Salzman said. â€œAnd they donâ€™t kill jobs, on balance.â€Â¶Follow Michael Dhar @michaeldhar. Follow us @livescience, Facebook & Google+. Original article on Live Science.

title: Doctors warn climate change is harming our health
author: Mary Brophy Marcus
content: Â¶Climate change isnâ€™t just happening in the Arctic Circle and Antarctica where more ice is melting year after year. Its impact is being felt right here at home, and itâ€™s posing a threat to the health of millions of Americans, say doctors representing 11 top U.S. medical societies. They are joining forces in Washington, D.C., today to speak out about the health risks posed by climate change.Â¶They announced the formation of a new organization, the Medical Society Consortium on Climate and Health â€” made up of family physicians, pediatricians, obstetricians, allergists, internists and other medical experts â€” and are meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill to discuss their concerns. More than half of all U.S. doctors are members of one of the participating groups, which include the American College of Physicians and the American Academy of Pediatrics.Â¶Theyâ€™ll also present a new report, â€œMedical Alert! Climate Change is Harming Our Health,â€ which includes scientific evidence and accounts from doctors who see climate change exacerbating a wide range of health issues, including: Â¶â€œMore than 97 percent of climate scientists have concluded that human-caused climate change is happening,â€ the report states. Â¶â€œItâ€™s not only hurting polar bears, itâ€™s hurting us,â€ said Dr. Mona Sarfaty, the director of the new consortium and a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia. She is also director of the Center for Climate Change Communication there.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Sarfaty told CBS News that primary care physicians as well as doctors in many specialty areas are reporting that climate change is making their patients sicker. Yet, she said, a recent poll showed only 32 percent of Americans could name a specific way in which global warming is harming human health.Â¶Carbon dioxide levels in the air are increasing and air and ocean temperatures are warming, contributing to more frequent and extreme droughts, wildfires, and flooding, Sarfaty explained. In turn, she said doctors are seeing an uptick in heat-related illnesses; worsening chronic conditions such as asthma; injuries and deaths from extreme weather like floods; infectious diseases spread by increasing populations of mosquitoes and ticks (including those that spread Lyme disease); illnesses stemming from contaminated food and water; and mental health problems like aggression and anxiety.Â¶Certain groups of people are especially vulnerable to the health effects of climate shifts, including children, student athletes, pregnant women, the elderly, low-income families, and people with chronic illnesses, the report said.Â¶But Sarfaty noted itâ€™s challenging to get this message through to many people because they feel fine. Â¶â€œWe think that people are largely unaware that climate has anything to do with their health. They think of it as an environmental issue and put it into an environmental box or a political box. But we think people need to know that this is about their health. Itâ€™s not one of those boxes. The truth is, itâ€™s affecting somebody you know,â€ she said.Â¶Dr. Nitin Damle, president of the American College of Physicians and an internist in Wakefield, Rhode Island, shared a story in the report. He said that over the past five years, his practice has seen a rise in the incidence of tick-borne diseases, including Lyme disease and other infections. Â¶â€œMy physician colleagues used to treat two or three cases a month during tick season; now each of us sees 40 to 50 new cases during each tick season,â€ he said. â€œThose blacklegged ticks, the carriers of Lyme disease, thrive in warm, muggy weather. In my home state of Rhode Island, where winters have gotten warmer and shorter, these tiny, sesame seed-sized insects have more time to bite humans and spread Lyme disease. Tick season used to be relegated to summer; it now spans spring and autumn. And this isnâ€™t limited to the typical tick hotspot states.â€ Â¶Damle drew a comparison to doctors working to prevent smoking and help patients quit because it increases the risk of cancer and lung disease.Â¶â€œWe see efforts to combat climate change in the same way: they will improve health today and reduce health risks down the road,â€ he said.Â¶Dr. Robert Byron, a long-time practicing internist at Bighorn Valley Health Center, in Hardin, Montana, spoke at the consortiumâ€™s Washington, D.C., press conference.Â¶â€œThere are day-to-day things weâ€™re seeing in individual patient care. Montana is seen as the blue sky state, but what weâ€™ve seen in recent years is a marked increase in wildfires,â€ Byron said. â€œFire season has increased by over two months in the last 50 years.â€Â¶He added, â€œWe caution patients with asthma and COPD to not be outside as much. Weâ€™ve seen increases in the amount of medication they use and increased hospitalizations in terms of flare-ups of their diseases. This used to be the exception and now itâ€™s the rule and itâ€™s a result of climate increases in our area.â€Â¶While in D.C., leaders of the consortium plan to connect with certain â€œpriority states where we felt policy makers really needed to get the message out, where the legislators may be less attuned to health consequences,â€ Sarfaty said. Those states include Montana, Wisconsin, Minnesota, New Mexico, Arizona and Virginia.Â¶The Medical Society Consortium on Climate and Health includes the American College of Physicians (ACP); American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, Immunology (AAAAI); the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP); the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP); and the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), among others.Â¶â€œWe want to send a very strong message to the American public and our leaders that climate change is already harming the health of Americans,â€ Sarfaty said.

title: Mass coral bleaching hits the Great Barrier Reef â€“ again
content: Â¶For the second consecutive year, mass coral bleaching is devastating the Great Barrier Reef, Australiaâ€™s lead management agency for the reef confirmed on Friday.Â¶The latest coral bleaching, a phenomenon that can result in coral dying off, is part of a larger event that has damaged the worldâ€™s largest reef over the past two years. Global warming is fueling the phenomenon, as warming ocean waters put corals at serious risk. Â¶The news comes after Australian government experts and researchers from the Australian Institute of Marine Science surveyed the Great Barrier Reef between Townsville and Cairns last week. It was the first aerial survey conducted this year, and the news was grim. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The examination found severe bleaching in offshore reefs ranging from north of Ingham to the area near Cairns. â€œThis year more bleaching is being observed in this central part of the Reef, which last year escaped widespread severe bleaching,â€ Australiaâ€™s Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority said in a statement.Â¶The survey confirmed anecdotal evidence collected by visitors to the reef, as well as other reef surveys completed by marine park rangers and commerical operators, the parkâ€™s director of reef recover, Dr. David Wachenfeld said. Â¶â€œMass bleaching is occurring on the Great Barrier Reef for the second consecutive year,â€ he confirmed. Â¶Widespread coral bleaching during back-to-back summers is particularly toxic, as it does not leave enough time for the corals to fully recover. Â¶â€œThis is the first time the Great Barrier Reef has not had a few years between bleaching events to recover,â€ said Dr. Neal Cantin from the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Â¶The environmental organization Greenpeace has also been documenting the bleaching, and is trying to sound the alarm worldwide. Â¶â€œIâ€™ve been photographing this area of the reef for several years now and what weâ€™re seeing is unprecedented,â€ conservation photographer and marine biologist Brett Monro Garner said in a statement last week. â€œJust a few months ago, these corals were full of colour and life. Now, everywhere you look is white. The corals arenâ€™t getting the chance to bounce back from last yearâ€™s bleaching event. If this is the new normal, weâ€™re in trouble.â€Â¶In 2015, UNESCO placed the Great Barrier Reef on its watchlist due to concerns about the Australian governmentâ€™s handling of the site.

title: Memo to Scott Pruitt: Here's how carbon dioxide is warming the planet
author: Stephanie Pappas
