content: Â¶The head of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) said he doesnâ€™t believe that carbon dioxide is a main driver of climate change.Â¶â€œI think that measuring with precision human activity on the climate is something very challenging to do, and thereâ€™s tremendous disagreement about the degree of impact. So no, I would not agree that itâ€™s a primary contributor to the global warming that we see,â€ EPA chief Scott Pruitt told CNBCâ€™s morning news show â€œSquawk Boxâ€ Thursday.Â¶Pruittâ€™s comments are in opposition to the scientific research on climate change. But when even the head of the EPA doubts the consensus, it can be hard to cut through the noise to understand what research scientists are really using when they express climate-change concern. [The Reality of Climate Change: 10 Myths Busted]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œI think plenty of people have pretty serious concerns in their life and they just donâ€™t have the time to do all of the homework and the background to figure this out,â€ said Katherine Moore Powell, a climate ecologist at the Field Museum in Chicago.Â¶So hereâ€™s a primer explaining exactly why scientists know the climate is changing and that human activities are causing it.Â¶At this point, even the staunchest climate deniers would be hard-pressed to argue that the climate is not warming. Simply put, itâ€™s getting hotter out there. Combining land and ocean measurements from 1850 to 2012, researchers have found that the average surface-air temperature globally has risen by 1.4 degrees Fahrenheit since the beginning of the industrial age. Thatâ€™s according to the fifth report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), released in 2014. The top graph in the figure from the IPCC report summary for policy makers shows the temperature anomaly in Celsius.Â¶The next graph in this sequence shows sea-level rise, which has gone up globally by about 7.4 inches on average since 1901. According to the IPCC, the rate of sea-level rise since the middle of the 1800s has been higher than the rate during the previous two millennia. Scientists use tide gauges and satellite measurements to track sea-level changes, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Geologists and other Earth scientists can study rocks, fossils and sediment cores to get a longer-term look at sea-level changes, according to NASA.Â¶The bottom two graphs show rising greenhouse-gas concentrations and estimated emissions of carbon dioxide by humans since 1850. The rising trend is evident on each figure. Scientists monitor carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by pumping air into an artificial chamber and shining an infrared light through the sample. Carbon dioxide absorbs infrared light very efficiently â€” more on that in a minute -- so the amount of infrared absorbed can be used to calculate the amount of CO2 in the sample. [Top 10 Ways to Destroy Earth]Â¶The premier (and longest-standing) site for these measurements is the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii, which recently reported that the planetâ€™s atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration has surpassed 400 parts per million. In 1958, when observations at Mauna Loa began, the annual carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere was 315 parts per million.Â¶Carbon dioxide is no dark-horse candidate for the warming of the atmosphere. In 1896, Swedish scientist Svante Arrhenius (who would later win the first-ever Nobel Prize for Chemistry) published a paper in the Philosophical Magazine and Journal of Science that laid out the basics of whatâ€™s now known as â€œthe greenhouse effect.â€Â¶The effect is a result of how energy interacts with the atmosphere. Sunlight enters the atmosphere as ultraviolet and visible light; some of this solar energy is then radiated back toward space as infrared energy, or heat. The atmosphere is 78 percent nitrogen and 21 percent oxygen, which are both gases made up of molecules containing two atoms. These tightly bound pairs donâ€™t absorb much heat.Â¶But the greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, water vapor and methane, each have at least three atoms in their molecules. These loosely bound structures are efficient absorbers of the long-wave radiation (also known as heat) bouncing back from the planetâ€™s surface. When the molecules in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases re-emit this long-wave radiation back toward Earthâ€™s surface, the result is warming.Â¶So, temperatures are rising, as are levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide. But are the two connected?Â¶Yes. The evidence is strong. In 2006, scientists presented a poster at the 18th Conference on Climate Variability and Change that even measured the effect directly. Using spectrometers (tools that measure spectra to identify particular wavelengths), the researchers analyzed the wavelengths of infrared radiation reaching the ground. Based on the varying wavelengths, the scientists determined that more radiation was occurring due to the contribution of specific greenhouse gases.Â¶Overall, they found that greenhouse gas radiation had increased by 3.5 watts per square meter compared with preindustrial times, a rise of just over 2 percent. Other researchers have noted â€œmissingâ€ infrared wavelengths in radiation into space, a phenomenon that happens because these missing wavelengths get stuck in the atmosphere.Â¶Scientists also know that the extra carbon in the atmosphere is the very same carbon that comes from burning fossil fuels. By analyzing molecular variations called isotopes, researchers can trace the origin of atmospheric carbon, Moore Powell said.Â¶â€œWe know what the burning of fossil fuels looks like, in a scientific sense,â€ she said.Â¶Thatâ€™s not to say that the climate is as simple as an actual greenhouse. Many factors influence global temperatures, including volcanic eruptions and variations in the solar cycle and Earthâ€™s orbit that alter the amount of sunlight reaching the planet.Â¶But scientists know that volcanoes and the sun arenâ€™t to blame for recent climate change. According to the IPCC, volcanic carbon dioxide emissions have been, at most, a hundredth of human CO2 emissions since 1750. In addition, volcanic eruptions cause changes for short timescales of about two years, not the longer-term changes being observed currently.Â¶The sun is more complex, but researchers have found that the recent solar-cycle minimum (between 1986 and 2008) was actually lower than the previous two solar-cycle minimums (the sun moves between quiet minimums and active maximums about once every five years). If anything, the IPPC concluded, recent solar activity should have resulted in cooling, not warming. Likewise, a 2012 study found that between 2005 and 2010, a period when solar activity was low, the Earth still absorbed 0.58 watts of excess energy per square meter, continuing to warm despite the lower level of solar energy going into the system.Â¶Given the weight of the evidence, scientists have come to a consensus that climate change is happening, and that human greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause.Â¶So where are the real scientific debates?Â¶There are still a lot of questions left about how fast climate change will happen and what the precise effects will be.Â¶â€œWhat I would say is most uncertain is simply how quickly things are changing,â€ Moore Powell said. â€œIâ€™m very interested in the pace.â€Â¶One of the major unknowns is the ultimate influence of clouds on climate: Clouds are white, so they reflect sunlight back toward space, which could have a cooling effect. But clouds are also water vapor, which traps heat. And different types of clouds might have warming or cooling effects, so the precise role of clouds in the feedback loop of global warming remains difficult to untangle, scientists have said.Â¶Another burning question is how high, and how quickly, the sea level will rise as warming sea waters expand and Antarctic and Arctic ice melts. The IPCC forecasted a rise of 20 to 38 inches, assuming no efforts are made to curb greenhouse gas emissions.Â¶That range is broad, largely because the dynamics of Antarctic ice sheets are not completely understood. If Antarcticaâ€™s land-based glaciers slough off to the sea rapidly with a little bit of warming, that will be bad news for coastal communities, researchers have said. Thatâ€™s why scientists are watching closely right now as a rift is splitting the Larsen C ice shelf on the Weddell Sea. If the giant iceberg-calving event about to occur destabilizes the ice shelf, it could result in the rapid flow of the land-based glaciers behind it into the ocean. This type of rapid glacial flow already occurred nearby, when the Larsen B ice shelf crumbled in 2002.Â¶For an ecologist like Moore Powell, there are also myriad questions to answer about how ecosystems will respond to a changing climate. If the pace is slow enough, plants and animals can adapt. But in many places, the change is happening very quickly, Moore Powell said.Â¶â€œThereâ€™s not enough time at this pace for natural adaptation to take over,â€ she said.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: The numbers are in on this freakishly warm February
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- A freakishly balmy February broke more than 11,700 local daily records for warmth in the United States, but it didnâ€™t quite beat 1954 for the warmest February on record, climate scientists said.Â¶The average temperature last month was 41.2 degrees -- 7.3 degrees warmer than normal but three-tenths a degree behind the record, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported Wednesday.Â¶It was unseasonably toasty for most of the country east of the Rockies, but a cool Pacific Northwest kept the national record from falling, said NOAA climate scientist Jake Crouch.Â¶Chicago had no snow. Oklahoma hit 99 degrees. Texas and Louisiana had their hottest February. NOAA said local weather stations broke or tied warm temperature records 11,743 times but set cold records only 418 times.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶An international science teamâ€™s computer analysis of causes of extreme weather calculated that man-made global warming tripled the likelihood for the nationâ€™s unusually warm February. The mostly private team of researchers, called World Weather Attribution, uses accepted scientific techniques to figure if climate change plays a role in extreme events based on computer simulations of real world conditions and those without heat-trapping gases.Â¶â€œI donâ€™t recall ever seeing a February like this,â€ said Princeton University climate scientist Gabe Vecchi, who was part of the quick attribution study that was not peer reviewed. â€œWe expect this to happen with more and more frequency over time.â€Â¶Several outside scientists praised the quick study including Pennsylvania State University meteorology professor David Titley, who was on a National Academy of Sciences panel that certified the accuracy of climate change attribution science.Â¶â€œThis is the new climate normal that we all need to come to grips with,â€ Titley said. â€œAnd itâ€™s stunning how quickly our climate has changed.â€Â¶Natural random weather variations and climate change combined to make it a weird February, meteorologists said.Â¶Overall, NOAA said it was the sixth warmest U.S. winter on record, about 3.7 degrees warmer than the 20th century average.Â¶â€œYou definitely do feel that this is going to be something that you get to enjoy now and you pay for after the fact,â€ said Vecchi, who was biking in short-sleeves in New Jersey last month.Â¶Oklahoma University meteorology professor Jason Furtado said he worries that the lack of deep Arctic cold plunges in February means the Gulf of Mexico never cooled down. And when severe weather season in the spring starts, the moisture coming north from warmer Gulf waters will goose outbreaks and increase the probability of nasty spring storms and tornadoes. Massachusetts already had an unprecedented February tornado.Â¶A March frost could kill early blooming trees and flowers and the lack of a proper winter could lead to more mosquitoes and ticks this year, Vecchi said.Â¶â€œWhat is lurking behind the corner while weâ€™re outside throwing a Frisbee might be looking to make our lives less pleasant,â€ he said.

title: EPA chief says carbon dioxide not a primary cause of global warming
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- The new chief of the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday he does not believe that carbon dioxide is a primary contributor to global warming, a statement at odds with mainstream scientific consensus and his own agency.Â¶EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt said measuring the effect of human activity on the climate is â€œvery challengingâ€ and that â€œthereâ€™s tremendous disagreement about the degree of impactâ€ of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.Â¶â€œSo, no, I would not agree that (carbon dioxide) is a primary contributor to the global warming that we see,â€ Pruitt told CNBCâ€™s â€œSquawk Box.â€Â¶More in Trump's First 100 DaysÂ¶Pruittâ€™s view is contrary to mainstream climate science, including NASA, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the EPA itself.Â¶NASA and NOAA reported in January that earthâ€™s 2016 temperatures were the warmest ever. The planetâ€™s average surface temperature has risen about 2 degrees Fahrenheit since the late 19th century, â€œa change driven largely by increased carbon dioxide and other human-made emissions into the atmosphere,â€ the agencies said in a joint statement.Â¶The EPA says on its website that â€œcarbon dioxide is the primary greenhouse gas that is contributing to recent climate change.â€ The agency notes that human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels, â€œrelease large amounts of CO2, causing concentrations in the atmosphere to rise.â€Â¶Kerry Emanuel, professor of atmospheric science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said Thursday that â€œScott Pruitt is just plain wrong on this.â€Â¶Emanuel, co-director of the Lorenz Center at MIT, said the most authoritative compilation of scientific research has shown that increasing carbon dioxide has been the dominant source of global warming, followed by methane and other gases.Â¶Environmental groups and Democrats seized on Pruittâ€™s comments as evidence he is unfit for the office he holds.Â¶â€œThe arsonist is now in charge of the fire department, and he seems happy to let the climate crisis burn out of control,â€ said Sierra Club executive director Michael Brune.Â¶Pruitt â€œis spewing corporate polluter talking points rather than fulfilling the EPAâ€™s mission of protecting our air, our water and our communities,â€ Brune said, noting that EPA has a legal responsibility to address carbon pollution.Â¶Sen. Brian Schatz, D-Hawaii, said the comments underscore that Pruitt is a â€œclimate denierâ€ and insisted lawmakers will stand up to him.Â¶â€œAnyone who denies over a centuryâ€™s worth of established science and basic facts is unqualified to be the administrator of the EPA,â€ Schatz said in a statement.Â¶Pruitt previously served as Oklahoma attorney general, where he rose to prominence as a leader in coordinated efforts by Republican attorneys general to challenge former President Obamaâ€™s regulatory agenda. He sued or took part in legal actions against the EPA 14 times.Â¶Pruitt said during his confirmation hearing in January that climate change is real - breaking with President Trump and his own past statements.Â¶Pruitt told Democratic senators that he disagreed with Mr. Trumpâ€™s earlier claims that global warming is a hoax created by the Chinese to harm the economic competitiveness of the United States.Â¶â€œI do not believe climate change is a hoax,â€ Pruitt said.Â¶In December, Mr. Trump said that he was â€œopen-mindedâ€ about climate change -- but also that â€œnobody really knowsâ€ the truth about the issue.Â¶In an interview with â€œFox News Sunday,â€ moderator Chris Wallace pointed out to Mr. Trump  that in the space of a week he both met with former Vice President Al Gore and appointed Pruitt to head the EPA. Where, Wallace asked, does Mr. Trump stand on climate change? Â¶â€œIâ€™m very open-minded. Iâ€™m still open-minded,â€ he said. â€œNobody really knows.â€Â¶Pruitt has previously cast doubt on the extensive body of scientific evidence showing that the planet is warming and man-made carbon emissions are to blame. In a 2016 opinion article, Pruitt suggested that the debate over global warming â€œis far from settledâ€ and he said â€œscientists continue to disagree about the degree and extent of global warming and its connection to the actions of mankind.â€

title: Climate Diaries: Saving whales in Antarctica - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶ANTARCTICA -- A pod of killer whales is spotted crossing a stretch of open water. Researchers jump into small boats to chase them, just like in the old days. Â¶This hunt, though, isnâ€™t about killing whales.  Itâ€™s about trying to save them. Â¶â€œOne of the reasons we study top pedators,â€ said John Durban, â€œis to understand the health of the ecosystem that supports them.â€  Â¶Itâ€™s an ecosystem that is changing. Â¶Durban and Holly Fearnbach are modern whale hunters, using modern gear -- a camera mounted on a drone -- to give the whales a health checkup, and finding some are in trouble.  Â¶â€œSheâ€™s very, very thin,â€ said Fearnbach about a whale. â€œYou can see her ribs really clearly, so sheâ€™s lost all of the fat all along her entire body.â€Â¶â€œYouâ€™re looking at a dying whale here?â€ CBS News asked. Â¶â€œYes, youâ€™re looking at a dying whale. And she has a dependent offspring and so, once the female dies, then sheâ€™s also going to lose her calf, so itâ€™s very worrying,â€ Fearnbach said. Â¶Itâ€™s too early to know why itâ€™s happening, but the prime suspect? Antarctica is warming up. Â¶â€œThereâ€™s, um, a problem with their food supply, and ... fewer seals,â€ said Durban. â€œAnd thatâ€™s what weâ€™ve been seeing so far this year.â€ Â¶â€œ Less ice, fewer seals -- is that a leap?â€ CBS News asked. Â¶â€œItâ€™s certainly a hypothesis,â€ Durban said. Â¶Durban and Fearnbach have had to cobble this project together. Fearnbach works for a marine animal welfare organization called SR3, and Durban works for NOAA Fisheries department. Â¶They get transport in Antarctica with Lindblad-National Geographic expeditions.   Â¶â€œThis is the seventh year in a row that weâ€™ve conducted research on board this ship,â€ Durban said. Â¶And itâ€™s the long-term commitment thatâ€™s important. Â¶â€œWeâ€™re studying animals that live as long as we do, and to understand them and to get enough opportunities with them, it takes multiple years,â€ said Durban.Â¶Right now, though, even the short-term commitment is in doubt.

title: Antarctica's record high temperatures documented in new report
author: Laura Geggel
content: Â¶Temperatures on the Antarctic continent reached a record-breaking high of 63.5 degrees Fahrenheit in 2015, according to a new report of balmy records for the bottom of the world. Â¶And things got even toastier back on Jan. 30, 1982, when the thermometer peaked at 67.6 degrees F at Signy Research Station on Antarcticaâ€™s Signy Island, according to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a division of the United Nations. This temperature was the highest on record for the Antarctic region, an area including all land and ice south of 60 degrees south latitude, the WMO said. Â¶When WMO experts looked at just the continent itself (the area including the continent and its nearby islands), they found that the warmest temperature -- a positively balmy 63.5 degrees F -- happened on March 24, 2015, at the Argentine Esperanza Base research station, located by the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. [Images of Melt: Earthâ€™s Vanishing Ice] Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The highest temperature for the Antarctic Plateau (an area with an elevation of 8,200 feet, or 2,500 meters) reached 19.4 degrees F at the Automatic Weather Station on the AdÃ©lie Coast on Dec. 28, 1980, the report found. Â¶These high temperatures are a large departure from the continentâ€™s lowest recorded temperature of minus-128.6 degrees F at Vostok Station on July 21, 1983, the WMO said.  Â¶The WMO published the report online March 1 in a continuing effort to expand its worldwide database on extreme weather and climate conditions, the organization said. The database will help the WMO learn about naturally occurring climate change, as well as human-induced climate change along global and regional levels, WMO officials said. Â¶Usually, Antarctica is cold, windy and dry, the WMO said. The average annual temperature ranges from about 14 degrees F on the Antarctic coast to about minus-76 degrees F (minus-60 degrees C) in Antarcticaâ€™s higher-elevation interior, the WMO said. Â¶Moreover, Antarcticaâ€™s ice sheet contains 90 percent of the worldâ€™s freshwater, and if the ice sheet were to melt, it would raise sea level by about 200 feet. Thatâ€™s disconcerting, given that the Antarctic Peninsula is one of the fastest-warming regions of the planet, having warmed by almost 5.4 degrees F over the past 50 years, the WMO said. Â¶In addition, about 87 percent of glaciers along the Antarctic Peninsulaâ€™s west coast have retreated over the past 50 years, especially in the past 12 years, the WMO added. Â¶The warming can be felt even during short visits down south, said Jamin Greenbaum, a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Texas Institute for Geophysics, who was not involved in the new report. Â¶â€œI just returned from Antarctica a few weeks ago, where I saw, firsthand, how warm it was there,â€ Greenbaum told Live Science. â€œIt was my 10th consecutive fieldwork experience down there, and Iâ€™ve never seen so much surface meltwater â€” it was remarkable.â€ Â¶Meltwater is the result of high temperatures that can melt the surface of the ice and snow, Greenbaum said. Meltwater is fairly alarming, he said, because it can lead to the rapid retreat of coastal ice, as well as sea-level rise. Â¶â€œThere was so much [meltwater] that even a large section of the snow road we take every day collapsed, forcing us to use helicopters to commute between the research station and the airfield,â€ Greenbaum said. [In Photos: Huge Icebergs Break Off Antarctica] Â¶Another Antarctic expert, Eric Steig, said that â€œthese temperatures are very likely associated with the extremely strong sea ice loss.â€ But the origin of that loss â€œis actually unclear at the moment,â€ said Steig, an adjunct professor of Earth and space sciences at the University of Washington, who was not involved in the report.  Â¶The new report may help scientists figure out whatâ€™s behind these high temperatures. For instance, the WMOâ€™s Commission for Climatology international evaluation committee found that the records at all three stations took place during an influx of warm air. Â¶The WMO scientists and their colleagues hope to learn more, and they aim to increase weather forecasting capability during the Year of Polar Prediction project, which will last from mid-2017 to mid-2019, the WMO said. Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: "A sense of despair": The mental health cost of unchecked climate change
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Climate change is taking an obvious physical toll on earth: from depleted farmland to the rise of toxic pollution to the degradation of long-stable ecosystems to the disappearance of biodiversity and endangered species. Â¶But looking beyond the physical, experts are also trying to sound the alarm about the quieter, more insidious effects of climate change: namely, that global warming is threatening the emotional health of humans worldwide. Â¶â€œWe see a sense of despair that sets in as inevitably Mother Nature, who we think of as our nurturing force, tells us weâ€™re not going to be able to survive the conditions sheâ€™s set for us,â€ Dr. Lise Van Susteran, a practicing psychiatrist and expert on the dangers of climate change on mental health, told CBS News. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Dr. Van Susteran presented on this topic earlier this month at the Climate & Health Meeting in Atlanta, a conference that looked at climate change through the lens of public health. Former Vice President Al Gore organized the meeting when, days before President Trumpâ€™s inauguration, a long-planned Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) summit on the topic was abruptly cancelled.Â¶Study after study shows that climate change has led to an increased burden of psychological disease and injury worldwide, particularly in developing countries. Â¶Whatâ€™s behind this link? For starters, climate change has normalized extreme weather events. These events, including floods, tornadoes, fires, drought, and sea level rise, are known to trigger mental health problems including post-traumatic stress disorder, anxiety, depression, the abuse of alcohol and drugs, and more.Â¶Extreme weather has a particularly disturbing link to increased aggression. In 2013, researchers from Princeton University and the University of California-Berkeley found that even slight spikes in temperature and precipitation have increased the risk of personal violence and social upheaval throughout human history. Â¶The researchers found that just one standard-deviation shift in heat or rainfall increases the risk of a riot, civil war or ethnic conflict by an average of about 14 percent. A similarly sized uptick in heat or rain triggers a 4 percent increase in person-on-person violence like rape, murder and assault. Â¶With projections that the Earth may warm between three and four degrees Fahrenheit by 2050, the researchers warned that climate change is almost certainly the precursor to more human conflict in the near future.Â¶Global warming is a particularly corrosive force in some farming economies, where overheating, unpredictable weather, new invasive species, and land losses are sinking communities into extreme poverty and creating a breeding ground for violent conflict.  Â¶For millions, the effects of climate change are so severe that leaving home is the only option for survival. Thirty-two million people fled their homes because of extreme weather in 2012 alone, according to the United Nations. Â¶Escaping hazards ranging from mudslides to drought, climate refugees add more stress to an already dire refugee situation worldwide. According to the UN, the world is currently witnessing the highest levels of displacement on record.Â¶As climate refugees become more and more common, refugee laws lag behind: none of the existing international or regional refugees law mechanisms specifically addresses climate refugees, the UN says. Â¶Climate change is triggering mental health problems beyond just developing countries and conflict zones. Â¶In cities, babies who are exposed in the uterus to higher levels of urban air pollutants (known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) are more likely to develop symptoms of anxiety and depression down the line, Columbia University researchers found in 2012. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons are the chemicals come from burning fossil fuels. Â¶â€œClimate anxietyâ€ can cripple individuals regardless of their geography, privilege, or vulnerability to the effects of climate change, Dr. Van Susteran said. Joining with other mental health professionals, she is one of the founders behind the Climate Psych Alliance, a new coalition trying to raise awareness about the links between climate change and clinical trauma. Â¶â€œYou can see how desperate, angry, despairing people are,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s a legitimate response to what people see as inaction, intentional inaction... Whether we know it or not, whether you accept it or not, everyone experiences climate anxiety.â€Â¶Seen through a certain lens, inaction on global warming meets the criteria of child abuse for future generations, she said.Â¶â€œWhen children believe their parents didnâ€™t do something right, or did something wrong, they spend a whole lifetime feeling abandoned. What in the world are future generations going to think or feel when they know that action could have been taken?â€ Â¶In the age of an unstable climate, the link between natural disasters and psychological trauma is â€œunder-examined, underestimated and not adequately monitored,â€ Italian researchers assessed in a January study in the journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine. That research gap is particularly worrisome in Africa, German researchers said in a paper published last year. Â¶Climate change is often the hidden catalyst â€” the fuel behind war, displacement and collapsed economies that doesnâ€™t make it into the headlines.Â¶Syriaâ€™s civil war, for instance, is most frequently framed as an entrenched political conflict. Closer examination shows thatâ€™s far from the full story: in fact, the countryâ€™s six-year conflict is rooted in a devastating drought. Earnings depleted and Syrian farmers moved to overcrowded cities, where political corruption and public health crises helped foment bloody revolution. Â¶Climate change carries enormous political risk for the 21st century, Dr. Van Susteran warned. Â¶â€œIn times of peril and scarcity, people regress,â€ she said. â€œThey turn to what they perceive as strong leaders to protect them, and are willing to give up their freedoms and values in exchange for perceived security.â€

title: Global warming, overfishing threaten Earth's "super-zoos," scientists warn
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- The six ocean hot spots that teem with the biggest mix of species are also getting hit hardest by global warming and industrial fishing, a new study finds. Â¶An international team looked at more than 2,100 species of fish, seabirds, marine mammals and even tiny plankton to calculate Earthâ€™s hot spots of marine biodiversity. Â¶These underwater super-zoos are in patches of ocean that are overfished and warming fast, and these pressures hurt the lush life there, according to a study appearing in Wednesdayâ€™s journal Science Advances. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œIn those hot spots, the changes are already happening,â€ says study co-author Andre Chiaradia, a senior scientist and penguin expert at the Phillip Island Nature Parks in Australia. â€œThey are the most at risk.â€ Â¶Several outside marine and climate scientists praised the work, saying it showed the importance of protecting these areas and reducing fishing. Â¶â€œBiodiversity and fisheries are humanityâ€™s legacyâ€ that should be preserved, marine ecologist Maria Vernet of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography said in an email. She wasnâ€™t part of the research. Â¶While scientists in the past have identified key areas of biodiversity, the new work is more detailed. Researchers found the liveliest ocean hot spot also happens to be where the science of evolution sprouted: the Pacific Ocean off the central South American coast. It includes the area around the Galapagos Islands and goes back to â€œour good friend (Charles) Darwin. When he went there, he got amazed,â€ Chiaradia said. Â¶Other hot spots include the southwestern Atlantic Ocean off Argentina; the western Indian Ocean off the African coast; the central western Pacific Ocean surrounding Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines; the southwestern Pacific off Australiaâ€™s southern and eastern coast; and the Oceania region of the Pacific around the international date line. Four of the six hot spots are in the Pacific; all are either in the southern hemisphere or just north of the equator. Â¶â€œWhat makes this biodiversity? Itâ€™s the isolation,â€ Chiardia said. â€œOn land, we have kangaroos and weird animals like the platypus. And in the ocean itâ€™s not different.â€ Â¶The ocean is home to Australian sea dragons, a fish related to the seahorse that resemble mythical dragons and sometimes even have yellow and purple markings on their bodies. Â¶These hot spots also tend to be places where the ocean waters churn more, Chiardia said. Â¶Penguins, which are near the top of the food chain, are a good example of the impact of changing water temperatures and currents. Warm El Nino waters have decimated Galapagos penguins and the population of southern African penguins has dropped by about 90 percent in just 20 years, Chiardia said.

title: Bill would leave evolution and climate skepticism up to teachers
content: Â¶PIERRE, S.D. â€” South Dakota legislators are weighing whether to let teachers decide how much skepticism to work into lessons on contentious scientific topics such as evolution and climate change.Â¶A House committee on Wednesday is set to consider the measure, which would give legal protection to teachers who want to discuss â€œin an objective scientific manner the strengths and weaknessesâ€ of the subjects.Â¶South Dakota is one of at least three states, along with Texas and Oklahoma, considering such a bill. Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee have enacted similar laws, according to Glenn Branch, deputy director of the California-based National Center for Science Education, which opposes the proposal. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Branch said there are concerns that such a bill would embolden some teachers to start presenting creationism in their classrooms.Â¶Critics argue that the measure is bad for students and that allowing teachers to teach any science curriculum they choose could subject school districts to litigation. Federal courts have struck down attempts to present creationism in various forms at public schools, Branch said.Â¶South Dakota Sen. Jeff Monroe, the billâ€™s prime sponsor, said teachers should be able to talk about weaknesses in scientific theories, but he disputed that it would allow for creationism to seep into school teachings. Rogue teaching of creationism instead of science wouldnâ€™t happen because itâ€™s not included in South Dakotaâ€™s science content standards, he said.Â¶The Republican has said he has heard from concerned teachers, including one who was chastised for discussing how embryos develop and another who was frustrated that she was forced to teach climate change as a fact.Â¶â€œThatâ€™s how we got off the theory that man canâ€™t fly, thatâ€™s how we got off the flat earth theory, by analyzing the theories, not by being stuck, told this is true and youâ€™re going to believe it and theyâ€™re going to teach it as true,â€ said Monroe, who added that it could help students learn.Â¶The effort may face a hurdle in GOP Gov. Dennis Daugaard, who said in a recent letter to a group of Augustana University professors that he views the bill as unnecessary.Â¶Deb Wolf, a high school science instructional coach who helps teachers in Sioux Falls schools write science curriculum said the bill is superfluous. She said sheâ€™s concerned that it would protect educators who teach things that arenâ€™t â€œtruly science.â€Â¶Pam Wells, a Mobridge-Pollock High School science teacher, said some parents have asked her to teach intelligent design during her 35 years in public schools. Wells said she read the textbooks they gave her on the subject, but decided not to include it in her curriculum because the theories werenâ€™t based in science.Â¶Wells said one high school senior told her that he wouldnâ€™t come to her class if she dropped evolutionary theory and picked up intelligent design, which holds that certain features of life forms are so complex that they can best be explained by an origin from an intelligent higher power. â€œHe said, â€˜If I wanted to learn about that Iâ€™d go to church,â€ said Wells, who plans to testify against the bill.Â¶Shannon Schlomer is a father of five kids who have attended Mobridge-area schools. He has written letters to the editor of the local paper urging lawmakers to kill the bill, which he said aims to belittle established science and would hurt kids in South Dakota who want to go to college to become physicists, geologists or cosmologists.Â¶Steve Matzner, an Augustana professor who signed a letter earlier this month urging House members to vote against the bill, teaches introductory biology classes every year. Some of the students come from small schools where evolutionary theory is breezed over, and they tend to struggle grasping evidence-based teaching, he said.Â¶â€œThe biggest effect of the bill would be that it could underprepare high school students if their science education is being watered down,â€ he said.

title: Climate Diaries: Is eco-tourism the future of science funding? - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶ANTARCTICA -- There are things you can do as a tourist here that you canâ€™t do anywhere else. A plunge into the freezing Antarctic Ocean water is something you may only want to try once.Â¶But encounters with the Antarctic wildlife are something you may want to do over and over again. These trips are called expeditions, not cruises, for reasons that go beyond marketing. Â¶And with climate-change skeptics in the White House, they may be a new model for how scientific research gets paid for in the future.Â¶Renowned Antarctic ice scientist Ken Taylor says word is already out that there will be less research money available from this administration.Â¶â€œWeâ€™ve already gotten indications from our federal funding agencies, particularly the National Science Foundation, that we should anticipate budget cuts,â€ Taylor said. â€œIt didnâ€™t take very long after the election for that word to come down.â€Â¶Even when research is government-funded, the money often doesnâ€™t go far enough, even now. Â¶John Durban, an employee of the NOAA Fisheries department, uses a drone to check on the health of Antarctic whales. But thereâ€™s no way he and his co-researcher Holly Fearnbach could be here if they didnâ€™t get a ride from the tour operators.Â¶â€œIt costs hundreds of thousands of dollars if youâ€™re going to charter a research vessel,â€ Durban said. â€œItâ€™s a wonderful relationship that we have.â€Â¶The tourists are effectively funding the science.   Â¶And many, like Lori Fey from Austin, whoâ€™s up for just about anything, say they are willing to pay a premium to do so.Â¶â€œI really think itâ€™s a shame that the science is in the crosshairs of politics â€¦ because it doesnâ€™t take much to understand that we are having a detrimental effect, collectively, on the world,â€ Fey said.Â¶They come here for the experience, and they leave with more than memories. They leave with knowledge.Â¶The scientists on board give the tourists a sense of purpose, and if it werenâ€™t for the tourists, the scientists wouldnâ€™t be here. Itâ€™s a marriage made in heaven.

title: NASA satellite spots mile-long iceberg breaking off of Antarctic glacier
author: Kacey Deamer
content: Â¶A massive, 1-mile-long chunk of ice has broken off Antarcticaâ€™s fast-changing Pine Island Glacier, and NASA satellites captured the dramatic event as the icy surface cracked and ripped apart.Â¶The Pine Island Glacier is one of the largest glaciers within the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, accounting for about 20 percent of the ice sheetâ€™s total ice flow to the ocean, according to NASA scientists. The immense glacier is also one of the least stable, and in recent years, the ice sheet has been quickly retreating and losing massive amounts of ice. Previously, icebergs the size of cities have broken off of the Pine Island Glacier. [Photo Gallery: Antarcticaâ€™s Pine Island Glacier Cracks]Â¶The glacierâ€™s last major iceberg break â€” an event known as calving â€” was in July 2015, when an iceberg measuring almost 225 square miles separated from Pine Island Glacier.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The Earth-watching Landsat 8 satellite captured images of the latest iceberg event between Jan. 25 and 29, seeing the progression from the initial crack to the iceberg floating into the bay. Though this latest iceberg is about 10 times smaller than the 2015 event, measuring between 0.6 and 1.2 miles, NASA scientists said the recent break shows how fragile the ice shelf is.Â¶â€œI think this event is the calving equivalent of an â€˜aftershockâ€™ following the much bigger event,â€ Ian Howat, a glaciologist at The Ohio State University, said in a statement. â€œApparently, there are weaknesses in the ice shelf â€” just inland of the rift that caused the 2015 calving â€” that are resulting in these smaller breaks.â€Â¶More icebergs may break off of the Pine Island Glacier in the near future. NASA has previously photographed small rifts developing about 6 miles from the ice front, and one such rift was observed on Nov. 4, 2016, during one of the agencyâ€™s Operation IceBridge flights to monitor the region.Â¶Climate change and the warming ocean have been linked to the the retreat and melt of the worldâ€™s ice. According to Howat, such â€œrapid fireâ€ calving is generally unusual for the glacier, but West Antarctic glaciers are eroding due to the flow of warm ocean water beneath them. A recent study found that the warming ocean was melting an ice crevasse of the Pine Island Glacier at the bedrock level, melting the glacier from its center.Â¶These warmer ocean waters are causing the Antarctic ice shelf to break from the inside out. As such, scientists expect further calving along the glacier and have warned that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could collapse within the next 100 years.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Climate Diaries: Dramatic decline in Antarctica's penguin population due to climate change - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶In this installment of our â€œClimate Diariesâ€ series, CBS News correspondent Mark Phillips continues his reporting from Antarctica, one of the most remote places on earth. He shows us the dramatic shifts happening around a half-century-old research base. The icescape and the areaâ€™s penguin population reveal the impact of the rapid pace of climate change.Â¶It can seem like a landscape frozen in time in Antarctica, but itâ€™s anything but. And one place has been keeping meticulous records of the changes for 50 years, reports CBS News correspondent Mark Phillips. Â¶At Palmer Station, about 40 people work at a U.S. research base that has clung to this rocky outcrop on the Antarctic coast since the mid-1960s.Â¶ Bob Farrell has run the station for the past 18 years. If anybody knows how things have been changing here, itâ€™s him. Â¶â€œIt changes all the time. I mean, day to day it changes,â€ Farrell said.   Palmer was put here because it was a great place to study Antarctic wildlife. It sat in the middle of the perfect habitat for the Adelie penguin, who nested here in their tens of thousands. These are the birds that brought you â€œHappy Feet.â€ But they donâ€™t seem happy any more.Â¶â€œWeâ€™re counting the penguins every year,â€ said Shawn Farry. He is called the â€œbird man.â€ But lately, heâ€™s had a lot fewer birds to study. Â¶â€œThese local islands where weâ€™ve been censusing for â€“ itâ€™s 43 years now -- have declined by about 85 percent,â€ Farry said.              â€œEight-five percent?â€ Philips asked.                â€œThe numbers on this island at their peak were almost 9,000 and this year, it was about 1,200,â€ Farry said.              The Adelie penguins need one essential condition to thrive. They need sea ice to hunt from, and thereâ€™s less of that around now.             â€œIn the last several decades, the amount of ice along the peninsula declined by about, well, three months of sea ice,â€ Farry said.Â¶â€œThe sea ice season is three months shorter than it used to be?â€ Phillips asked.Â¶â€œCorrect,â€ Farry said. Â¶At first, it was hoped the penguins had simply moved further south into the Antarctic in search of the ice they love. Sadly, it seems not.             â€œWe do work other places down the peninsula looking for them,â€ Farry said.              â€œYouâ€™re not finding them?â€ Phillips asked.                    Â¶â€œCorrect. Weâ€™re not finding them,â€ Farry said.Â¶Not just the sea ice is retreating at Palmer. The base is next door to a spectacular glacier that is less spectacular than it used to be. Theyâ€™ve got a photograph showing the extent of the glacial ice in 1975 and where it had retreated to by 2013. Then a funny thing happened.Â¶Normally in places like this, you talk about things moving at glacial speed, taking their time -- not here. Here they know exactly when that glacier split off from this place. On March 14, 2014, this became Detrich Island. Â¶They had thought the island was part of the mainland, until the glacier linking it to the shore collapsed and disappeared.Â¶The speed of change has shocked even Farrell, the old Antarctica hand. Â¶â€œYeah, I mean, when you come back here after a year and you see, â€˜Wow, the glacier is quite a bit farther back,â€™ or you have people coming back who havenâ€™t been here for quite a while and theyâ€™re shocked by it,â€ Farrell said. â€œYeah, itâ€™s really remarkable.â€             Theyâ€™ve got a little bet going on Palmer Station where theyâ€™ve always thought the base was on the mainland. Now they think it may actual be on an island. They may not have to wait long to find out.

title: Climate threat to wildlife may have been massively underreported
author: Kacey Deamer
content: Â¶More than 700 of the worldâ€™s threatened and endangered animal species may be directly affected by climate change, according to a new study â€” vastly more than the number of animal species scientists initially thought would face risks from global warming.Â¶Scientists had previously determined that only 7 percent of mammals and 4 percent of birds on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) â€œRed Listâ€ of threatened species are affected by climate change. However, a new study finds that the threat from climate change may have been massively underreported.Â¶In a comprehensive analysis of 130 previous studies on the subject, researchers found that nearly half of the worldâ€™s threatened and endangered mammals and nearly a quarter of birds are already seriously impacted â€” more than 700 species total. [8 Ways Global Warming Is Already Changing the World]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Most climate change studies focus on impacts in the future, but the researchers said the effects of global warming are being felt â€œhere and now.â€ And research on present threats were focused on specific species and were spread across numerous journals, according to study co-author James Watson, director of the Science and Research Initiative at the Wildlife Conservation Society.Â¶â€œWe did the study because no one had really pulled together the evidence of how much climate change has impacted species to date,â€ Watson told Live Science. â€œWe know that the last 50 years have been warmer than the 50 years before that, and that thereâ€™s already been a 1-degree [Celsius] global warming event, but no one really talks about it.â€Â¶Once the researchers combined the studies into one analysis, Watson said the evidence of change was apparent and they could generalize trends across species. For example, the species most threatened lived in areas that have already warmed dramatically, or they had very specific survival requirements.Â¶Primates, in particular, are threatened because they have specialized diets and their tropical homes are vulnerable to extreme weather events caused by climate change. In some cases, species can adapt to the changes, but others are facing dire consequences, Watson said.Â¶â€œFor instance, mountain gorillas live on top of mountains â€” theyâ€™ve got nowhere else to go if the climate changes,â€ Watson said. â€œTheyâ€™re stuck on top of these mountains, so they might not survive climate change because they canâ€™t move anywhere else.â€Â¶Though birds can fly from mountaintop homes, the researchers found that species that live at higher altitudes and experience little seasonal temperature changes are negatively affected by climate change. Animals that dwell in aquatic environments also face even higher risks because these ecosystems are among the most vulnerable to global warming, according to the scientists.Â¶While the analysis notes that slightly more than 700 species may be affected by climate change, the researchers said this study only scratches the surface of how many of the planetâ€™s endangered species are at risk. The studies reviewed for their research only focused on mammals and birds â€” the most well-studied taxonomic groups, according to the scientists.Â¶â€œWe looked at only the most mobile species that probably should adapt the best and we found that theyâ€™re getting hammered,â€ Watson said. â€œCold-blooded animals are probably even more susceptible to climate change and we didnâ€™t even look at them yet. Certain types of plants even are far more susceptible, because they canâ€™t move â€” theyâ€™re actually stuck in the soil.â€Â¶The researchers are also calling for conservation efforts and governmental policies on climate change to focus on the present impacts on animals.Â¶â€œWe have to give species their best chance to overcome this, and the only way to do that is to keep nature intact,â€ Watson said. â€œItâ€™s pretty simple really, weâ€™ve just got to stop altering nature and degrading nature. Weâ€™ve got to keep things functioning and hope for the best.â€Â¶The new analysis is detailed in a paper published online Monday, Feb. 13, in the journal Nature Climate Change.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Climate Diaries: Researchers using unusual techniques to save killer whales in the Antarctic - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶In this latest installment of the â€œClimate Diariesâ€ series, CBS News correspondent Mark Phillips is in Antarctica, following a group of researchers chasing killer whales. They are using new technology, including drones, to learn about the health of the oceanâ€™s top predator. Phillips shows us how the Antarctic Oceanâ€™s dwellers are experiencing the effects of climate change.Â¶The ship that took a CBS News team to the U.S. research base at Palmer Station, Antarctica is not your average love boat.  Thereâ€™s some serious scientific work being done on this cruise, and the findings are not always happy ones, reports CBS News correspondent Mark Phillips.    The National Geographic Explorer is a different kind of adventure cruise ship. Sheâ€™s on a whale hunt, cutting through the pack ice near the Antarctic Circle. The good ship Explorer is not just here for sightseeing, although thereâ€™s plenty to see.Â¶ And while nobody shouts â€œThar she blows,â€ when whales are spotted, this time in open water, people do jump into small boats to chase them, just like in the old days. This hunt, though, isnâ€™t about killing whales; itâ€™s about saving them. Itâ€™s about giving them a health check, and the prognosis isnâ€™t particularly good.Â¶â€œOne of the reasons we study top predators -- and killer whales are the top predator in the ocean -- is to understand the health of the ecosystem that supports them,â€ said John Durban. He and Holly Fearnbach are modern whale hunters who use the latest tools. They use a drone fitted with equipment to monitor the whalesâ€™ condition. Â¶â€œWith a small drone like this, we can fly just a little over 100 feet -- the whales donâ€™t know itâ€™s there -- and we fly a camera much lower so the quality of the images are so much better,â€ Durban explained.  Â¶ The results are better pictures, but, it turns out, not better whales. The images of one pod of killer whales were not encouraging, particularly for the adult female -- the mother of the family.Â¶ â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with her?â€ Phillips asked.             â€œSheâ€™s very, very thin,â€ Fearnbach said. Â¶ â€œYou could see just following her, her whole body profile, you could see her ribs really clearly, so sheâ€™s lost all of the fat along her entire body,â€ Fearnbach said.  â€œYouâ€™re looking at a dying whale here?â€ Phillips asked.Â¶             â€œYes, youâ€™re looking at a dying whale. And she has a dependent offspring, and so once the female dies, then sheâ€™s also going to lose her calf, so itâ€™s very worrying,â€ Fearnbach said.Â¶And itâ€™s not just the size of the whales that Durban and Fearnbach are looking at. You wouldnâ€™t think you could take health-analyzing samples from whales out here in the Antarctic Ocean, but you can. The team has developed a technique â€“ here theyâ€™re using it in the Pacific â€“ to actually breathalyze whales by flying through the cloud of mist they produce when they breathe.  Â¶ â€œYou can tell by flying through that cloud of whale breath, the exhalation of a whaleâ€¦ youâ€™re picking up whatâ€™s inside the whale, is what youâ€™re saying?â€ Phillips asked.             â€œYeah. So these collection plates, like the one on the top here and the front here, theyâ€™re sterile, and weâ€™re able to collect droplets of whale blow. And from that, we take them back to the lab and use genetic techniques to identify the microorganisms that are in that blow,â€ Durban explained. Â¶Itâ€™s early in the program and Durban and Fearnbach are just building up a database of what comes out of a whaleâ€™s blowhole. But if a whale is unwell, the theory is youâ€™d effectively be able to smell it on their breath.Â¶In the meantime, they can only take an educated guess on why theyâ€™re finding sick whales in these pristine waters, which, like everywhere else, are getting warmer. The pack ice around which they normally hunt is not as abundant as it used to be; neither is the food they hunt for. Â¶â€œOur hypothesis certainly is thereâ€™sâ€¦ you know, a problem with their food supply, andâ€¦ fewer seals. And thatâ€™s what weâ€™ve been seeing so far this year,â€ Durban said.Â¶â€œLess ice, fewer seals? Is that a leap?â€ Phillips asked.Â¶â€œItâ€™s certainly a hypothesis,â€ Durban said. Â¶The next time Durban and Fearnbach are down this way, theyâ€™ll be looking for this family of whales, hoping theyâ€™re still around. Because this place is so remote and so difficult to work in for much of the year, wildlife research is less developed than in the Arctic. Everybody knows about the polar bears; now, itâ€™s time to think about the killer whales.

title: Climate Diaries: Tracking "irreversible" ice flows in Antarctica - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶ANTARCTICA -- High summer in Antarctica is an explosion of life when the deep freezer warms up to become just a refrigerator. Â¶And itâ€™s an explosion of scientific research when the Antarctic reveals the secrets that have been locked in its ice.Â¶â€œSomething is obviously going on. Itâ€™s very clear,â€ said Ken Taylor, a scientist who runs one of the continentâ€™s most ambitious ice research projects. Â¶And whatâ€™s going on is the huge crack thatâ€™s opened up in one of the floating ice shelves that cling to the coast here.Â¶â€œThereâ€™s a large berg about to break off of the Larsen Ice Shelf,â€ Taylor said. â€œThe size of Delaware, yes, itâ€™s very large and the fracture that is breaking off is expanding quite a bit lately, jumps about a mile every week or so.â€Â¶Itâ€™s not the ice from the ice shelf that is worrying.Â¶More Antarctic ice flowing into the sea would increase the threat to low-lying coastal areas around the world, including in the United States.Â¶â€œThere are several spots around Antarctica that are believed to be in this irreversible situation, where the ice on the ground is going to flow into the sea and thereâ€™s nothing we can do to stop it at this point,â€ Taylor said.Â¶Eric Guth is part of the Extreme Ice Survey, a scientific study that uses time-lapse photography to document whatâ€™s happening and prove that Antarctic ice is on the move. Â¶Images snapped every hour, then strung together, show how quickly the glaciers are flowing.  The pictures arenâ€™t just useful for science, but they have another purpose, according to Guth.Â¶â€œMuch of the general public are visual learners, as am I, and I think being able to see that with your own eyes is a very compelling way of communicating information,â€ he said.Â¶Arguments over the causes of climate change may be raging again at home. In Antarctica, suggestions of a hoax come up against some cold hard facts.  Â¶Taylor, the ice scientist, normally drills miles deep into the icecap for answers. Sometimes, though, theyâ€™re floating all around.Â¶Bubbles trapped in the ice contain the air that was around tens of thousands of years ago, when the ice froze.  And that air that contained a fraction of the warming greenhouse gasses the human race is now pumping into the atmosphere.  Â¶â€œIf you break this open and smell that air, youâ€™re smelling ancient air. Itâ€™s really good air, itâ€™s like air before humans messed up the atmosphere,â€ Taylor said.Â¶Thereâ€™s another kind of chill in Antarctica as well, a chill felt by the scientific community who fear the research money they need will be harder to come by in the future. And that there is a less sympathetic ear in government for the kind of science theyâ€™re doing.

title: Climate Diaries: Scientists on the front lines in Antarctica - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶Correspondent Mark Phillips has traveled through Europe and Africa to document how climate change is impacting our world for his â€œClimate Diariesâ€ series. This morning, traveling aboard the Lindblad Expeditions National Geographic Explorer, he reports from the far-less-traveled continent of Antarctica, where a massive iceberg is poised to break away, at a time of uncertainty over the U.S. governmentâ€™s policy toward climate change:Â¶Itâ€™s high summer down in Cierva Cove, Antarctica, and the temperature has been soaring all the way up to the freezing point. But when it comes to doing climate research, this is one of the hottest places on the planet.Â¶Summer in Antarctica is an explosion of life in a place often thought of as a bleak, frozen wasteland.Â¶And itâ€™s an explosion of scientific research, because this is the time of year when Antarctica is accessible and can be studied. This is when it reveals the secrets that have been locked into its ice.Â¶Ken Taylor, one of Americaâ€™s foremost ice scientists, has been studying the huge crack thatâ€™s opened up in one of the floating ice shelves that cling to the coast of Antarctica. â€œThereâ€™s a large berg about to break off of the Larsen ice shelf,â€ he said. Â¶A berg the size of Delaware.  Â¶â€œYes, itâ€™s very large, and the fracture that is breaking off is expanding quite a bit lately, it jumps about a mile every week or so.â€Â¶Itâ€™s not so much the floating sea ice from the shelf that is worrying; itâ€™s that without the ice shelf to hold it back, the glacial ice on land will flow into the ocean more quickly and drive sea levels up even more than the three feet that is already predicted for this century.Â¶â€œThere are several spots around here, around Antarctica, that are believed to be in this irreversible situation, where the ice on the ground is going to flow into the sea, and thereâ€™s nothing we can do to stop it at this point,â€ Taylor said. Â¶Eric Guth is trying to get at science in another way. Because there are concerns about ice shelf stability, there are concerns about warming sea temperatures around the Antarctic peninsula.Â¶What Guth is producing is an overview â€¦ literally. He is part of the Extreme Ice Survey that is documenting the changes that are happening, in pictures. Cameras placed at strategic locations snap one shot an hour, year-round.Â¶And they produce time-lapse images showing how the glaciers are moving, looking to see if theyâ€™re speeding up or getting thinner.Â¶â€œThis type of visual evidence, I think, is what people need,â€ Guth said. â€œMuch of the general public are visual learners, as am I, and I think being able to see that with your own eyes is a very compelling way of communicating information.â€Â¶Why is all this happening? Again, the ice tells the story, and it is not in denial.Â¶Ken Taylor normally drills miles deep into the Antarctic icecap to find the answers. Sometimes, though, you can find them floating all around you. Â¶Trapped in the ice are bubbles of the air that was around tens of thousands of years ago when it was frozen -- air that had a fraction of the amount of the greenhouse gases in it compared to what the human race is pumping into the atmosphere now.  Â¶â€œItâ€™s trapped in the ice, and if you release it, you can tell what the atmosphere was like 20-, 50-, 100,000 ago?â€ Phillips asked.Â¶â€œIf you break this open and smell that air, youâ€™re smelling ancient air. Itâ€™s really good air! Itâ€™s like air before humans messed up the atmosphere, yeah,â€ Taylor replied.Â¶Thereâ€™s another kind of chill down here as well -- a chill in the scientific community whoâ€™s working here. A fear the research money they need for their work will be less forthcoming in the future, and a less sympathetic ear in government for the kind of science they do.

title: Behold the collapsing beauty of Antarctica's Larsen Ice Shelf
author: Stephanie Pappas
content: Â¶An expansive new image shows the changes in Antarcticaâ€™s Larsen Ice Shelf since the mid-1980s.Â¶The story is one of retreat, and the ice continues to crumble. A growing crack in a portion of the ice shelf called Larsen C is poised to free an iceberg the size of Delaware from the continent.Â¶Larson C isnâ€™t visible in the new satellite image, which focuses on two more northerly portions of the sheet, Larsen A and Larsen B. Ice shelves are floating mattresses of ice that form from the outflow of the glaciers that creep slowly across the Antarctic continent. The Larsen Ice Shelf is on the northeast coast of the Antarctic Peninsula along the Weddell Sea. It was named for the Norwegian explorer Carl Anton Larsen, who explored parts of it in 1893 by ship and ski. [Images of Melt: Earthâ€™s Vanishing Ice]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Since 1995, the Larsen Ice Shelf has lost 75 percent of its mass, according to the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). In 1995, a 579-square-mile (1,500 square kilometers) chunk of Larsen A broke off from the ice shelf, according to NASAâ€™s Earth Observatory. In 2002, an even larger portion of Larsen B â€” 1,255 square miles (3,250 square km) crumbled away. While calving events are normal, collapses of this magnitude have only been seen in the last 30 years, according to the NSIDC.Â¶The collapse of floating ice doesnâ€™t raise sea levels, but a 2004 study by NSIDC researchers found that in the wake of Larsen Bâ€™s 2002 collapse, the land-based glaciers that feed the ice sheet have accelerated their flow toward the sea. This speedy flow of ice does have the ability to raise sea levels.   Â¶â€œYou can think of the Larsen or really any ice shelf like it is a cork in the neck of a champagne bottle lying on its side,â€ Christopher Shuman, a researcher who has studied these ice sheets at NASAâ€™s Goddard Space Flight Center, told the Earth Observatory. â€œOnce you pop that cork, the wine inside â€” all that glacial ice sitting on land â€” will start flowing out.â€Â¶The newly released image is a combination of four images that were taken by the Operational Land Imager on the Landsat 8 satellite on Jan. 6 and Jan. 8, according to the Earth Observatory. An overlay shows the former extent of the ice shelf in 1986, 2002 and 2016.Â¶The ice sheets are not only retreating, but also thinning, as a 2016 study in the journal Annals of Glaciology by Shuman and his colleagues found. The ice shelf is losing thickness at a rate of between 6.2 feet and 8.9 feet (1.9 and 2.7 meters) each year, with the fastest losses occurring on the eastern side of the shelf, the researchers reported. Scientists expect the remnants of the Larsen B Ice Shelf to vanish entirely as early as 2020, marking the end of an ice mass that previously persisted for 12,000 years.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Major global warming study again questioned, again defended
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” Another round of bickering is boiling over about temperature readings used in a 2015 study to show how the planet is warming.Â¶The issue is about how readings gathered decades ago were adjusted to try to get a clearer picture of how the Earthâ€™s temperature is changing now. Those adjustments have been questioned by some who reject mainstream climate science and have tried to claim there has been a pause in global warming.Â¶A January study in a scientific journal used another set of measurements to confirm the readings and prove again that the earthâ€™s temperature is rising quickly and that the warming has not paused.Â¶But a congressional committee on Tuesday seized on complaints from a retired scientist from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration about how the original data were handled to claim the data were falsified â€” even though the retired NOAA scientist they cite does not argue that it was.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶What is being touted as a scientific scandal is more about data handling than what rising temperatures show, according to phone and email interviews with more than two dozen experts on the issue, including the former government scientist, whose blogging Saturday reignited a debate.Â¶The hubbub was sparked when retired NOAA data scientist John Bates claimed in a blog post that his boss, then-director of the National Centers for Environmental Information Thomas Karl, â€œconstantly had his â€˜thumb on the scaleâ€™ â€” in the documentation, scientific choices and release of datasets â€” in an effort to discredit the notion of a global warming hiatusâ€ and rushed a study published in the journal Science before international climate negotiations.Â¶Bates said in an interview Monday with The Associated Press that he was most concerned about the way data was handled, documented and stored, raising issues of transparency and availability. He said Karl didnâ€™t follow the more than 20 crucial data storage and handling steps that Bates created for NOAA. He said it looked like the June 2015 study was pushed out to influence the December 2015 climate treaty negotiations in Paris.Â¶However Bates, who acknowledges that Earth is warming from man-made carbon dioxide emissions, said in the interview that there was â€œno data tampering, no data changing, nothing malicious.â€Â¶â€œItâ€™s really a story of not disclosing what you did,â€ Bates said in the interview. â€œItâ€™s not trumped up data in any way shape or form.â€Â¶Still, after Batesâ€™ blog post, the House Science Committee, a British tabloid newspaper and others who reject mainstream climate science accused NOAA of playing â€œfast and looseâ€ with land and water temperature data.Â¶House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, speaking at a hearing Tuesday, called on Science to retract the 2015 study and blasted NOAA for not being cooperative with his subpoenas. When the journalâ€™s publisher Rush Holt, a physicist and former Democratic congressman, said the charges donâ€™t support a retraction because the issue is more about data procedures than science, Smith, an attorney, interrupted him and insisted: â€œThey falsified global warming data.â€Â¶The Karl study looked mostly at ocean temperature records several decades old and determined that those older readings skewed too warm when compared to modern monitoring from buoys and other devices because they were taken in shipsâ€™ engine rooms. He adjusted those old readings down, which makes it clearer that the earthâ€™s temperature is rising now.Â¶Since then, a new independent study from the University of California, Berkeley looked at the same issue in a different way, and confirmed the Karl calculations.Â¶â€œNot using their data we get the exact same results, both for the ocean record and for the land,â€ said Zeke Hausfather, lead author of the Berkeley study. He called Batesâ€™ claims â€œall about procedural disagreements within NOAA that have very little bearing about our understanding about whatâ€™s happening to Earthâ€™s climate.â€Â¶Marcia McNutt, who was editor of Science at the time the paper was published and is now president of the National Academy of Sciences, praised Bates for wanting to highlight the importance of data archiving, but said his criticisms have little to do with the main part of the paper and chastised the House for using issues of data archiving to try to discredit the 2015 study.Â¶â€œThe study has been reproduced independently of Karl et al â€” thatâ€™s the ultimate platinum test of whether a study is to be believed or not,â€ McNutt said. â€œAnd this study has passed.â€Â¶The Associated Press interviewed more than two dozen experts by phone or email. Most agreed with Karl or didnâ€™t take a side but said it didnâ€™t matter because global warming continues regardless of this latest kerfuffle. Two supported Bates, saying there were serious scientific integrity concerns.Â¶As far as the study being rushed, the journal says its records show otherwise. Scienceâ€™s new editor-in-chief Jeremy Berg said it usually takes 109 days between a paperâ€™s submission and its publication. The Karl study was received by the journal on Dec. 23, 2014 and published 185 days later, on June 26, 2015.Â¶â€œThe paper was not rushed in any way,â€ McNutt said. â€œIt had an exceptional number of reviewers, many more than average because we knew it was on a controversial topic. It had a lot of data analysis.â€

title: Storms preview sea-rise damage to California roads, cities
content: Â¶SAN FRANCISCO -- Ocean rise already is worsening the floods and high tides sweeping California this stormy winter, climate experts say, and this monthâ€™s damage and deaths highlight that even a state known as a global leader in fighting climate change has yet to tackle some of the hardest work of dealing with it.Â¶The critical steps yet to come include starting to decide which low-lying cities, airports and highways, along with threatened landmarks like San Franciscoâ€™s Embarcadero, to hoist above the rising water and which to abandon -- and where to start getting the many billions of dollars for those climate rescues.Â¶â€œPeople always tell us weâ€™re ahead of the curveâ€ on climate change, said Larry Goldzband, head of a regional San Francisco Bay commission that late last year stepped up regional efforts to identify and prioritize communities and infrastructure at risk from rising sea level. As proud as Californians are of their climate-change efforts, â€œI always think, â€˜Man, if we are ahead of the curve, I feel sorry for the rest of the country,â€™â€ Goldzband said.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶A 2009 study by the Pacific Institute, a California-based environment think-tank, estimated $100 billion in property was at risk from ocean rise in California, two-thirds of it in the low-lying San Francisco Bay region. Thatâ€™s far more than the state takes in from income taxes each year.Â¶Experts say the real cost of raising, shielding or evacuating vulnerable spots, which include mass-transit systems, power plants and sewage plants, could be far higher.Â¶â€œAstronomical. The San Francisco airport? What would it cost to replace that?â€ asked Gary Griggs, director of the Institute of Marine Sciences at the University of California, Santa Cruz.Â¶Griggs is part of a scientific working group requested by Gov. Jerry Brown to examine whether new evidence on melting and potential ice-sheet collapse in the Antarctic, whose ice holds almost 90 percent of the Earthâ€™s fresh water, means sea-level rise may be even higher than the 3 feet projected for California by the end of the century.Â¶The Pacific off California has risen just about 8 inches overall in the past century. For the next three decades or so, the accelerating pace of sea rise primarily will make worse the flooding and erosion from big storms like this monthâ€™s in California.Â¶â€œProbably until mid-century, short-term events ... are going to be more damaging than sea-level rise itself,â€ Griggs said.Â¶In January, a series of powerful storms brought more than a foot of rain to parts of the San Francisco Bay, triggered record 34-foot waves off the stateâ€™s central coast, killed at least five people and prompted the evacuations of thousands around the state.Â¶The dead included a cab driver who slid off a wet road and into a swollen estuary off Oaklandâ€™s airport, which along with San Franciscoâ€™s bayside airport is one of the big sites expected to be hit more and more often by flooding as the Pacific Ocean rises a foot over the next 30 years.Â¶Brown, who declared an emergency in much of the state this month because of flooded towns and highways, crumbled roads and rockslides, has vowed to fight if the fossil-fuel friendly Trump administration goes after Californiaâ€™s landmark programs to reduce climate-changing carbon emissions. Brownâ€™s administration in 2015 also sought to speed up planning for dealing with sea rise and other climate change.Â¶On a sparkling afternoon after three storms brought some of the heaviest rain and surf to California in decades, ecologist Fraser Shilling stood on a highway bridge north of San Francisco, looking over sprawling miles of floodwater and salty bay water swallowing the highwayâ€™s exit ramp, and drowning salt marshes and fence posts as far as the eye could see.Â¶State Route 37 is a busy highway for tens of thousands of commuters and truckers in and out of Californiaâ€™s wine country. Shilling, a co-director of the Road Ecology Center at the University of California, Davis, had forecast it wouldnâ€™t be seeing this kind of regular high water for at least another 20 years.Â¶â€œThis is the new normal,â€ says Shilling, who believes sea rise already is changing conditions on the ground more than some state agencies realize. â€œAnd all of our infrastructure is not accommodating the new normal.â€Â¶Pumps and bulldozers labored to clear water from another stretch of the state highway, two weeks after the storms.Â¶State and local governments acknowledge that low-lying sites like State Route 37 will be hit by sea-rise worsened floods and tides more and more, before the bay claims them completely.Â¶But authorities are stymied by the financial and political difficulties of raising billions to elevate or protect the highway, or reroute it through pricey vineyards inland. As it is now, substantial state funding isnâ€™t expected for this particular highway until 2088, long after parts of it are expected to be regularly submerged.Â¶â€œOur biggest challenge is how to fund and build it before it goes underwater,â€ said Kate Miller, executive director of the transportation authority for Napa County.Â¶California might not really start funding its rescues from sea rise until a major part of the public is inconvenienced, said state Sen. Jerry Hill, a Democrat from San Mateo County.Â¶Hillâ€™s prediction of what would free the funds: If a low-lying stretch of U.S. Highway 101 near San Franciscoâ€™s old Candlestick Park floods, and much of the Bay Area suddenly could not get to work.Â¶â€œThat will be the wake-up call, when the rubber hits the road,â€ he said. â€œWhen the water hits the tailpipe.â€

title: Climate change poses increasingly severe risks, EU agency warns
content: Â¶COPENHAGEN, Denmark -  The European Environment Agency says the continent is facing rising sea levels and more extreme weather, such as more frequent and more intense heat waves, flooding, droughts and storms because of climate change.Â¶The Copenhagen-based agency says that its assessment is based on the latest trends and projections on climate change and its impacts across Europe.Â¶The European Union body says that observed changes in climate â€œare already having wide-ranging impactsâ€ on ecosystems, the economy and on human health and well-being in Europe.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Its head, Hans Bruyninckx, said Wednesday that climate change â€œwill continue for many decades to come,â€ adding the scale and impacts will, among other things, â€œdepend on the effectiveness of implementing our global agreements to cut greenhouse gas emissions.â€Â¶The landmark Paris climate agreement, which went into effect in November, provides targets set by each country to reduce its emissions, with the aim of slowing the pace of global warming. But President Donald Trump has said in the past he believes climate change is a â€œhoaxâ€ and that he intends to â€œcancelâ€ U.S. involvement in the Paris deal.Â¶Meanwhile, the Earth set its third straight record for the hottest year in  2016, and scientists have grown increasingly alarmed by the accelerating rate of polar ice melt and the threat of rising sea levels that could inundate coastlines around the world.

title: Sea level rise will disproportionately hit U.S. this century, NOAA warns
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Global sea level rise is unfolding at a stunning pace, and a new report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA) says the U.S. will find itself directly in the crosshairs. Over the coming decades, some parts of the nationâ€™s coastline will be hit harder than others, the study finds.Â¶The report â€” co-authored with the U.S. Department of Commerce, the U.S. Geological Survey, the Environmental Protection Agency, the South Florida Water Management District, and scientists from Rutgers and Columbia University â€” outlined six likely scenarios for sea level rise, ranging in severity from low to extreme, so that communities and the federal government can plan around those likelihoods. Â¶In almost all the scientistsâ€™ projections, sea level rise will disproportionately affect the coasts of the U.S. Northeast and the western Gulf of Mexico, compared to averages across the globe. Except for Alaska, the report says nearly all of the U.S. coastline is more vulnerable than the global average if more severe scenarios come to pass.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In the mildest projected scenario, global sea levels will rise by about one foot by the end of this century. In the worst-case scenario, global sea levels will rise by 8.2 feet. Â¶Though eight feet may not sound like a huge number, the consequences would be devastating: researchers have estimated that a lower rise of six feet would be enough swallow up the homes of about six million Americans.Â¶The new report is an update to one issued in 2012, and paints a significantly darker picture of sea level rise. The worst-case scenario outlined in this report is 1.6 feet higher than the worst-case scenario scientists projected for this century just five years ago. Â¶Whatâ€™s behind the growing concern about sea level rise? A major factor, scientists say, is the rapid melting of Arctic ice due to global warming. The Earth saw its third straight year of record-high temperatures in 2016, while polar ice diminished to record lows.
