Â¶In historical perspective, Arctic warming over the past five years is â€œas fast and as large a magnitudeâ€ as the warming that occurred during the last vestiges of the Ice Age 11,500 years ago â€” the transition that gave birth to our modern climate era, Paul Mayewski, professor at the University of Maineâ€™s Climate Change Institute, told CBS News last month.Â¶The latest report also points out that worldwide, sea level rise will impact different geographic areas in vastly different ways, shaped by factors like land elevation and ocean circulation.Â¶â€œThe ocean is not rising like water would in a bathtub,â€ said William Sweet, Ph.D., a NOAA oceanographer and lead author of the report, explained in a statement. â€œFor example, in some scenarios sea levels in the Pacific Northwest are expected to rise slower than the global average, but in the Northeast they are expected to rise faster.â€ Â¶The authors say the report was conceived in response to states and citiesâ€™ requests for more information tailored to their specific locations, to help them prepare and make decisions about how to manage and adapt their critical infrastructure.

title: "Nobody wants to do this": Scientists debate extreme steps to fight global warming
author: Mola Taylor Redd
content: Â¶Potential large-scale solutions to combat the influence that humans have on Earthâ€™s rising temperatures may directly affect astronomers.Â¶During one of the United Statesâ€™ largest astronomical conferences, on Jan. 4, scientists discussed what geoengineering the planetâ€™s atmosphere could mean for astronomers whose job it is to observe the night sky. Geoengineering refers to directly altering the Earth or its atmosphere to try and lessen the impact of climate change. While climate change is seemingly unrelated to night-sky observation, the panelists argued that it was an issue that astronomers needed to be concerned with.Â¶â€œItâ€™s an astronomical problem if we define astronomy to include planetary science and evolution,â€ said David Grinspoon, an astrobiologist at the Planetary Science Institute. He was joined by Jane Long, a retired scientist at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory; Tom Ackerman, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Washington; and Mel Ulmer, an astronomer at Northwestern University. James Lowenthal, an astronomer at Smith College, served as moderator.Â¶  [Changing Earth: 7 Ideas to Geoengineer Our Planet]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œWe [humans] need to learn how to become a long-term stabilizing factor on this planet,â€ Grinspoon said.Â¶To mitigate the most serious consequences of global warming, climate scientists have warned that the rise in Earthâ€™s temperature needs to be capped at no more than 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit (2 degrees Celsius). Long-term strategies require reducing the burning of fossil fuels, which puts carbon dioxide into the air. But the panelists said that wonâ€™t be sufficient to reach the low levels necessary to meet the goals established by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).Â¶â€œOne of the dirty little secrets of the IPCC is that it requires negative emissions,â€ Long said, referring to the process of recapturing CO2 that has already been released. No existing models predict staying below the necessary levels, she said, which means that itâ€™s not enough to simply stop emitting carbon dioxide; further steps will need to be taken to remove whatâ€™s already in the air.Â¶Geoengineering Earthâ€™s atmosphere includes several different proposals for removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Various proposed methods can lock solid or liquid carbon into the ground, in trees or in water.Â¶â€œI like fizzy water, and Iâ€™m looking forward to seeing lots of CO2 in ground water,â€ Ulmer joked.Â¶Geoengineering also includes methods for reducing the amount of sunlight. The panelists discussed releasing aerosol particles or spraying seawater into the atmosphere to form clouds, and launching mirrors into orbit to redirect sunlight. The planetâ€™s temperature depends on how much sunlight it receives, so changing that amount can keep the planet cooler.Â¶Changing the amount of sunlight is more readily deployable than removing carbon dioxide, Ackerman said. Synthetic volcanic clouds or clouds that hang over the ocean would reflect sunlight back into space, lowering the temperature.Â¶Geoengineering the atmosphere isnâ€™t something to be rushed into, however. According to Ackerman, there is no active research program in the United States or Europe that is studying the consequences of geoengineering.Â¶â€œNobody wants to do this,â€ Ackerman said. â€œNo one wants to fund it.â€Â¶With no funding for trying to understand how any of the proposed methods could affect the atmosphere, those ideas are immediately dismissed from the realm of possibility. That needs to change if scientists plan to actively take steps to reduce carbon dioxide, the panelists said.Â¶â€œWe canâ€™t go out and start this tomorrow, at least not in any responsible way,â€ Ackerman said. He said that he firmly supports the need to do more research before deploying any systems to change the environment. That includes studying what kinds of unintended consequences could come from geoengineering.Â¶The panel members seemed certain that manipulating the climate on large scales could lead to problems on smaller scales: Changing the entire planetâ€™s climate could result in catastrophes at regional levels.Â¶â€œWe can have a solution that works globally and gets the average temperature down to a safer range,â€ Grinspoon said. Itâ€™s possible, however, that such a solution could kick off a monsoon and cause a disaster for a lot of people, he said.Â¶The panel members agreed that geoengineering was only a short-term solution to help scale down the planetâ€™s temperature before it reaches catastrophic levels â€” itâ€™s not a long-term, permanent solution.Â¶â€œSolar-radiation management is not a substitute for mitigation,â€ Long said.Â¶Adding particles into the air could have a number of important ramifications, including affecting how well astronomers can view the night sky. According to Lowenthal, some studies have shown that adding clouds to the atmosphere can increase the brightening of the night sky by as much as 25 percent. But that doesnâ€™t mean it shouldnâ€™t be done.Â¶â€œFixing global warming is more important than astronomy,â€ Grinspoon said. He expressed the hope that such a solution might inspire more astronomers to invest time in promoting climate change. Even without that impetus, he felt that the need to address the long-term consequences of global warming outweighed the potential benefits of studying the heavens.Â¶â€œThereâ€™s no question to my mind that saving our civilization and many other species is more important than our ability to do ground-based astronomy for a few decades,â€ Grinspoon said.Â¶Follow Nola Taylor Redd on Twitter @NolaTRedd or Google+. Follow us at @Spacedotcom, Facebook or Google+. Originally published on Space.com.

title: Hawaii considers 100 percent renewable energy goal for transportation
content: Â¶HONOLULU -- Hawaii has the most aggressive renewable energy targets in the nation, aiming for its utilities to get 100 percent of their electricity from renewable sources by 2045.Â¶Now advocates want to extend that goal to the transportation sector to urge all forms of ground transportation to fuel up using renewable sources by 2045.Â¶â€œThe majority of our fossil fuel goes into transportation, and thatâ€™s a challenge that we have to solve, and we currently donâ€™t have a vision for what that future looks like,â€ said Jeff Mikulina, executive director of the Blue Planet Foundation, which is pushing the bill.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶But Hawaii officials arenâ€™t planning to make everyone get rid of their fuel-powered cars - at least not yet.Â¶â€œNobody wants to step in and force people to get rid of cars that they might love now,â€ said state Rep. Chris Lee, chairman of the Energy and Environment committee.Â¶The goal represents a steep climb for the auto industry in a state where there are about 5,000 electric vehicles, out of an estimated one million cars on the road.Â¶â€œOur ability to achieve it is really going to be dependent on what happens throughout the entire automotive industry,â€ said Hugh Baker, managing director of HD Baker & Co., an energy consulting company. â€œWe can say we want 100 percent clean transportation technology, but the market in Hawaii is not nearly big enough by itself to move the whole global automotive industry. It will really take more than just Hawaii.â€Â¶Unlike Hawaiiâ€™s groundbreaking 100 percent renewable goal for electricity, where utilities in the state will be fined if they donâ€™t comply by deadline, the proposed transportation goal isnâ€™t a mandate.Â¶With one million cars on the roads, hundreds of auto dealerships and multiple counties with fleets of vehicles, itâ€™s unclear how the state could enforce a renewable fuels mandate, advocates said. Beyond the vehicle stakeholders, there are cyclists and pedestrians in the mix, making it challenging for the state to even measure what percentage of the stateâ€™s transportation fuel comes from renewables.Â¶The bill is being introduced in the Hawaii Legislature, which began Wednesday. If passed, Hawaii would be the first in the nation to set such a high goal for its transportation sector. Vermont also has an aggressive goal for renewable fuel in transportation, but most states donâ€™t have such targets in place.Â¶â€œThatâ€™s a huge, huge transformation,â€ said Hawaii Gov. David Ige in a recent interview with The Associated Press. â€œWe are the most isolated community on the planet, and we import virtually all of the oil we use today.â€Â¶Details of the bill are still being worked out, but itâ€™s undecided whether it will come with funding, Lee said.Â¶The state recently created a new position in the Department of Transportation to work on renewable fuels in transportation, and it is planning to build infrastructure to increase electric vehicle charging stations at work locations in Honoluluâ€™s urban core using state funds, he said.Â¶Lawmakers also are introducing a bill to boost the required number of electric vehicle charging stations, which is currently one station per 100 spaces, so that commuters can charge electric vehicles during the day when more energy from the sun is pumping into the grid.Â¶Encouraging more electric vehicles - or â€œbatteries on wheelsâ€ - could help Hawaii meet its renewable electricity goals.Â¶â€œItâ€™s easier to manage more renewable energy when we have electric vehicles on the grid that can suck up that excess and hopefully in the future put some energy back on the grid,â€ Mikulina said.Â¶Auto dealers in Hawaii support the transition to renewable energy, but they believe it will take a massive advertising campaign by the state to encourage people to buy vehicles powered by alternative fuels, said David Rolf, executive director of the Hawaii Automobile Dealers Association.Â¶â€œIâ€™m passionate about this goal, but Iâ€™m also realistic,â€ Rolf said.Â¶Hawaiiâ€™s residents ranked second in the nation in 2015 with 2.94 electric vehicles for every 1,000 residents, just behind California, according to the U.S. Department of Energy.Â¶Tackling the fossil fuels used in air travel - which is critical to Hawaiiâ€™s tourism-driven economy - will have to wait.Â¶About a quarter of the 36 million barrels of oil Hawaii imported in 2015 was used for commercial aviation. But the long flights require energy in a dense form, and with todayâ€™s technology thatâ€™s generally only available in fuels, energy experts said.Â¶â€œThey need to go so far between recharge opportunities that they really need something with a higher energy density than batteries, and itâ€™s just not even physically possible for an airplane to carry enough batteries to go where it needs to go,â€ said Matthias Fripp, an assistant professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of Hawaii at Manoa.

title: Huge ice crack in Antarctica forces British scientists to flee research station
content: Â¶LONDON -- British scientists have decided to close the Halley VI Research Station in Antarctica for the winter amid concerns about safety.Â¶The British Antarctic survey said Monday that changes to the ice presents â€œa complex glaciological pictureâ€ that causes concern about the shelf on which the station is located in the coming months. The survey says a new crack on the floating Brunt Ice Shelf in Antarctica will force them to remove people before the Antarctic winter, which runs from March to November, ends.Â¶Thereâ€™s no risk to the people currently at the station, but difficulties in evacuating people during the winter prompted scientists to shut the station as a precaution.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The station is a platform for global Earth, atmospheric and space weather observation in a climate-sensitive zone.

title: Global warming could steal postcard-perfect weather days
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- Global warming is going to steal away some of those postcard-perfect weather days in the future, according to a first-of-its-kind projection of nice weather.Â¶On average, Earth will have 10 fewer days of mild and mostly dry weather by the end of the century, the researchers estimate. Some places will get more days perfect for picnics or outdoor weddings, while other places will lose a lot. Rio de Janeiro, Miami and much of Africa are big losers, while Europe and Seattle will gain nicer weather.Â¶â€œItâ€™s the type of weather where you can go outside and do something fun,â€ said study lead author Karin van der Wiel, a meteorology researcher at Princeton University and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration . â€œItâ€™s not too cold. Itâ€™s not too hot. Itâ€™s not too humid.â€Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶For the past three decades, the world has averaged 74 mild days a year. But by 2035 that will shrink to 70 and then 64 by the last two decades of the century, according to the study, published Wednesday in the journal Climatic Change . Mild weather was defined as between 68 and 86 degrees (18 and 30 degrees Celsius) with low humidity and no more than a trace of rain.Â¶Any change depends on where you live and the time of year. For example, on average, the U.S. will lose nine mild summer days by the end of the century, although most is gained back with more mild days in the winter, spring and fall. The report estimates that Washington, Chicago, New York and Dallas will lose two weeks of pleasant summer weather but some is gained back. On average, Washington loses 13 mild days; Atlanta, 12; Chicago, 9; Denver and New York, 6; and Dallas, 1.Â¶The biggest losers will be the tropics and nearly all of Africa, eastern South America, South Asia and northern Australia. Rio de Janeiro, on average, will see 40 mild days disappear. Miami will lose its only mild summer day and nearly a month of spring and fall mild days by 2100.Â¶â€œThe changes are more dramatic in parts of the developing world, where you have high concentrations of populations,â€ said NOAA climate scientist and co-author Sarah Kapnick.Â¶Other places, especially northern developed ones, will gain some of what the tropics lost. England and northern Europe are big winners. Seattle should pick up nine mild days and Los Angeles, which already has a lot of nice weather, gets six extra by the end of the century.Â¶The scientists didnâ€™t specifically focus on whether the loss of mild days has already started globally, but they did see it happening in much of Africa and South America, Van der Wiel said.Â¶Climate scientists usually focus on extreme weather -- record heat, tropical cyclones, droughts, floods â€” and how they could get worse as the world warms. Kapnick said she wanted to look at nice weather because her friends kept asking her what day to choose for good wedding weather.Â¶The team used a middle ground scenario for global warming -- not worst-case runawaycarbon pollution and not dramatic cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases -- and ran different computer simulations to see what would happen.Â¶Itâ€™s not just fewer nice days to enjoy. Fewer mild days will also harm agricultural production and allow disease carrying insects to thrive more in more places, said University of Georgia meteorology professor Marshall Shepherd.Â¶Stanford University climate scientist Chris Field, who led an international study of extreme weather, questioned the purpose of the study: â€œExtreme conditions are the sharp end of the climate stick. It is in the extremes when things break and damage occurs.â€Â¶National Center for Atmospheric Research scientist Gerald Meehl, who also studies extreme weather, said a decrease in mild weather may not quite have the economic and health costs but there are other factors such as tourism â€œor simple human enjoyment.â€

title: Earth sets hottest year record for third straight year
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” Government scientists say the Earth sizzled to a third straight heat record last year. Globally, the average temperature over land and ocean surfaces for 2016 was the highest since record keeping began in 1880.Â¶They mostly blame man-made global warming with help from a natural El Nino, which has since disappeared.Â¶The figures announced Wednesday come from NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which measure global temperatures in slightly different ways. They said last year passed 2015 as the hottest year on record.Â¶NOAA calculated that the average global temperature last year was 58.69 degrees (14.84 degrees Celsius) - beating the previous year by .07 degrees (.04 Celsius).Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Temperatures were particularly high in the first half of the year due to the power of El NiÃ±o.Â¶Sixteen of the 17 hottest years ever on record have officially occurred in the 21st century, according to the WMO. The only outlier was 1998.Â¶NASAâ€™s figures include more of the Arctic, which was warmer than usual. The agency said last year was .22 degrees (.12 degrees Celsius) warmer than 2015. Â¶Looking forward, continued melting of polar ice in the Arctic could lead to catastrophic sea level rise and flooding around the world. Some 13 million Americans could become â€œclimate refugeesâ€ by the end of this century if the worst projections come to pass, research in 2016 warned.Â¶NASAâ€™s Gavin Schmidt said most of the record heat was from man-made climate change.

title: U.S. plan on endangered polar bears lacks teeth, critics say
content: Â¶ANCHORAGE, Alaska -- The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service released its plan Monday for the recovery of threatened polar bears, acknowledging it will take no direct action for addressing the primary threat -- greenhouse gases that contribute to the decline of sea ice habitat.Â¶Polar bears, the first species to be declared threatened or endangered because of climate change, rely on sea ice for hunting seals and raising their young. Climate models project that rising temperatures will continue to diminish sea ice throughout the century.Â¶The plan calls for reduced greenhouse-gas emissions but focuses agency actions only on other conservation strategies, such as preventing contamination from spills, protecting dens or reducing conflicts with people.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Shaye Wolf, climate science director for the Center for Biological Diversity, which filed the petition to list polar bears in 2005, called the recovery plan toothless.Â¶She said it acknowledges that polar bears will not survive without cuts in large-scale greenhouse-gas pollution and shows the need to keep global temperature rise well below 2 degrees Celsius. But the agencyâ€™s job was to call out the steps needed for polar bears to survive, Wolf said.Â¶â€œIt acknowledges the problem but fails to put the solution in the core strategy for the bear,â€ she said.Â¶The agency said in its plan that addressing increased greenhouse gases that result in Arctic warming will require global action. Until that happens, the focus of recovery will be on efforts by U.S. wildlife management that contribute to polar bear survival in the interim â€œso that they are in a position to recover once Arctic warming has been abated,â€ the plan said.Â¶Dirk Kempthorne, who was secretary of the U.S. Interior Department under President George W. Bush, announced in 2008 that polar bears would be listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. But he said that law would not be used to set climate policy or limit greenhouse-gas emissions.

title: Quirk may shield U.S. coast during busy hurricane season
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- A climatic quirk seems to be slightly shielding the U.S. coast during busy hurricane seasons, often weakening major storms just as they approach Americaâ€™s beaches, a new study finds.Â¶That could help explain why itâ€™s been more than 11 years since a major hurricane with winds of more than 110 mph has hit the United States mainland.Â¶Last yearâ€™s Hurricane Matthew was a perfect example of this uniquely American â€œprotective barrierâ€ of stronger crosswinds and cooler coastal waters, according to the studyâ€™s author, climate scientist Jim Kossin of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Matthew devastated Haiti as a monster storm hitting land with 145 mph winds, threatened Florida as a major hurricane and then fizzled as it finally came ashore in South Carolina, barely registering as a hurricane with 75 mph winds.Â¶Kossinâ€™s study published Wednesday in the journal Nature found that shifts in air and ocean conditions over decades work together to weaken major storms along the U.S. coast. This protective barrier begins around the U.S.-Mexico border in Brownsville, Texas, and gets more noticeable around the Atlantic coast, Kossin said.Â¶â€œItâ€™s a lucky byproduct for the United States coast,â€ Kossin said. â€œItâ€™s really unfortunate that weâ€™re the only ones that seem to be benefiting from this situation.â€Â¶The Atlantic Ocean seems to alternate between cycles of heavy and low hurricane activity. The current heavy cycle began in 1993, after a low period of more than two decades. During those quieter times, when a major hurricane forms in the Atlantic it is three to six times more likely to rapidly intensify near the U.S. coast than during the busier times, according to the study.Â¶Kossin mapped sea surface temperatures and wind shear levels in the Atlantic to see small changes near the U.S. coast - but only during a busy cycle. His study found a localized increase in high altitude crosswinds â€” called wind shear â€” that tear at a stormâ€™s structure. It also found slightly cooler sea surface temperatures, which reduce a hurricaneâ€™s fuel of hot water. The changes seem to be just a function of larger natural conditions, he said.Â¶Take Octoberâ€™s Hurricane Matthew: â€œAs it approached Florida, it started to encounter wind shear, which weakened it to a minimal hurricane,â€ Kossin said.Â¶Previously, he also found that during busy cycles, bigger storms tend to form slightly more to the east â€” toward Africa â€” giving them more opportunity to curve harmlessly north in the Atlantic instead of hitting the U.S. coastline. All those factors seem to be helping reduce the U.S. threat compared to other places in the Atlantic, he said.Â¶Even with that â€œprotective barrierâ€ as Kossin calls in in the paper, there is still a greater chance of major hurricanes nearing the U.S. during busy times than quiet times, Kossin said. Thatâ€™s because there are more storms brewing overall.Â¶Three outside scientists contacted by The Associated Press praised the study as interesting, though not complete, while two others cautioned against reading too much into it. Georgia Techâ€™s Judith Curry called it solid research while Penn Stateâ€™s David Titley said he worried about small sample size and natural variations.Â¶Kossin and other scientists also said the 11-year major hurricane landfall drought since 2005â€™s Wilma is a bit of a statistical quirk because of strict meteorological definitions and national borders. Superstorm Sandy in 2012 wasnâ€™t considered a major hurricane because its winds werenâ€™t strong enough.

title: Global warming data that riled doubters turns out to be true
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” A new independent study shows no pause in global warming, confirming a set of temperature readings adjusted by U.S. government scientists that some who reject mainstream climate science have questioned.Â¶The adjustments, made by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in 2015 to take into account changes in how ocean temperatures have been measured over the decades, riled a House committee and others who claimed the changes were made to show rising temperatures. The House Science Committee subpoenaed the agencyâ€™s scientists and then complained that NOAA wasnâ€™t answering its requests quickly enough.Â¶The new international study looked at satellite data, readings from buoys and other marine floats for ocean temperatures. Each measurement system independently showed the same 20 years of increase in temperatures that NOAA found: about two-tenths of a degree Fahrenheit per decade since 2000, said the studyâ€™s lead author, Zeke Hausfather of the University of California, Berkeley.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œOur research confirms that NOAA scientists were right,â€ Hausfather said. â€œThey were not in any way cooking the books.â€Â¶NOAA adjusted past data to take into account old measurements by ships that often recorded temperatures from their engine rooms, where heat from the engines skewed the data. Buoys and satellite data donâ€™t have such artificial warming, Hausfather said.Â¶In 1990, about 90 percent of the ocean temperature readings were done by ships, now it is about 85 percent by the more accurate buoys, Hausfather said.Â¶Scientists Andrew Dessler of Texas A&M University and Kevin Trenberth of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, who werenâ€™t part the original study or the more recent one that confirmed its conclusions, called both accurate.Â¶â€œThis paper further allays any qualms that there may have been scientific errors or any non-scientific agendas,â€ Trenberth said in an email.Â¶Officials at the House Science Committee did not respond to repeated requests for comment.Â¶Hausfatherâ€™s study was published Wednesday in the journal Science Advances.

title: How climate change transformed the Earth in 2016
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶2016 was a milestone year in the continued warming of the planet. From unstable agriculture to the drought in California to melting ice sheets to extreme weather events and heat waves, climate change has disrupted virtually every corner of the world.Â¶Itâ€™s impossible to exhaustively list all the ways in which climate change was felt in 2016, but hereâ€™s a guide to understanding the year that was for the planet:Â¶â€œIn the centuries to come, history books will likely look back on September 2016 as a major milestone for the worldâ€™s climate,â€ Brian Kahn of Climate Central wrote earlier this year.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Thatâ€™s because, during September, a month in which atmospheric carbon dioxide â€” a heat-trapping greenhouse gas â€”is usually at its lowest, the monthly value failed to drop below 400 parts per million. The 400 ppm mark has sad significance in the climate community, as it has long been considered a point of no return for the atmosphere by scientists. Â¶This year is poised to be the hottest year in the 137-year official record, with global temperatures climbing even higher than record-breaking 2015, according to data released in November from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). Temperatures were particularly high in the first half of the year due to the power of El NiÃ±o.Â¶Though final data from December is not yet in, January to November 2016 was the warmest such period worldwide on record, according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Â¶If 2016 ends up with the title of hottest year on record, as expected, that would mean that 16 of the 17 hottest years on record have occurred in this century. The only outlier was 1998, according to the WMO.Â¶Still need perspective? Research released this year shows that, if we take a much longer view of Earthâ€™s temperature history and consider temperature averages in 5,000 year increments, the Earth is now warmer than it has been in 120,000 years.Â¶Global warming has had a particularly dramatic impact on the Arctic, which has been transformed by significantly warmer temperatures, lower levels of sea ice, and more open water in recent years.Â¶Last month, the average Arctic sea ice extent â€” the measurement scientists use to represent the area of ocean where there is at least some sea ice â€” was 17.7 percent below the averages from 1981 to 2010, according to NOAA. Thatâ€™s the lowest November extent since the NOAA began keeping records in 1979.Â¶â€œFor the people in the Arctic, no one has to tell them an abrupt climate change has hit,â€ Paul Mayewski, professor at the University of Maineâ€™s Climate Change Institute, told CBS News in an interview last week.Â¶Continued melting of polar ice could lead to catastrophic sea level rise and flooding on coastlines around the world. Some 13 million Americans could become â€œclimate refugeesâ€ by the end of this century if the worst projections come to pass, one study this year warned.Â¶Scientists say human activities are directly linked to Arctic warming: driving a gas-powered car about 90 miles â€“ the distance between New York and Philadelphia â€“ produces enough carbon pollution to melt about a square foot of Arctic sea ice during the critical month of September, research shows.Â¶The continued warming of the planet in 2016 is having a destabilizing impact on agriculture worldwide. Â¶Those disruptions were particularly felt in coffee production, which supports an estimated 120 million of some of the worldâ€™s poorest people in Africa, Central and South America, and Southeast Asia.Â¶In the mountains of eastern Uganda, a coffee-rich region, growers struggled to protect their crops â€” which require just the right altitude and temperature and the right amounts of rain and sunshine â€” from the effects of global warming. Faced with headaches such as new pests and diseases, and beans rendered inedible from too much sunshine, many small-scale family farmers can no longer rely on coffee production to feed their families, pay for medical care, and send their kids to school. Â¶Experts project that by the middle of this century, climate change could rule out as much as half of the land now used for coffee production worldwide, CBS Newsâ€™ Mark Phillips reported in December.Â¶Warming oceans in 2016 caused the largest die-off of corals ever recorded on Australiaâ€™s Great Barrier Reef, scientists said in November. The reefâ€™s coral cover suffered significant bleaching this year due to the El Nino weather effect and continued climate change.Â¶Coral bleaching occurs when unusual environmental conditions, like increased sea temperatures, result in corals expelling the small algae which normally provide oxygen and nutrients. The loss turns the corals white. Reefs can recover if temperatures drop and the algae resettle, but if not, the corals will die.Â¶This yearâ€™s coral die-off was â€œsubstantially worseâ€ than the previous worst-ever event in 1998, Australian scientists reported. Experts estimate the Great Barrier Reef has lost 50 percent of its coral cover in the past three decades.Â¶A resilient body, the Great Barrier Reef could regain the corals itâ€™s lost, Australian officials said. But even under good conditions, that could take 10 to 15 years, scientists said, and the acceleration of climate change threatens to derail the natural rhythm of loss and recovery.

title: North Pole temperatures climb near melting point this Christmas week
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶Temperatures around the North Pole will almost certainly pass the melting point, 32 degrees Fahrenheit, in the days leading up to Christmas, as global warming wreaks havoc on some of the worldâ€™s coldest and iciest areas, scientists say.Â¶â€œHigh up into the Arctic and close to the North Pole, the temperatures are very, very possibly above freezing,â€ Paul Mayewski, professor at the University of Maineâ€™s Climate Change Institute, told CBS News Wednesday. He called the current temperatures in the Arctic â€œremarkable.â€Â¶The Arctic has seen a dramatic transformation in recent years, with significantly warmer temperatures, lower levels of sea ice, and more open water. In November, the average Arctic sea ice extent â€” the measurement scientists use to represent the area of ocean where there is at least some sea ice â€” was 17.7 percent below the averages from 1981 to 2010, according to NOAA. Thatâ€™s the lowest November extent since the NOAA began keeping records in 1979. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶At the moment, temperatures at the North Pole are about 50 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than normal. Meteorologist Jeff Berardelli of CBS affiliate WPEC explains that â€œessentially a conveyor belt of very warm, most airâ€ is currently pushing north into the Arctic. Â¶The ongoing warming trend is hardly news to people in the region, where Mayewski does field research collecting and analyzing snow samples and ice cores.Â¶â€œFor the people in the Arctic, no one has to tell them an abrupt climate change has hit,â€ Mayewski said. Â¶But, he noted, the same cannot be said for people living farther down in the Northern Hemisphere who are unknowingly experiencing the ripple effects of Arctic warming. Â¶â€œThey assume the Arctic is far away, and they assume, â€˜What impact could this have on us?â€™â€ Mayewski said. Â¶But Arctic warming is directly tied to extreme weather in the Northern Hemisphere, he explained. With the barrier between the cold north and warm south weakening, cold air masses are more easily moving south and warm air masses are more easily moving north, fueling the changes in surface ocean currents that can exacerbate extreme weather events. In addition, as sea ice transforms into open water, that open water absorbs more heat, a cycle of warming that increasing moisture levels and raises the odds of events like floods and droughts throughout the hemisphere. Â¶Mayewski cited a long list of recent extreme weather events in the Northern Hemisphere: the drought in the western United States, the historically cold East Coast winter of 2014, the initially mild winter of 2015-16 that suddenly gave way to record cold temperatures.Â¶â€œAll of this points to instability,â€ he said. Â¶In historical perspective, Arctic warming over the past five years is â€œas fast and as large a magnitudeâ€ as the warming that occurred during the last vestiges of the Ice Age 11,500 years ago â€” the transition that gave birth to our modern climate age, Mayewski said.Â¶The Arcticâ€™s climate system has followed largely linear patterns until now.Â¶â€œWhile none of the global climate models predicted weâ€™d have an Arctic warming so fast, it no less happened. The models are based on input from the last few decades. Weâ€™re experiencing something which is a surprise, a quick change in the climate system,â€ he said, citing the rapid release of greenhouse gases and the hole in the ozone as accelerating factors. Â¶As the Arctic continues to warm, it will release dangerous amounts of the greenhouse gas methane, which absorbs the sunâ€™s heat and further warms the atmosphere. In the first two decades after its release, methane is 84 times more potent than carbon dioxide, according to the Environmental Defense Fund.Â¶Now, with warming well underway in the Arctic, climate scientists stress that the only way to change course is to dramatically mitigate the rise of greenhouse gases worldwide.Â¶â€œThe more we can mitigate now, the better we are,â€ Mayewski said, calling the Paris Agreement on climate change a â€œfantastic start and a very important cornerstone.â€ Â¶President-elect Trump campaigned on the promise to withdraw from the international climate accord.Â¶Earlier this month, Donald Trump said he is â€œopen-mindedâ€ about climate change â€” but added that â€œnobody really knowsâ€ the truth about it, contradicting the near-universal scientific agreement on the issue.Â¶This year from January to November was the warmest such period for the Earth on record, according to NOAA. That follows another record-breaking warm year in 2015.

title: Climate change fingerprints seen on 24 weird weather cases, study says
content: Â¶WASHINGTON, D.C. -- A new scientific report finds man-made climate change played some role in two dozen extreme weather events last year but not in a few other weird weather instances around the world. Â¶An annual report released Thursday by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration found climate change was a factor, however small or large, in 24 of 30 strange weather events. They include 11 cases of high heat, as well as unusual winter sunshine in the United Kingdom, Alaskan wildfires and odd â€œsunny dayâ€ flooding in Miami. Â¶The study documented climate change-goosed weather in Alaska, Washington state, the southeastern United States, Canada, Europe, Australia, China, Japan, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, the western north Pacific cyclone region, India, Pakistan, Egypt, Ethiopia and southern Africa. Â¶â€œIt has to be measureable. It has to be detectable. There has to be evidence for it and thatâ€™s what these papers do,â€ said NOAA scientist Stephanie Herring, co-editor of the report. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In six cases -- including cold snaps in the United States and downpours in Nigeria and India -- the scientists could not detect climate changeâ€™s effects. Other scientists, though, disputed that finding for the cold snap that hit the Northeast. Â¶Herring highlighted the Miami flooding in September 2015. Because of rising sea levels and sinking land, extremely high tides flooded the streets with 22 inches of water. Â¶â€œThis one is just very remarkable because truly, not a cloud in the sky, and these types of tidal nuisance flooding events are clearly become more frequent,â€ she said. Â¶The report also found an increase in tropical cyclone activity and strength in the western Pacific can be blamed partly on climate change and partly on El Nino, the now-gone natural weather phenomenon. But similar storm strengthening hasnâ€™t increased noticeably around the United States yet, said study co-editor Martin Hoerling, a NOAA scientist. Â¶The report was published in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. Using accepted scientific techniques, 116 scientists from around the world calculated whether the odds of the extreme weather events were increased by global warming. They based their calculations on observed data, understanding of the physics of the climate and computer simulations - techniques that the National Academy of Sciences said were valid earlier this year. Â¶Columbia University meteorology professor Adam Sobel, who was on the national academy panel but not part of this report, praised the NOAA study but noted it wasnâ€™t comprehensive. It picked only certain but not all weather extremes to study. Â¶For the February 2015 Northeast cold snap, other scientists have connected the polar vortex pushing south to shrinking ice in the Arctic Ocean. Â¶Judah Cohen, seasonal forecasting chief at Atmospheric Environmental Research in Lexington, Massachusetts, said he even predicted the 2015 polar vortex because of the low sea ice. He said the same thing is happening with the bitter cold hitting the U.S. this week. Â¶NOAAâ€™s Hoerling said the research found a connection between the shrinking ice and the polar vortex but didnâ€™t see one causing the other.

title: A smaller Rudolph? Scientists say reindeer are shrinking
content: Â¶STOCKHOLM -- Reindeer living on the Arctic island of Svalbard are getting smaller â€” and scientists say climate change may be the cause. Â¶Scientists from Britain and Norway have found that adult Svalbard reindeer born in 2010 weigh 12 percent less on average than those born in 1994. Â¶Ecologist Steve Albon of Scotlandâ€™s James Hutton Institute says rising temperatures in the Arctic mean Svalbard is getting more rain, creating a hard ice sheet the islandâ€™s reindeer canâ€™t easily break through to reach food. Â¶Reindeer populations are also increasing due to warmer summers, stoking competition. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Albon says researchers think there is a correlation between rising temperatures and reindeer weight. He says more research is needed to confirm the link. Â¶Their findings were presented Monday at a meeting of the British Ecological Society.

title: Trump's EPA pick Scott Pruitt signals "180-degree shift" for agency
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶The environmental protection movement is bracing for what could be one of its biggest challenges in decades: the nomination of a climate change skeptic and longtime opponent of Environmental Protection Agency regulations to assume leadership of that same agency. Â¶Scott Pruitt, attorney general of the oil and gas-friendly state of Oklahoma, was confirmed as President-elect Trumpâ€™s pick to head the EPA on Wednesday. Â¶â€œQuite clearly, this is a 180-degree shift from where the administration has been on most things environment-related,â€ David Konisky, associate professor at Indiana Universityâ€™s School of Public and Environmental Affairs, told CBS News. Â¶Hamstrung from enacting climate change legislation through Congress, the Obama administration has in recent years relied heavily on the EPA to implement its environmental agenda across the country through enacting regulations and regulatory oversight. Under Pruitt, the agency is poised for major transformation. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Hereâ€™s what you need to know about Trumpâ€™s Cabinet pick:Â¶In an op-ed published earlier this year in The National Review, Scott Pruit argued that global warming is â€œfar from settled,â€ despite the overwhelming consensus among scientists that human activities are behind the accelerated warming of the planet, with consequences ranging from vanishing polar ice to extreme weather patterns worldwide to the loss of coral on the Great Barrier Reef and food supplies for already endangered species. Â¶â€œScientists continue to disagree about the degree and extent of global warming and its connection to the actions of mankind. That debate should be encouraged â€” in classrooms, public forums, and the halls of Congress,â€ Pruitt wrote. He went on: â€œDissent is not a crime.â€Â¶Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, said Wednesday that Pruittâ€™s views â€œcouldnâ€™t make him more out of touch with the American people â€” or reality.â€Â¶Pruittâ€™s future boss is also a climate change skeptic. The president-elect has previously said that he believed climate change was a â€œhoax created by and for the Chinese,â€ though he recently indicated that he was open to rethinking his position. Â¶During his presidential campaign, Mr. Trump pledged to â€œcancelâ€ U.S. involvement in the Paris climate agreement, a landmark global accord that aims to reduce carbon emissions and halt the effects of climate change.Â¶In a statement released by Trumpâ€™s transition team, Pruitt said Americans â€œare tired of seeing billions of dollars drained from our economy due to unnecessary EPA regulations, and I intend to run this agency in a way that fosters both responsible protection of the environment and freedom for American businesses.â€Â¶In Oklahoma, Pruitt established a dedicated â€œfederalism unitâ€ within the Office of the Solicitor General to fight against federal government regulation. Â¶He has led court challenges to the implementation of the Affordable Care Act and the constitutionality of the Dodd-Frank campaign finance law. Pruittâ€™s supporters view him as a champion of fighting overzealous, wasteful government regulation.Â¶Importantly, Pruitt has used his perch as attorney general to sue the EPA multiple times to block what he considers excessive regulation of natural resources. Â¶Under Pruitt, whoâ€™s called himself a â€œleading advocate against the EPAâ€™s activist agenda,â€ federal regulation of the environment could be gutted. Â¶The EPA is designed as a collaborative body, with the work of environmental protection shared between the federal agency and state governments. In essence, the federal government sets standards, in line with the presidentâ€™s environmental agenda, and individual states then implement those standards with oversight from regional offices of the EPA. Â¶Across the country, this model creates huge variability in environmental standards. Some states and some regional offices are aggressive and meticulous in their approaches to environmental protection; others, far less so. The water crisis in Flint, Michigan was caused, in part, by shoddy oversight from the EPAâ€™s regional office tasked with overseeing Flint, according to a state-commissioned report released earlier this year.Â¶Under Pruitt, the EPA will likely devolve more responsibilities to state governments and weaken the EPAâ€™s regional oversight further, adding to the variability that already exists in environmental protection across the country. Â¶â€œIf your goal is making sure everyone has a baseline of environmental protection, that becomes threatened,â€ Konisky said of Pruittâ€™s stance on decentralized regulation. Â¶Like most federal agencies, the EPA is staffed by career public servants who enjoy, to some degree, civil service protections that make layoffs challenging and guarantee some level of consistency from administration to administration. Â¶These staffers represent Pruittâ€™s first hurdle. Â¶â€œ[They] wonâ€™t roll over to an administrator who doesnâ€™t share those principles,â€ Konisky said. â€œThey donâ€™t yield completely to an agenda that they find problematic.â€Â¶What does history teach us? In terms of values and priorities, Pruitt appears closely aligned with 1981-1983 EPA Administrator Anne Gorsuch Burford, who served under President Reagan. A firm believer that the EPA was too big, wasteful and unfriendly to private enterprise, Burford found herself at odds with EPA staff for weakening the agencyâ€™s authority and slashing its budget, as well as for several mismanagement scandals. Eventually â€” having made enemies in her own agency and with both Republicans and Democrats in Congress â€” Burford was forced to resigned. Â¶If Pruitt faces internal opposition, he can easily shift career staff around â€” essentially, removing individuals with different policy views to less influential positions.  Â¶As administrator, Pruitt will also have significant authority to hire like-minded individuals to lead the EPAâ€™s program offices, which oversee areas like chemical safety, pollution prevention, and water safety, and carry out his deregulation agenda. Â¶Environmental groups now enter a new chapter in which they need to play both defense and offense to keep their cause alive, without allies in the executive branch, Konisky said. Â¶Defense will come in the form of efforts to block specific legislation in Congress and to defend existing environmental protections in the courts.Â¶Offense will likely move to another front: winnable battles in green-friendly cities and states, like California.Â¶â€œYouâ€™ll see these groups look to other venues at the state and local level where they can be successful in pushing policy,â€ Konisky said. â€œEnvironmental groups will try to work through the states to achieve new protections where they can.â€

title: Climate change killing Uganda coffee crop and hitting world's poorest hard - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶The nomination of a climate change skeptic to run the Environmental Protection Agency may have renewed old arguments in Washington, but CBS News correspondent Mark Phillips says in Uganda, thereâ€™s no argument. Â¶The facts there are clear, and they affect people in the African country directly. As Phillips discovered, the facts also affect anybody, anywhere who starts their day with a favored hot, brown beverage.Â¶To millions of people, coffee is the other dark liquid that powers the world. But because of the damage being done to the planet by the primary dark liquid, oil, along with other fossil fuels, coffee is in trouble. Â¶So, too, are the farmers who grow it.Â¶High in the mountains of eastern Uganda, coffee is the most important crop grown, but it hasnâ€™t been a good year for harvest.Â¶Anthony and Vincent Khabalaâ€™s family have been growing coffee on their farm about 4,000 feet up the slopes of Mount Elgon for generations. Lately, theyâ€™ve been having problems their family has never encountered before.Â¶It turns out coffee is as fussy as the people who drink it. This Goldilocks of crops likes just the right altitude, the right temperature and the right amount of rain and sunshine -- and all in the right order.Â¶â€œToo much sunshine produces bad fruits,â€ Anthony tells CBS News, and this year, thereâ€™s been too much sunshine on Mount Elgon.Â¶On another farm, Phillips meets another farmer with another problem. Â¶A fine white powder coats parts of Sam Massaâ€™s coffee plants. Itâ€™s produced by the stem-borer beetle, which drills into the plants and, according to Massa, â€œcompletely ruinsâ€ them.Â¶Massa says the warming weather has brought new pests and diseases that used to live down in the valleys, up the hillsides.Â¶â€œTen years back, it was not here,â€ he tells Phillips. But now, â€œmost of the farms have been destroyed completely, totally by this stem borer.â€Â¶Crop yields have been dropping and prices are up by as much as 30-percent in some areas since last year, according to published reports. Â¶More than just the consumerâ€™s morning pick-me-up is threatened here; the farmers are caffeine-dependent for another reason. Â¶From picking the coffee plant berries to processing them to drying and sorting the beans and getting them to market, this is a family business, and every member of the family contributes.Â¶ Cash from the coffee sales provides the only income to pay for school for the kids, and for medical care. Â¶Coffee production supports an estimated 120 million of some of the worldâ€™s poorest people.Â¶But there is an imbalance in the coffee world; the retail end is controlled by big brands, the big global distributers, but much of the production comes from small family-run, almost vegetable-patch sized farms like the ones Phillips toured in Uganda. Â¶If production fails on Mount Elgon, the big boys can simply go elsewhere. The people who depend on those sales for their livelihood, however, canâ€™t go anywhere.Â¶The latest estimates warn climate change may mean as much as half of the land now used for coffee production around the world will no longer be suitable for it by the middle of this century.Â¶For the people who consume coffee, itâ€™s about a drink.Â¶ For the people who produce it, and depend on it, itâ€™s about life.Â¶ The problem isnâ€™t limited to Africa: The same things are happening in Central and South America, and in the new coffee boom areas of Southeast Asia.Â¶One more thing that may be the cruellest cut; the type of coffee plants being hit hardest by the changing conditions, the ones at greatest risk, are the best, most coveted of them all -- the Arabica beans.

title: Weather Channel to Breitbart: Stop using us to mislead public on climate change
author: Shanika Gunaratna
content: Â¶In an unusually direct message, the Weather Channel is taking Breitbart to task for using Weather Channel content to â€œmislead Americansâ€ about climate change.  Â¶â€œThough we would prefer to focus on our usual coverage of weather and climate science, in this case we felt it important to add our two cents,â€ the Weather Channel wrote in a post on its website Tuesday.Â¶It firmly denied a claim that overall global temperatures are declining, an idea promoted by Breitbart and spread widely on social media.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The company was specifically concerned after Breitbart â€” the right-wing opinion website that had been led by President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s chief advisor Steve Bannon â€” used a Weather Channel video clip atop an article that claimed the last three years of weather patterns represent â€œthe final death rattle of the global warming scare.â€ Â¶Breitbart is the primary megaphone of the alt-right, an extreme right-wing movement promoting white nationalism that has gained new national stature with Bannonâ€™s involvement in the Trump campaign and future administration.Â¶The Weather Channel explained that, while Breitbart had the legal right to use its video clip through a content sharing agreement, it did not want to stand idly by without addressing the articleâ€™s specific, erroneous claims. Â¶The Weather Channel outlined multiple examples of Breitbart â€œcherry picking, or pulling a single item out of context to build a misleading case.â€Â¶For instance, Breitbartâ€™s article claimed that â€œglobal land temperatures have plummeted by one degree Celsius since the middle of this year â€” the biggest and steepest fall on record.â€Â¶The Weather Channel pointed out that this characterization is based only on one satellite estimate of temperatures over land in the lower atmosphere. Â¶â€œTemperatures over land give an incomplete picture of global-scale temperature,â€ the Weather Channel responded. â€œMost of the planet â€” about 70 percent â€” is covered by water, and the land surface warms and cools more quickly than the ocean. Land-plus-ocean data from the other two satellite groups, released after the Breitbart article, show that Earthâ€™s lower atmosphere actually set a record high in November 2016.â€Â¶Warming ocean temperatures, in particular, are a concern as scientists predict melting polar ice could lead to catastrophic sea level rise.Â¶The weather experts also disputed Breitbartâ€™s claim that any recent warming was simply the result of El NiÃ±o. â€œNOAA data show ... El NiÃ±o clearly added to the strength of the record global warmth observed since late 2015. However, if the El NiÃ±o spike is removed, 2016 is still the warmest year on record and 2015 the second warmest.â€Â¶This Breitbart article gained even more attention after it was shared on social media by the U.S. House Committee on Science, Space and Technology last week. The committee, led by Republican Rep. Lamar Smith of Texas, has 180,000 followers on Twitter and has opposed the Obama administrationâ€™s efforts to regulate the gas, oil and coal industries and reduce carbon emissions.Â¶New research suggests that the world is not only breaking heat records, but breaking heat records at a faster and faster pace due to man-made climate change. If greenhouse gas emissions continue at their current pace, there will be about 15 new heat records for every cold record 50 years from now, according to a study published last month in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.Â¶The Weather Channel ended its note with a direct plea to Breitbart: â€œThe next time you write a climate change article and need fact checking help, please call. Weâ€™re here for you. Iâ€™m sure we both agree this topic is too important to get wrong.â€

title: Polar ice the size of India has melted into the sea, scientists say
content: Â¶As global temperatures continue to rise and break records, polar sea ice covering an area about the size of India has vanished, according to climate scientists. The trend of polar ice melt has been alarming researchers, with sea ice in the Arctic and Antarctica being measured at record lows for this time of year, Reuters reports. Â¶â€œThere are some really crazy things going on,â€ Mark Serreze, director of the U.S. National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) in Boulder, Colorado, told the news service. Â¶Serreze said temperatures in regions of the Arctic, for instance, were 36 degrees Fahrenheit above average on some days last month. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Beyond that, the NSIDC satellite measurements show that on Dec. 4, the extent of polar sea ice was 1.48 million square miles below the 1981-2010 average. That amounts to about the size of India, or for another point of reference, two Alaskas. Â¶The latest measurements appear to reverse a trend of expanding Antarctic sea ice, which some skeptics cited to contradict evidence of climate change.Â¶A number of factors may be contributing, including warmer waters in the Pacific from this yearâ€™s El Nino weather event, the report said. Â¶Scientists say man-made global warming also played a major role.Â¶This of course has been viewed as a major global crisis for world leaders. With last yearâ€™s Paris climate agreement, nearly 200 governments agreed to curb carbon emissions with the goal of keeping the worldâ€™s temperature increase to no more than 2 degrees Celsius above the global average temperature before the Industrial Revolution. Â¶It remains unclear whether the U.S. commitment to that deal will be honored by President-elect Donald Trump, who has previously called climate change a â€œhoaxâ€ and stated he might want to pull out of the Paris agreement. Mr. Trump backtracked somewhat in November, telling the New York Times that he has an â€œopen mindâ€ when it comes to climate change.Â¶Mr. Trump and Ivanka Trump held meetings with Al Gore Monday at Trump Tower to discuss the issue of climate change. Gore characterized his talk with the president-elect as â€œvery productiveâ€ and â€œa sincere search for areas of common ground.â€Â¶Those meetings came as Antarcticaâ€™s sea ice measured 4.33 million square miles â€” its smallest for early December, effectively beating 1982â€™s record, NSIDC reports. Similarly, sea ice in the Arctic, though expanding for the winter, hit a record low of 3.96 million square miles this season, below 2006â€™s record.Â¶All of this is â€œan extraordinary departure from the norm,â€ Anders Levermann, a professor at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, told Reuters.Â¶Scientists worry that these developments could have a domino effect. As sea ice melts, glaciers could collapse more quickly into their surrounding waters, potentially increasing the rate of sea level rise rapidly.

title: Australia considers new price tag on pollution
content: Â¶CANBERRA, Australia â€” Australia will consider making electrical power companies pay for greenhouse gas pollution they create, three years after the government scrapped the national carbon tax, a Cabinet minister said Monday.Â¶The conservative government rejected all polluter-pays options in 2014 when it repealed Australiaâ€™s 3-year-old carbon tax levied against the nationâ€™s biggest industrial polluters.Â¶But Environment and Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg said that charging power generators fueled by coal and natural gas for their pollution was under consideration as the government looks for ways to achieve its carbon gas reduction targets.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶He said while his government rejected the previous center-left Labor Party governmentâ€™s policy of charging all major industrial polluters, the electricity industry produced a third of Australiaâ€™s greenhouse gases and could face its own charges.Â¶The new scheme could include international trade in carbon credits, he said.Â¶â€œHow we do we meet our emissions reduction targets while at the same time keeping electricity affordable and the lights effectively on? Thatâ€™s our target,â€ Frydenberg told Australian Broadcasting Corp.Â¶The government on Monday released details of its climate change policy review which will begin in February. Australia has pledged to reduce its carbon emissions by at least 26 percent below 2005 levels by 2030.Â¶The government replaced the carbon tax with a 2.55 billion Australian dollar ($1.9 billion) fund paid by taxpayers to give incentives to polluters to reduce their emissions. Only AU $400 million is left, Frydenberg said.Â¶Environmentalist John Connor, chief executive of the Australian Climate Institute, said the fund could not achieve Australiaâ€™s reduction target.Â¶Australia is among the worldâ€™s worst greenhouse gas polluters on a per capita basis because of its heavy reliance on abundant reserves of cheap coal for electricity generation.

title: "Extreme" downpours could become much more common
content: Â¶Extreme downpours â€” like those that flooded Louisiana, Houston and West Virginia earlier this year â€” will happen nearly three times as often in the United States by the end of the century, and six times more frequently in parts of the Mississippi Delta, according to a new study.Â¶Scientists have long pointed out that warmer air holds more moisture, so man-made climate change will increase the frequency of extreme downpours. That increase has already started, they say, but new work with much stronger computer simulations shows just how bad it will get, and where.Â¶The high-resolution computer simulation â€” about 25 times better than other computer models â€” projects at least a fivefold increase in downpours in the Gulf Coast, Atlantic Coast and Southwest, according to a study in Monday's journal Nature Climate Change.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Study lead author Andreas Prein, a scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research, said the entire U.S. will average a 180 percent increase in these types of downpours by 2100. The Midwest and parts of the West Coast are expected to see the smallest increases.Â¶Previous projections haven't been as detailed because they could not take into consideration small scale weather events like thunderstorms. The new computer simulations can, Prein said. He looked at the type of thunderstorms that are in the top one half of 1 percent of rainmakers.Â¶"It's much more likely that you'll get hit by very strong thunderstorms, very strong downpours in the future climate," Prein said. "What this means in the future is you might have a much higher potential for flash floods. This can have really big impacts."Â¶Outside experts praised the study.Â¶"The paper elegantly shows why these heavy downpours increase in frequency when the air is moist but decrease when the air is dry," said Stanford University climate scientist Chris Field. "With high warming through the century, this paper projects that most of the U.S. (gets) scary increases in the frequency of downpours."

title: California's next global warming target: dairy cows
content: Â¶GALT, Calif. â€” California is taking its fight against global warming to the farm. The nationâ€™s leading agricultural state is now targeting greenhouse gases produced by dairy cows and other livestock.Â¶Despite strong opposition from farmers, Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation in September that for the first time regulates heat-trapping gases from livestock operations and landfills.Â¶Cattle and other farm animals are major sources of methane, a greenhouse gas many times more potent than carbon dioxide as a heat-trapping gas. Methane is released when they belch, pass gas and make manure.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œIf we can reduce emissions of methane, we can really help to slow global warming,â€ said Ryan McCarthy, a science advisor for the California Air Resources Board, which is drawing up rules to implement the new law.Â¶Livestock are responsible for 14.5 percent of human-induced greenhouse gas emissions, with beef and dairy production accounting for the bulk of it, according to a 2013 United Nations report.Â¶Since the passage of its landmark global warming law in 2006, California has been reducing carbon emissions from cars, trucks, homes and factories, while boosting production of renewable energy.Â¶In the nationâ€™s largest milk-producing state, the new law requires dairies and other livestock operations to reduce methane emissions 40 percent below 2013 levels by 2030. State officials are developing the regulations, which take effect in 2024.Â¶â€œWe expect that this package ... and everything weâ€™re doing on climate, does show an effective model forward for others,â€ McCarthy said.Â¶But dairy farmers say the new regulations will drive up costs when theyâ€™re already struggling with five years of drought, low milk prices and rising labor costs. Theyâ€™re also concerned about a newly signed law that will boost overtime pay for farmworkers.Â¶â€œIt just makes it more challenging. Weâ€™re continuing to lose dairies. Dairies are moving out of state to places where these costs donâ€™t exist,â€ said Paul Sousa, director of environmental services for Western United Dairymen.Â¶The dairy industry could be forced to move production to states and countries with fewer regulations, leading to higher emissions globally, Sousa said.Â¶â€œWe think itâ€™s very foolish for the state of California to be taking this position,â€ said Rob Vandenheuvel, general manager for the Milk Producers Council. â€œA single state like California is not going to make a meaningful impact on the climate.â€Â¶Regulators are looking for ways to reduce so-called enteric emissions â€” methane from the bodily functions of cows. That could eventually require changes to what cattle eat.Â¶But the biggest target is dairy manure, which accounts for about a quarter of the stateâ€™s methane emissions.Â¶State regulators want more farmers to reduce emissions with methane digesters, which capture methane from manure in large storage tanks and convert the gas into electricity.Â¶The state has set aside $50 million to help dairies set up digesters, but farmers say thatâ€™s not nearly enough to equip the stateâ€™s roughly 1,500 dairies.Â¶New Hope Dairy, which has 1,500 cows in Sacramento County, installed a $4 million methane digester in 2013, thanks to state grants and a partnership with the local utility, which operates the system to generate renewable power for the grid.Â¶But co-owner Arlin Van Groningen, a third-generation farmer, says he couldnâ€™t afford one if he had to buy and run it himself.Â¶â€œThe bottom line is itâ€™s going to negatively impact the economics of the California dairy industry,â€ Van Groningen said of the new law. â€œIn the dairy business, the margins are so slim that something like this will force us out of state.â€Â¶State officials say theyâ€™re committed to making sure the new regulations work for farmers and the environment.Â¶â€œThereâ€™s a real opportunity here to get very significant emissions reductions at fairly low cost, and actually in a way that can bring economic benefits to farmers,â€ Ryan said.

title: Great Barrier Reef hits sad milestone
content: Â¶CANBERRA, Australia â€” Warming oceans this year have caused the largest die-off of corals ever recorded on Australiaâ€™s Great Barrier Reef, scientists said Tuesday.Â¶The worst-affected area is a 400-mile swath in the north of the World Heritage-listed 1,400-mile chain of reefs off Australiaâ€™s northeast coast, said the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies.Â¶The center, based at James Cook University in Queensland state, found during dive surveys in October and November that the swath north of Port Douglas had lost an average of 67 percent of its shallow-water corals in the past nine months.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Farther south, over the vast central and southern regions that cover most of the reef, scientists found a much lower death toll.Â¶The central region lost six percent of bleached coral and the southern region only one percent.Â¶â€œThe mortality weâ€™ve measured along the length of the Great Barrier Reef is incredibly patchy,â€ the centerâ€™s director, Terry Hughes, told reporters. â€œThereâ€™s very severe damage in the northern section of the reef.â€Â¶â€œThe good news is that south of Port Douglas, including the major tourist areas around Cairns and the Whitsundays (Whitsunday Islands), have had relatively low levels of mortality,â€ he added.Â¶The governments of Australia and Queensland will update the UNESCO World Heritage Center this week on progress being made to protect and improve the reef, including their response to coral bleaching.Â¶Providing a status update to the World Heritage Committee was required as part of its decision in June last year not to list the reef as â€œin danger.â€Â¶Federal Minister for the Environment and Energy Josh Frydenberg said Tuesday that the reefâ€™s coral cover had increased by 19 percent in recent years before it suffered a â€œsignificant bleaching eventâ€ this year, caused by the El Nino weather effect and climate change.Â¶â€œWhat that shows is that the Great Barrier Reef is very resilient and quite strong,â€ Frydenbergâ€™s office said in a statement.Â¶The governmentâ€™s plan to spend $1.5 billion over the next decade on improving the reefâ€™s health.Â¶Hughes said the coral death rates in the north would likely make the task of keeping the reef off the â€œin dangerâ€ list much harder.Â¶â€œIn its ongoing dialogue with UNESCO, Australia has said the outstanding universal values of reef are in tact because of the pristine condition of the northern reef. Thatâ€™s simply no longer the case,â€ Hughes said.Â¶Researcher Andrew Baird said the 2016 coral die-off was â€œsubstantially worseâ€ than the previous worst-ever event in 1998.Â¶â€œThe proportion of reefs that were severely affected was much, much higher,â€ Baird said, adding that he did not have precise figures immediately available.Â¶The 1998 event was restricted to in-shore reefs around the Queensland coastal city of Townsville, while the 2016 destruction affected a much larger area, he said.Â¶Scientists expect that the northern region will take at least 10 to 15 years to regain the lost corals. They are concerned that another bleaching event could interrupt that recovery.Â¶There have been three extreme mass bleaching events in 18 years on the reef. In each case, the areas that suffered the worst bleaching were where the water was hottest for the longest period of time.Â¶Reef tourism operator Craig Stephen did not expect the dead coral would diminish visitorsâ€™ experience of one of Australiaâ€™s biggest tourist drawcards.Â¶â€œThe patchiness of the bleaching means that we can still provide our customers with a world-class coral reef experience by taking them to reefs that are still in top condition,â€ Stephen said in a statement.Â¶Graeme Kelleher, who headed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for 16 years, said last week that Australians must not buy the â€œpolitical lieâ€ that they can have the reef as well as major coal mines nearby.Â¶â€œWeâ€™ve lost 50 percent of the coral cover on the Great Barrier Reef in the last 30 years and the main cause of that is the burning of fossil fuel. I sincerely hope UNESCO rejects the claim that the government is doing enough,â€ Kelleher said.

title: Wind turbines face uphill battle in upstate New York
content: Â¶Clean energy and environmental interests usually go hand in hand. But in western New York, they are battling over plans to build dozens of wind turbines that could be among the nationâ€™s tallest, rising 600 feet above the scenic shores of Lake Ontario.Â¶Apex Clean Energyâ€™s proposal to plant 70 propeller turbines amid the farms and towns east of Niagara Falls is still in its early stages, but it has already generated thousands of pages of comments, studies and legal documents considered by state regulators.Â¶Wildlife groups are concerned the turbines could disrupt a major flyway for migrating birds. Local lawmakers worry about flight operations being compromised at a nearby military base. Residents fret about potential health threats from noise, which are still being studied, and say views could be dominated by structures taller than any skyscraper in upstate New York.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œThereâ€™s nothing this size on land,â€ opponent Pam Atwater said of the turbine towers proposed by Apex. â€œWeâ€™re not even really talking about aesthetics or anything like that. But of course itâ€™s going to have an impact. The terrain here is flat. You can see for miles.â€Â¶Itâ€™s a debate playing out as rapidly improving technology for towers and turbines allow the wind industry to move on to increasingly taller structures.Â¶Federal Aviation Administration records show that the vast majority of the hundreds of proposed turbines the agency is reviewing for air safety would stand at or just below 500 feet. But two other projects in New York â€” one in central New York, one in the northeast corner â€” have submitted plans for a combined 70 turbines from 640 to 656 feet tall, and there are several projects with towers topping 600 feet in the works in Texas and Kansas. The tallest towers in the world now top 700 feet and operate offshore in Europe.Â¶Charlottesville, Virginia-based Apex, a major national wind farm developer, said it hasnâ€™t settled precisely on the turbine size for the project named Lighthouse Wind, but noted that taller machines offer greater yield.Â¶â€œCurrently in New York the tallest wind turbine is just under 500 feet,â€ Apex development manager Taylor Quarles told The Associated Press. â€œBut certainly the trend in the industry is to go higher as the consistency and wind speed, essentially the quality of the wind, does tend to increase with elevation.â€Â¶Seventy turbines is the high end of its proposal, he said, and it may require only 50 or 60 of the larger machines to achieve the projectâ€™s goal of generating 201 megawatts of electricity, enough to power 50,000 average New York homes.Â¶â€œThere is this phase where what used to be the offshore type of size is now migrating onshore for more wind resources,â€ said Yates Town Supervisor James Simon, a wind farm opponent. He said that makes people in his community and the neighboring town of Somerset, essentially, â€œguinea pigs.â€Â¶Atwater notes that â€œtheyâ€™re designed for offshore use, so there is no place you can go and no one who can tell you what the impactâ€™s going to be.â€Â¶Retired truck driver Howard Pierce, whose home in Yates is across a street from one boundary of the project, said he isnâ€™t worried about environmental issues as much as the payments landowners will get for leasing to Apex.Â¶â€œThe No. 1 industry in our town is farming, and the wind farm would give these farmers a steady income every year,â€ Pierce said. â€œThis would not depend on the commodity prices.â€Â¶The project is one of the first tests of a new state regulatory regime, known as â€œArticle 10â€ for the 2011 law that took the power to approve major energy projects out of the hands of a mix of local and state authorities and gave it to a single state authority, the Board on Electric Generation Siting and the Environment. There is not yet a timetable for when the panel will make a decision.Â¶Gov. Andrew Cuomo has set a goal of meeting half the stateâ€™s energy needs from renewable sources by 2030. One of the challenges to that goal has been a lull in wind projects since 2013. Installed capacity grew in leaps from 2000 to 2012 and then stalled, with almost no new capacity added in recent years, according to federal Department of Energy statistics.Â¶That has opponents worried the process will be biased toward approving the project.Â¶Republican Assemblyman Steve Hawley, who opposed Article 10 and Lighthouse Wind, is giving the process a chance.Â¶â€œIâ€™m going to trust that theyâ€™re going to take, not with a grain of salt, not in one ear and out the other, but seriously take the localsâ€™ concerns into consideration,â€ he said.

title: The problem with Donald Trump's stance on global warming
author: Laura Geggel
content: Â¶Is there reason to doubt climate change because some of the nationâ€™s hottest days happened in 1898, as President-elect Donald Trump told the New York Times in an interview Tuesday?Â¶In an exchange with Times publisher Arthur Sulzberger Jr. and staff about climate change on Tuesday (Nov. 22), Trump said, â€œI have an open mind to it,â€ but later added, â€œYou know the hottest day ever was in 1890-something, 98. You know, you can make lots of cases for different views.â€Â¶However, itâ€™s misleading to single out a weather event â€” such as a particularly hot day in 1898 â€” as evidence for or against climate change, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrationâ€™s National Ocean Service (NOS). [The Reality of Climate Change: 10 Myths Busted]Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œWeather is what you see outside on any particular day,â€ the NOS reports. â€œSo, for example, it may be 75 degrees and sunny or it could be 20 degrees with heavy snow.â€Â¶In contrast, climate is an average of weather over time. â€œFor example, you can expect snow in the Northeast in January, or for it to be hot and humid in the Southeast in July,â€ the NOS said.Â¶Extreme values, such as record rainfall or record high and low temperatures, are known as climate records because they stand out in a long period of time, the agency added.Â¶In 1898, both Oregon and Maryland reached their highest temperatures on record: 119 degrees Fahrenheit (66 degrees Celsius) in Oregon and 109 F (60.5 C) in Maryland, according to The Weather Channel. But these record-hot temperatures are simply climate records in two states, not evidence for widespread climate change, according to experts.Â¶Rather, looking at the climate for an extended period of time gives researchers a better idea about the direction the climate is heading. For instance, 2016 is expected to be the hottest year on record by a significant margin, with world temperatures an average of 2.2 F (1.2 C) above preindustrial levels, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said, as reported by Climate Central.Â¶Moreover, 2011 to 2015 is the hottest five-year period on record, according to a separate WMO report released this month, according to Climate Central. When 2016 officially becomes the hottest year on record, 16 of the 17 hottest years will have happened since 2000, with the El NiÃ±o year of 1998 being the only exception, Climate Central reported.Â¶Ninety-seven percent of climate scientists agree that this rapid warming is not due to natural causes, but due primarily to the result of human activity, according to NASA.Â¶These increasing temperatures are â€œconsistent with our expectations for the response of the climate system to increases in greenhouse gases,â€ Jennifer Francis, a research professor in the Department of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers University in New Jersey, told Live Science last week.Â¶During the interview with Trump, Sulzberger also conflated a single weather event â€” Hurricane Sandy, which slammed the Caribbean and the East Coast of the United States in 2012 â€” with climate change, saying, â€œWell, since weâ€™re living on an island, sir, I want to thank you for having an open mind. We saw what these storms are now doing, right? Weâ€™ve seen it personally. Straight up.â€Â¶However, there is debate about whether Hurricane Sandy was a consequence of climate change.
