In general, scientists are hesitant to say that climate change caused the 2012 hurricane, but some say that climate change contributed to it, Live Science reported in 2012.Â¶For instance, warm oceans and moist air give strength to existing hurricanes, Kevin Trenberth, a distinguished senior scientist in the Climate Analysis Section at the National Center for Atmospheric Research, told Live Science.Â¶Moreover, itâ€™s possible that future flood-causing surges from hurricanes and other storms will be more severe as climate change causes sea levels to rise, according to study published in October in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.Â¶Original article on Live Science.

title: Heat records have become the new normal
content: Â¶WASHINGTON â€” The United States is already setting twice as many daily heat records as cold records, and a new study predicts that will get a lot more lopsided as man-made climate change worsens.Â¶Under normal conditions, without extra heat-trapping gases from human activity, the nation should set about the same number of hot and cold records over the course of several years. But thatâ€™s not happening and itâ€™s steadily getting worse, scientists said.Â¶If and when the nation warms another 4.5 degrees, expect there to be around 15 heat records for every cold one, the new study in Mondayâ€™s Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences predicts. That warming can be as early as 50 years from now if greenhouse gas emissions - from the burning of coal, oil and gas - continue at their recent pace or a century away if carbon pollution slows down, said study lead author Gerald Meehl, senior scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œThis climate is on a trajectory that goes somewhere weâ€™ve never been. And records are a very easy measure of that,â€ said study co-author Claudia Tebaldi, whoâ€™s also at the atmospheric center in Boulder, Colorado.Â¶They used records from the nationâ€™s weather stations for their statistical calculations.Â¶After an earlier study in 2009, Meehl and Tebaldi looked further in the past and into the future. In the Dust Bowl hot 1930s, there were 1.1 hot records for every cold. After a couple decades of more cold records and an even one-to-one ratio in the 1980s, the number of high heat marks left cold in the dust.Â¶So far in the 2010s there have been 2.2 hot records for every cold, including six hot records for every cold this year, Meehl said.Â¶Looking at records is important because people donâ€™t feel shifts in average temperature, but they do notice shifts in extremes like this, Meehl said.Â¶â€œThese results are not surprising,â€ University of Georgia meteorology professor Marshall Shepherd said in an email. â€œAnd it further points to the notion that â€˜extremesâ€™ not averages get our attention. In life we get alarmed when we have a fever, not when our temperature is near the 98.6 average. We are setting Earth on course for high fever events to be quite common.â€

title: Fight against climate change runs into cold hard reality
content: Â¶JAENSCHWALDE, Germany â€” Amid whiffs of chemicals and the electric hum of transformers, Kraftwerk Jaenschwalde rises like an ash-colored fortress over a landscape disfigured by decades of open-pit coal mining.Â¶The communist-era colossus in eastern Germany is one of Europeâ€™s dirtiest power plants, belching 24 million tons of climate-warming carbon dioxide into the air every year.Â¶It could have been closed for good when former owner Vattenfall, a Swedish utility, decided to get rid of its coal assets in Germany to reduce its carbon footprint. But as local officials point out, the lignite industry employs thousands in this region and together with hard coal accounts for more than 40 percent of Germanyâ€™s power production.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶â€œThis is the reason why you canâ€™t shut down a coal mine or power plant from one day to another,â€ plant spokesman Thoralf Schirmer says.Â¶That the fight against climate change ran into that cold hard reality here in the heart of Europe â€” the worldâ€™s climate leader â€” shows how challenging itâ€™s going to be to keep the global temperature rise â€œwell belowâ€ 2 degrees Celsius, as agreed in last yearâ€™s Paris emissions pact.Â¶A growing body of evidence suggests that the power plants, buildings, cars, trucks, ships and planes in use today are likely to emit enough CO2 over their lifetime for the world to miss that target. Coal plants alone could blow the carbon budget for 1.5 degrees C of warming, the lower threshold also mentioned in the agreement, unless they are shut down early.Â¶â€œFor 1.5 degrees we would have to start retiring things like crazy and we wouldnâ€™t be able to build anything new,â€ says University of California, Irvine, scientist Steven Davis. â€œTwo degrees is starting to look equally bleak.â€Â¶That hasnâ€™t quite sunk in amid the fanfare surrounding the Paris Agreement, which entered into force with record pace.Â¶Temperatures have already risen by about 1 degree C since the industrial revolution, when countries started burning fossil fuels for energy.Â¶In 2010 Davis and others estimated that the worldâ€™s existing energy infrastructure had locked in 496 billion tons of CO2 emissions if left to operate for their expected lifetime. By 2013, as hundreds of additional power plants had come online in Asia, the number rose to 729 billion tons.Â¶â€œBy my latest calculations, weâ€™re close to 800 billion tons now,â€ Davis says.Â¶Thatâ€™s roughly whatâ€™s remaining of the so-called carbon budget for 2 degrees, according to recent estimates based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changeâ€™s latest assessment.Â¶That budget is significantly lower for 1.5 degrees. Joeri Rogelj of the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Laxenburg, Austria, estimated that itâ€™s 150 billion tons or somewhat higher, while researchers at the Climate Interactive group said itâ€™s about 210 billion tons.Â¶There is uncertainty surrounding the estimates partly because itâ€™s unclear exactly how sensitive the climate system is to increases in atmospheric CO2 levels.Â¶Davisâ€™ research shows that, assuming an average lifespan of 40 years, the worldâ€™s coal-fired power plants will emit 280 billion tons of CO2, exceeding the budget for 1.5 degrees. And that doesnâ€™t even count the hundreds more that are under construction or on the drawing board, primarily in China and other Asian countries.Â¶â€œThose things wouldnâ€™t be able to operate over their normal 30, 40 year lifespan,â€ says Davis. â€œInstead theyâ€™d need to be closed down after 10 or 15 years. And so itâ€™s a matter of paying for that. Thatâ€™s a lot of life in those power plants that weâ€™d basically have to throw away.â€Â¶This is happening in some places like the United States where coal plants are being shut down because of competition from natural gas, which is cheaper and has lower emissions. But not fast enough to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement, as globally more coal plants are built every year than are retired, according to a report this year by environmental groups CoalSwarm, Greenpeace and the Sierra Club.Â¶The report said there are 7,273 operating coal plants around the world this year, with 719 under construction and more than 1,000 in the planning stages.Â¶At U.N. climate talks in Morocco this week, governments and clean energy advocates noted that the worldâ€™s transition toward a low-carbon economy is well underway, with renewable sources like wind and solar expanding quickly.Â¶But global energy demand is also growing, meaning renewables are adding power capacity rather than replacing existing capacity from fossil fuels, said Glen Peters of the Center for International Climate and Environmental Research in Oslo.Â¶â€œThere is a bit of displacement going on in U.S. and in China,â€ he said. â€œBut for emissions to go down you need to not build any more fossil (fuel) infrastructure. And to go down faster you would have to close down existing infrastructure.â€Â¶Very few of the scientific projections count on countries retiring fossil fuels fast enough to meet the Paris targets. Instead they assume the world will find a way to suck vast quantities of CO2 from the atmosphere in the latter half of the century.Â¶The story of Jaenschwalde helps explain why. When Vattenfall, which is owned by the Swedish government, decided to offload its coal plants and mines in Germany, it came under pressure from environmentalists to decommission them instead. But that would have been â€œfinancially burdensome,â€ says Vattenfall CEO Magnus Hall.Â¶â€œSo we decided to divest it,â€ he says, adding that what to do with them is a question for the German government and people.Â¶Environmental groups protested the sale of the mines and plants to Czech investors, saying this just means their carbon footprint is passed on to someone else.Â¶But there was no appetite among German decision-makers for closing down the lignite industry, which employs 8,000 people in the eastern Lausitz region bordering Poland.Â¶The new Czech owners are considering expanding the mines, saying Germanyâ€™s decision to phase out nuclear power means the demand for lignite power â€œwill remain stable.â€Â¶Thatâ€™s encouraging to Schirmer, a bookish man with a purple scarf. On the other side of the border, he says, Poland is planning to open new lignite mines, meaning Germany could end up importing electricity generated from Polish coal if it shuts down its own mines.Â¶He agrees that Germany needs to go â€œ100 percent renewables,â€ but thatâ€™s still â€œa long way awayâ€ because until energy storage makes a quantum leap, coal power will be needed on days when thereâ€™s no wind or sunshine.Â¶â€œIt wouldnâ€™t be wise to sink the ship,â€ he says, â€œbefore you even have seen land.â€

title: Climate Diaries: Drought threatening African mountain gorillas - CBS News
author: CBS News
content:
Â¶VOLCANO NATIONAL PARK, Rwanda -- Thereâ€™s a population on the slopes of these volcanic peaks in central Africa that knows nothing of arguments in Washington about climate change.Â¶But the famous â€œgorillas in the mistâ€ do know something is going on.  Â¶They know the bamboo shoots that make up a major part of their diet, and which used to sprout like clockwork, are now less predictable. Â¶The rains that produce them were a month late this year. The gorillas have had to adapt their roaming and foraging patterns because the old seasonal rhythms of food production have altered. Their world is changing.Â¶
                                                            Conservation tourism is a lifeline for the critically endangered mountain gorillas in Rwanda's Volcanoes National Park
                                                    Â¶The gorillasâ€™ problems are made worse by the troubles of their distant cousins and close neighbors: people. Â¶Since the late rains have also made the water supply down in the valleys less reliable, local villagers have been going up into gorilla country, where theyâ€™re not supposed to go, to bring that good mountain water home.Â¶And park ranger Abel Musana says water isnâ€™t the only thing the people are after during the drought. Â¶â€œThe harvest will be impacted and the people are coming to invade the habitat, which is for gorillas,â€ Musana said.Â¶When the people are low on food, they go into the park looking for it.Â¶The human population has ballooned in the areas surrounding the park. According to David Greer of the World Wildlife Fundâ€™s great apes program, when those people are forced up into the mountains they bring disease and other dangers with them.Â¶â€œThey have to enter the park to access this clean water. And in the meantime they might want to set a snare for catching an ungulate for food,â€ Greer said, referring to a class of mammals that includes antelopes and other local fauna.Â¶But on some occasions, a gorilla can become ensnared in those same traps.Â¶Thatâ€™s what happened to one gorilla, filmed by a â€œ60 Minutesâ€ team a few months ago. The snare was removed by one of the vets whose work has actually helped the ape population increase lately.Â¶Still, there are only about 880 mountain gorillas left in the world, confined to the mountain tops across Uganda, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Rwanda. Theyâ€™re already considered critically endangered. And as their world changes, they have nowhere to go.

title: France: U.S. must respect "irreversible" climate deal
content: Â¶MARRAKECH, Morocco -- French President Francois Hollande on Tuesday urged the United States to respect the â€œirreversibleâ€ Paris Agreement on climate change, and said France will lead a dialogue on the topic with President-elect Donald Trump â€œon behalf of the 100 countries that have ratifiedâ€ the deal.Â¶Speaking to a U.N. climate conference in Morocco, Hollande praised President Barack Obama for his role in getting the landmark deal adopted by more than 190 countries in the French capital last year.Â¶â€œThe United States, the most powerful economy in the world, the second-largest emitter of greenhouse gases, must respect the commitments that were made,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s not simply their duty, itâ€™s in their interest.â€Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Scientists say oil and other fossil fuels are the biggest contributors to man-made warming. Trump, however, has called global warming a â€œhoaxâ€ and pledged during his campaign to â€œcancelâ€ the Paris deal.Â¶Earlier, U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said he hopes Trump will shift his course on global warming and â€œunderstand the seriousness and urgencyâ€ of addressing the problem.Â¶â€œAs president of the United States, Iâ€™m sure that he will understand this, he will listen and he will evaluate his campaign remarks,â€ Ban told reporters in Marrakech.Â¶The Paris Agreement was signed by more than 190 countries and has been formally approved by more than 100 of them, including the United States and even oil-rich Saudi Arabia.Â¶Ban called international climate action â€œunstoppableâ€ and said that no country, â€œhowever resourceful or powerful,â€ is immune from the impacts of global warming.Â¶â€œWe have no right to gamble with the fate of future generations â€” or imperil the survival of other species that share our planet,â€ Ban told the conference.Â¶Trumpâ€™s election has created uncertainty about the U.S. role in the Paris deal, which calls on all countries to reduce or curb their greenhouse gas emissions and encourages rich countries to help poor ones deal with climate change.Â¶King Mohammed VI of Morocco urged delegates at the conference to translate their commitments into actions.Â¶â€œWhatâ€™s at stake is the very existence of man,â€ the king said. â€œIt is therefore our joint duty to work hand in hand to protect humanity.â€

title: 2016 set to break heat record despite slowdown in emissions
content: Â¶MARRAKECH, Morocco -- Global temperatures are soaring toward a record high this year, the U.N. weather agency said Monday, while another report showed emissions of a key global warming gas have flattened out in the past three years.Â¶The reports injected a mix of gloom and hope at U.N. climate talks in Marrakech this week.Â¶â€œAnother year. Another record. The high temperatures we saw in 2015 are set to be beaten in 2016,â€ said Petteri Taalas, the head of the World Meteorological Organization.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶WMOâ€™s preliminary data through October showed world temperatures, boosted by the El NiÃ±o phenomenon, are 1.2 degrees Celsius (2.2 degrees Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial levels.Â¶Thatâ€™s getting close to the limit set by the global climate agreement adopted in Paris last year. It calls for limiting the temperature rise since the industrial revolution to 2 degrees C or even 1.5 degrees C.Â¶WMO said 16 of the 17 hottest years have occurred this century. The only exception was 1998, which was also an El Nino year.Â¶Taalas said parts of Arctic Russia saw temperatures soaring 6-7 degrees C above average. â€œWe are used to measuring temperature records in fractions of a degree, and so this is different,â€ he said.Â¶Environmental groups and climate scientists said the report underscores the need to quickly reduce the emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases blamed for warming the planet.Â¶Another report released Monday delivered some positive news, showing global CO2 emissions have flattened out in the past three years. However, the authors of the study cautioned itâ€™s unclear whether the slowdown, mainly caused by declining coal use in China, is a permanent trend or a temporary blip.Â¶â€œIt is far too early to proclaim we have reached a peak,â€ said co-author Glen Peters, a senior researcher at the Center for International Climate and Environmental Research in Oslo.Â¶The study, published in the journal Earth System Science Data, says global CO2 emissions from fossil fuels and industry is projected to grow by just 0.2 percent this year.Â¶That would mean emissions have leveled off at about 36 billion metric tons in the past three years even though the world economy has expanded, suggesting the historical bonds between economic gains and emissions growth may have been severed.Â¶â€œThis could be the turning point we have hoped for,â€ said David Ray, a professor of carbon management at the University of Edinburgh, who was not involved with the study. â€œTo tackle climate change those bonds must be broken and here we have the first signs that they are at least starting to loosen.â€Â¶Chinese emissions were down 0.7 percent in 2015 and are projected to fall 0.5 percent in 2016, the researchers said, though noting that Chinese energy statistics have been plagued by inconsistencies.Â¶Peters said it remains unclear whether the Chinese slowdown was due to a restructuring of the economy or a sign of economic instability, but the unexpected reduction in Chinese emissions â€œgive us hope that the worldâ€™s biggest emitter can deliver much more ambitious emission reductions.â€Â¶China, which accounts for almost 30 percent of global carbon emissions, pledged to peak its emissions around 2030 as part of the global climate pact adopted in Paris last year. Many analysts say Chinaâ€™s peak is likely to come much earlier â€” and may already have occurred.Â¶â€œThe continued decline of Chinaâ€™s CO2 emissions, combined with knowledge of structural change in the energy system, does indicate that CO2 emissions from China may have peaked, however a few more years of data is needed to confirm this,â€ said Bill Hare, of Climate Analytics, a separate group that monitors global emissions.Â¶Even if Chinaâ€™s emissions have stabilized, growth in India and other developing countries could push global emissions higher again. Indiaâ€™s emissions rose 5 percent in 2015, the study said.Â¶The election of Donald Trump as president of the United States â€” the worldâ€™s No. 2 carbon polluter â€” could also have an impact.Â¶U.S. emissions fell 2.6 percent last year and are projected to drop 1.7 percent this year, as natural gas and renewables displace coal in power generation, the study showed. But itâ€™s unclear whether those reductions will continue under Trump, who has pledged to roll back the Obama administrationâ€™s environmental policies, including the Clean Power Plan to reduce carbon pollution from power plants.Â¶Other researchers not affiliated with the study stressed that itâ€™s not enough for global emissions to stabilize; they need to drop toward zero for the world to meet the goals of the Paris deal.Â¶â€œWorryingly, the reductions pledged by the nations under the Paris Agreement are not sufficient to achieve this,â€ said climate scientist Chris Rapley of University College London.

title: Supermoon elevates flooding in South Florida - CBS News
author: CBS News
content: Â¶The extra-bright â€œsupermoonâ€ has been lighting up the sky all over the world. The full moon is currently the closest it has been to Earth since 1948, and will reach the peak of its full phase at 8:52 a.m. Eastern. Â¶But the supermoonâ€™s stronger gravitational pull is amplifying the seasonal â€œking tide,â€ and creating heightened flood risks in places like South Florida.Â¶In Fort Lauderdale, king tides happen once or twice a year, bringing seawater into low-lying neighborhoods. While the supermoon is making this tide more extreme, flooding has become a persistent problem throughout South Florida, leading to aggressive and expensive solutions.Â¶On  South Bayshore Lane in Coconut Grove, the bay came ashore at high tide Sunday night, with six inches of water in the street. Â¶â€œBy 2030, we expect up to another six inches of sea level rise to occur,â€ Dr. Tiffany Troxler, director of Florida International Universityâ€™s Sea Level Solutions Center, told correspondent David Begnaud. â€œWe might see another six inches on top of this.â€Â¶With rising sea levels, seasonal king tides are swamping storefronts and submerging city streets.  But scientists say this monthâ€™s flooding is expected to be even worse, thanks to the so-called supermoon -- when the moon is closer to the Earth than normal. Â¶â€œThat additional gravitational pull has caused our high tides to be a little bit higher than they would have been without that supermoon,â€ Dr. Troxler said. Â¶Infrastructure director Ray Coley, who manages the waterway and sewer systems in Miami Beach, said, â€œWeâ€™re at the point that the waters are rising high enough that itâ€™s interfering with public safety.â€Â¶Scientists say flooding incidents in Miami Beach have increased at least 400 percent in the last 10 years. Â¶â€œA year ago, we were having to close the road twice a day because the water was about a foot taller than the ground,â€ said Coley. â€œIf we have to close this road, that affects our police, our fire, our ambulance service.â€Â¶If Miami Beachâ€™s sea level were to rise just two feet, the area would undergo a radical transformation. Â¶Desperate times lead to desperate measures: The city is spending at least $400 million trying to keep the tourist mecca higher and drier.  Â¶Fifty temporary pump stations have been installed, and more permanent ones are on the way, similar to those in New Orleans. And Miami Beach is actually raising the city streets and elevating flood walls.  Â¶Dr. Troxler says this has gone beyond a debate over climate change.Â¶â€œWhatâ€™s happening is that we have sea level rising in our neighborhoods and we need to do something about it now,â€ she told Begnaud. Â¶Most people in Fort Lauderdale live about five feet above sea level. According to one study, South Florida could see a six-inch increase in sea level by 2030 -- four years before the next supermoon.

title: Secretary of State John Kerry lands in Antarctica, with climate legacy under threat
content: Â¶MCMURDO STATION, Antarctica â€” U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry became the highest-ranking American official to visit Antarctica on Friday when he landed for a two-day trip during which heâ€™ll hear from scientists about the impact of climate change on the frozen continent.Â¶Kerry left from New Zealand after being held up for about a day by bad weather. Kerry and his entourage left the Christchurch airport at 6 a.m. aboard a C-17 Globemaster military cargo plane and landed in Antarctica about 11 a.m.Â¶Kerry, an experienced pilot, spent much of the flight in the cockpit of the huge jet, chatting with the pilots. After a smooth trip of about five hours, the group landed on the Pegasus Ice Runway, the strip of ice that serves McMurdo. The large base is the hub for U.S. operations.Â¶Kerry made no public remarks on the initial leg of the trip. In Christchurch a day earlier, he congratulated President-elect Donald Trump for winning a â€œmomentous electionâ€ and said he had reminded State Department staff of the â€œtime-honored tradition of a very peaceful and constructive transfer of power.â€Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In Antarctica, Kerryâ€™s plans called for his entourage to transfer immediately at the airstrip to a smaller military transport plane for a three-hour flight to the research station the U.S. government operates near the South Pole. Kerry planned to visit that station for about two hours before returning to McMurdo for the night.Â¶Kerryâ€™s aides described the trip as a learning opportunity for the secretary of state. He planned to receive briefings from scientists working to understand the effects of climate change on Antarctica. Kerry has made climate change an intensive focus of American diplomacy during his term, and had previously spent decades working on the issue as a U.S. senator.Â¶However, that legacy could be less lasting than he might have hoped, if the Trump administration moves to pull out of the Paris Agreement on reducing emissions and climate change, which the U.S. and more than 100 other countries signed onto last year.Â¶Trump has also vowed to reverse Obama administration environmental policies encouraging clean energy.Â¶Kerry planned to return to New Zealand on Saturday for meetings with Prime Minister John Key. He plans to fly next week to the Middle East for talks, and then onward to a global climate conference in Morocco, where he will give a major speech.

title: Trump likely to take aim at Obama environment initiatives
content: Â¶GAINESVILLE, Fla. -- President-elect Donald Trump has not minced words about his approach to environment and energy policy: He loathes regulation and wants to increase the use of coal, offshore drilling and fracking.Â¶Trump has said he believes climate change is a hoax and that he would â€œcancelâ€ U.S. involvement in the landmark Paris Agreement on global warming.Â¶While heâ€™s been vague about precise policies, Trumpâ€™s election likely means trouble for some of President Barack Obamaâ€™s signature environmental initiatives, environmentalists and policy analysts say.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In a signal of how he plans to approach the issue as president, Trump has selected a skeptic of climate change to lead his Environmental Protection Agency transition team.Â¶Myron Ebell of the Competitive Enterprise Instituteâ€™s (CEI) is also viewed by many as a top candidate to become the next head of the EPA. Ebellâ€™s research focuses on questioning what he calls â€œglobal warming alarmismâ€ and opposing energy rationing policies, according to his biography on CEIâ€™s website.Â¶Analysts say itâ€™s probable that Trumpâ€™s administration will seek to weaken or kill the Clean Power Plan, a cornerstone Obama policy meant to reduce carbon pollution from the nationâ€™s power plants as part of an effort to combat climate change.Â¶The Clean Power Plan is being challenged in federal court, and if it survives, Trump could move to scuttle it. But not without a fight.Â¶â€œWe donâ€™t consider the CPP dead. We have many tools to help preserve it,â€ said David Goldston, director of government affairs for the Natural Resources Defense Council. â€œHe canâ€™t just snap his fingers and wish away regulations. Thereâ€™d be a backlash, which would make Congress think twice.â€Â¶Any move to back out of the Clean Power Plan or the Paris Agreement could be extremely unpopular moves, environmentalists argue. Polls have shown a majority of voters in at least two states surveyed believe global warming is a serious problem.Â¶An exit poll conducted for The Associated Press and television networks found that about half of Trump voters in Florida, a state he carried, agreed that climate change was a serious problem. In Maine, just over half of Trump supporters also agreed, while about four in 10 disagreed.Â¶Trump also has vowed to tap into Americaâ€™s coal reserves in an effort to put the shrinking energy sector back to work. In a speech in the Bakken shale fields of North Dakota, he also said he would increase hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, in the nationâ€™s shale and natural gas reserves to further remove any dependence on foreign energy sources.Â¶Industry advocates are buoyed by the possibilities presented by Trumpâ€™s win.Â¶â€œWe look forward to working with the new administrationâ€ on issues such as opening more public land and offshore areas to oil and gas drilling, building more energy infrastructure and reducing environmental regulations, American Petroleum Institute President Jack Gerard said Thursday. He would not say whether he supported a U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement.Â¶Likewise, the coal industry believes Trump â€œunderstands the urgent need to rein in the Washington bureaucracy and sweeping, excessive regulationsâ€ to protect coal jobs in an industry where sharply falling demand for coal has led to permanent plant closures, the American Coal Council said.Â¶â€œThe coal sector has been devastated by lower demand and job loss in recent years due to the mounting impact of regulations pointed squarely at our industry,â€ American Coal Council CEO Betsy Monseu said.Â¶Some question whether it would make economic sense for the U.S. to attempt to increase the use of coal, a fuel being phased out of the energy picture due to its pollution and falling prices of renewables such as solar and wind.Â¶â€œCoal is not coming back,â€ said Michael Brune, Sierra Club executive director. â€œAsk investors on Wall Street, or regulators at the state and local level who are choosing solar and wind because of basic economics.â€Â¶As for offshore drilling, Trump could target the Atlantic and Arctic: two areas the Obama administration had made off-limits for oil leases in the immediate future. While the Obama administration has moved to restrict drilling in waters off the Eastern Seaboard and Alaska, Trump has been vague on whether he would support reopening these areas to drilling, saying he backs it when it â€œcan be done responsibly.â€Â¶Environmentalists said Wednesday they hope Trump concludes opening the Atlantic and Arctic to offshore drilling is a bad business decision.Â¶â€œIn the Atlantic, we hope he will recognize the strong opposition from the business community, which has mounted a concerted campaign to protect its fishing and tourism industries against the interest of the oil industry,â€ said Jacqueline Savitz of Oceana, a group opposed to offshore drilling. â€œIn the Arctic, itâ€™s impossible to respond to an oil spill, with extreme cold, floating ice, darkness much of the year and no response facilities.â€Â¶Concerns over the incoming administrationâ€™s environmental approach were not confined to policy.Â¶Some climate scientists expressed concern that the Trump administration could reduce governmentâ€™s efforts to study climate change. For example, some Republicans have long wanted to stop NASAâ€™s role in studying earth science and climate change â€” a key contribution to scientific understanding of the issue that helps drive policy decisions.Â¶Waleed Abdalati, a former NASA chief scientist, said in an email that the agencyâ€™s contributions are extremely important to the nationâ€™s success.Â¶â€œPart of this investment includes trying to better understand how and why our environment is changing and the implications for the American people, as well as people all over the world,â€ Abdalati wrote. â€œNo one can argue that there is tremendous value in knowing what tomorrow will bring.â€

title: Climate change denier is leading Trump's EPA transition team
author: Julia Boccagno
content: Â¶President-elect Donald Trump has selected a climate skeptic to lead his Environmental Protection Agency transition team, a man whose beliefs are distinctly at odds with President Obamaâ€™s environmental policies.Â¶The Competitive Enterprise Instituteâ€™s (CEI) Myron Ebell is also viewed by many as a top candidate to become the next head of the EPA. Ebellâ€™s research focuses on questioning what he calls â€œglobal warming alarmismâ€ and opposing energy rationing policies, according to his biography on CEIâ€™s website.Â¶In 2012, Ebell, in a Frontline documentary entitled â€œClimate of Doubt,â€  described former Vice President Al Gore as â€œthe perfect proponent and leader of the global warming alarmist because heâ€™s very politically diverse and controversial.â€ Gore, after a failed presidential bid, emerged as one of the leading climate change activists for his role in the documentary â€œAn Inconvenient Truth.â€ He had already written about the environment in his book, â€œEarth in the Balance.â€Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Ebell and other climate change deniers have collectively described the â€œglobal warming consensusâ€ as â€œphony.â€ Â¶â€œWe believed that the so-called global warming consensus was not based on science, but was a political consensus, which included a number of scientists,â€ he said.Â¶Ebellâ€™s environmental ideology aligns with beliefs held by the president-elect. Trump has referred to climate change as a â€œhoax.â€ And his â€œAmerica Firstâ€ vision on energy and climate change includes revitalizing the coal industry, lifting regulations on oil and gas industries, as well as nullifying the international landmark agreement dedicated to halting the effects of climate change because theyâ€™re â€œbad for US business.â€Â¶The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive.Â¶Not only are wind farms disgusting looking, but even worse they are bad for people's health http://t.co/2G8YrOUZ (cont) http://t.co/NujHgnXUÂ¶Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, who is a big proponent of oil and gas exploration (remember â€œDrill, baby, drill?â€), has also been floated for a cabinet position, Politico reported, saying that she could be in the running for Interior secretary.Â¶In September, hundreds of scientists and members of the National Academy of Sciences signed an open letter warning the public of Trumpâ€™s harmful environmental policies. A Trump presidency, the letter read, â€œwould make it far more difficult to develop effective global strategies for mitigating and adapting to climate change,â€ adding that the consequences would be â€œsevere and long-lastingâ€ for Americaâ€™s international credibility and for the planet.

title: Record-hot temperatures of 2015 could soon be the new normal
author: Brian Mastroianni
content: Â¶In less than a decade, the record-breaking hot temperatures weâ€™ve seen lately may have become the â€œnew normalâ€ around the world, climate scientists say. New research predicts that the unusually warm temperatures that made 2015 the hottest year on record by a wide margin will be standard by 2025 if carbon emissions continue to increase at their current rate.Â¶The research was published in the Bulletin of American Meteorological Society. Â¶â€œIf we continue with business-as-usual emissions, extreme seasons will inevitably become the norm within decades and Australia will be the canary in the coal mine that will experience this change first,â€ lead author Dr. Sophie Lewis, from the Australian National University hub of the ARC Centre of Excellence for Climate System Science (ARCCSS), said in a press release. Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The climate trends outlined in the report look worrisome. Lewis said that regardless of whatever actions we take to curb emissions today, the planet was already locked into a pattern of rising temperatures. That being said, the researchers believe that if aggressive action was taken now, record-breaking seasons could be stopped from becoming the norm, at least at the regional level. Â¶If not, summers in some areas could become unbearable within decades.Â¶â€œThat means the record hot summer of 2013 in Australia â€” when we saw temperatures approaching 50Â°C [122Â° Fahrenheit] in parts of Australia, bush fires striking the Blue Mountains in October, major impacts to our health and infrastructure and a summer that was so hot it became known as the â€˜angry summerâ€™ â€” could be just another average summer season by 2035,â€ Lewis said. Â¶However, she added, that fate could still be avoided â€œif we reduce emissions drastically to the lowest pathway recommended by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changeâ€ â€” a U.N.-sponsored panel of experts which has developed a plan to keep global temperature increases below 2 degrees Celsius (3.6Â°F) by the end of the century.Â¶What exactly would it mean to establish a â€œnew normal?â€ Lewis and her team developed a definition which specifies this would occur when â€œat least half of the years following a record year were cooler and half warmer.â€Â¶The researchers then used a supercomputer that ran climate models to project when a â€œnew normalâ€ would occur based on four different scenarios laid out by the U.N. panel, depending on how much carbon emissions were reduced.Â¶Following this, they looked at seasonal temperatures from December to February throughout Europe, Asia, Australia, and North America. Global average temperatures would hit this â€œnew normalâ€ designation when the climate models were put through all four carbon emission scenarios. This was not the case on a smaller scale when it came to seasonal and regional levels.Â¶Lewis said that if we took strong steps to reduce greenhouse gases globally, seasonal extremes â€œmight never enter a new normal state in the 21st century at regional levels for the Southern Hemisphere summer and Northern Hemisphere winter.â€Â¶She used Australiaâ€™s â€œangry summerâ€ of 2013 as a cautionary tale. Â¶â€œIf If we donâ€™t act quickly Australiaâ€™s â€˜angry summerâ€™ of 2013 may soon be regarded as mild,â€ she added. â€œImagine for a moment, if a summer season like 2013 became average. The likely impacts of an extremely hot year in 2035 would beyond anything our society has experienced.â€

title: Trump win raises questions about UN climate deal
content: Â¶MARRAKECH, Morocco -- The election of a U.S. president who has called global warming a â€œhoaxâ€ alarmed environmentalists and climate scientists Wednesday and raised questions about whether America, once again, would pull out of an international climate deal.Â¶Many said itâ€™s now up to the rest of the world to lead efforts to rein in greenhouse gas emissions, while others held out hope that Donald Trump would change his stance and honor U.S. commitments under last yearâ€™s landmark Paris Agreement.Â¶â€œNow that the election campaign has passed and the realities of leadership settle in, I expect he will realize that climate change is a threat to his people and to whole countries which share seas with the U.S., including my own,â€ said Marshall Islands President Hilda Heine.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Small island nations which fear they will be swallowed by rising seas are among the biggest supporters of the Paris deal and other international efforts to curb emissions, mainly from fossil fuels.Â¶More than 100 countries, including the U.S., have formally joined the agreement, which seeks to reduce emissions and help vulnerable countries adapt to rising seas, intensifying heat waves, the spreading of deserts and other climate changes.Â¶â€œIâ€™m sure that the rest of the world will continue to work on it,â€ Moroccan chief negotiator Aziz Mekouar said at U.N. climate talks in Marrakech.Â¶Many environmentalists and scientists werenâ€™t so sure.Â¶â€œThe Paris Agreement and any U.S. leadership in international climate progress is dead,â€ said Dana Fisher, director of the Program for Society and the Environment at the University of Maryland. However, the transition toward cleaner energy is so entrenched in the U.S. it would continue without federal money, she added.Â¶The U.S. under the Bush administration declined to join the previous climate deal, the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, which greatly reduced its impact on global emissions. But President Barack Obama made climate change a priority and was instrumental in making the Paris Agreement come together.Â¶Trump pledged in May to â€œcancelâ€ the Paris deal.Â¶In a signal of how he plans to approach the issue as president, Trump has selected a skeptic of climate change to lead his Environmental Protection Agency transition team.Â¶Myron Ebell of the Competitive Enterprise Instituteâ€™s (CEI) is also viewed by many as a top candidate to become the next head of the EPA. Ebellâ€™s research focuses on questioning what he calls â€œglobal warming alarmismâ€ and opposing energy rationing policies, according to his biography on CEIâ€™s website.Â¶On the campaign trail, Trump called for stripping regulations to allow unfettered production of fossil fuels â€” a key source of emissions â€” and rescinding the Clean Power Plan, an Obama administration strategy to fight climate change.Â¶In May, Trump told an oil and gas conference in North Dakota he would â€œsave the coal industryâ€ and stop all payments of U.S. tax dollars to global warming programs.Â¶â€œTrump will try and slam the brakes on climate action, which means we need to throw all of our weight on the accelerator,â€ said May Boeve, leader of the 350.org environmental group.Â¶The pro-fossil fuels American Energy Alliance said Trumpâ€™s victory presents a chance to reset â€œharmful energy policiesâ€ in the United States.Â¶â€œHe has laid out an energy plan that puts the needs of American families and workers first,â€ the groupâ€™s president, Thomas Pyle, said.Â¶While shell-shocked American climate activists in Marrakech cried and embraced, U.S. negotiators declined to speak to reporters about the electionâ€™s outcome.Â¶However, before the two-week conference, U.S. officials said they expect other countries to stay the course irrespective of what Washington decides, because they see it is in their national interests.Â¶Li Shuo, a climate policy expert at Greenpeace in China, said his nation â€” the worldâ€™s top polluter â€” would continue to work on climate change â€œout of its own very genuine concern on air pollution, water pollution and food security.â€Â¶The withdrawal process would take four years â€” an entire presidential term â€” under the terms of the agreement. However, Trump could also decide to simply ignore the Obama administrationâ€™s Paris pledge to reduce U.S. emissions by 26-28 percent from 2005 levels by 2025. The pledges are self-determined, and there is no punishment for countries that miss their targets.Â¶Alden Meyer of the Union of Concerned Scientists, a veteran U.S. observer of the climate talks, said he hopes Trump will adopt a more â€œresponsibleâ€ view in office.Â¶â€œEven he does not have the power to amend and change the laws of physics, to stop the impacts of climate change, to stop the rising sea levels,â€ Meyer said.Â¶Several analyses have shown that the world is not on track to keep the global temperature rise below 2 degrees C (3.6 degrees F) compared with preindustrial times, the goal of the Paris Agreement. Temperatures have already gone up by half that amount.Â¶Many climate scientists who feel countries arenâ€™t doing enough to reduce emissions were dismayed by the Trumpâ€™s victory.Â¶â€œCan the world do climate stewardship without the U.S.? It has to,â€ said Jason Box, a glacier expert at the Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland.Â¶Among the minority of researchers who disagree that global warming is a major threat, Trumpâ€™s win sparked hopes that a new administration would somehow change the way science looks at the issue.Â¶â€œExpect some long-awaited, rigorous examination of the theory/models,â€ John Christy, of the University of Alabama, Huntsville, wrote in an email. â€œThe danger just isnâ€™t there.â€

title: October temperatures in the U.S. were warmest in decades
author: Brian Mastroianni
content: Â¶In a continuing trend of record or near-record-breaking temperatures, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) reports that the U.S. experienced its third-warmest October ever this year. Last month was the warmest October since 1963.Â¶Last month saw an average U.S. temperature of 57.7 degrees Fahrenheit, which was 3.6 degrees above the 20th century average, according to NOAA. This news might have a familiar ring to it. Each of the last three Octobers were among the six warmest in the 122-year period of official temperature record-keeping. Â¶Notably, this is also the second-warmest year on record so far, with the year-to-date average temperature for the contiguous U.S. measuring 57.8 degrees Fahrenheit, which is about 2.8 degrees above average. Â¶NOAA reports that those in the Pacific Northwest and the coastal southeast have experienced wet conditions during this exceptionally warm year, while the interior southeast experienced intensifying drought throughout October.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Which areas experienced the most extreme temperature increases? NOAA found that the â€œyearâ€™s most profound warmthâ€ in the U.S. has occurred in usually chilly Alaska. Alaskaâ€™s year-to-date temperature was 6.7 degrees above the average, measuring at 36.3 degrees Fahrenheit. That breaks an Alaska record set way back in the January-October period of 1926. Â¶The temperature shifts in Alaska are another sign of climate change thatâ€™s been bringing significant disruption to the state.Â¶North and South Carolina also set temperature records for the year to date.Â¶In all, NOAA says 37 states experienced one of their five warmest January-October periods in the record books.

title: Amid election uncertainty, UN vows progress on climate deal
content: Â¶MARRAKECH, Morocco â€” Climate negotiators started work Monday on implementing the Paris Agreement on global warming amid uncertainty over how the U.S. election will impact the landmark deal as temperatures and greenhouse gases soar to new heights.Â¶U.N. climate chief Patricia Espinosa told delegates in the rain-soaked Moroccan city of Marrakech that â€œno politician or citizen, no business manager or investorâ€ can doubt that the world is determined to shift toward a â€œlow-emission, resilient society.â€Â¶So far, 100 countries have formally joined the agreement adopted last year in Paris, including top polluters China, the United States, the European Union and India.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶However, U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has said he would â€œcancelâ€ the deal if he wins the election this week. His opponent, Hillary Clinton, backs the climate policies of President Barack Obamaâ€™s government.Â¶The upcoming election seemed to be on everyoneâ€™s mind at the start of the two-week conference in Marrakech, where even security guards at the sprawling conference center were overheard discussing the potential implications for the world and efforts to fight climate change in particular.Â¶â€œTrump becoming President? I personally donâ€™t have problem with it. But what does the guy want to do?â€ said Adjo Bokon, a delegate from the West African nation of Togo. â€œIs he conscious of what is going on with climate change?â€Â¶Gabriela Fischerova, a Slovak official representing the European Union, said the 28-nation bloc is â€œopen to any result. We will continue our discussions with any administration that will be in place.â€Â¶The Paris Agreement marks the first time all countries have pledged to fight global warming by curbing the rise in greenhouse gas emissions, primarily carbon dioxide from fossil fuels.Â¶The U.N. says global emissions rise every year, reaching 52.7 billion tons in 2014, primarily driven by the rapid expansion of China, India and other Asian economies.Â¶Meanwhile, global average temperatures keep hitting new records. Last year was the hottest since reliable record-keeping began in the 19th century and this year is expected to be even hotter.Â¶On a per-capita basis, rich countries like the United States, Australia and oil-rich Gulf nations, have the highest emissions.Â¶â€œThe wealthiest countries live as if there were three planets,â€ said French Environment Minister Segolene Royal. Meanwhile, poor countries in Africa who have contributed very little to the problem are suffering the consequences with fertile land turning into desert, she said.Â¶Delegates will meet for two weeks in the Moroccan city to work on the rules for implementing the Paris deal, including how to measure and report emissions so that countries can be held accountable.Â¶The goal of the agreement is to keep the global temperature rise below 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) compared with pre-industrial times, and â€œpursue effortsâ€ to try to hold it to 1.5 degrees Celsius.Â¶The lower threshold was introduced on demand from vulnerable countries such as low-lying island nations who fear they will be washed away by rising seas as global warming melts glaciers and ice sheets.Â¶Temperatures have already risen about 1 degree C (1.8 degrees F) since the industrial revolution and analyses of the emissions cuts that countries have pledged so far show they put the world on a path to about 3 degrees C (5.4 degrees F) of warming.Â¶â€œDecisions made in the next few years will largely determine if weâ€™re able to achieve the 1.5 C warming threshold agreed in Paris,â€ said Manuel Pulgar-Vidal, Peruâ€™s former environment minister who now leads environmental group WWF Internationalâ€™s work on climate change. â€œOr if we take the unthinkable option of blowing right past it.â€

title: Paris climate deal goes into effect sooner than expected
content: Â¶STOCKHOLM â€” The Paris Agreement on climate change enters into force Friday â€“ faster than anyone had anticipated â€“ after a year with remarkable success in international efforts to slash man-made emissions of carbon dioxide and other global warming gases.Â¶It means the world has moved a little closer to fixing what scientists say is the root cause of the worldâ€™s rising temperatures.Â¶But only a little.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶In the Paris Agreement, countries agreed to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) and do their best to keep it below 1.5 degrees C (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit), compared with pre-industrial times.Â¶But agreeing on those goals was the easy part. Achieving them will require a transformational shift in our energy system, which despite strong gains by clean energy sources such as wind and solar power still depends on fossil fuels.Â¶Here are some of the things that need to be worked out before the Paris Agreementâ€™s ambitious goals can be met:Â¶First, countries need to specify the rules for transparency and accountability to make sure countries fulfill their commitments.Â¶The wording on that was left vague in the Paris deal, which says all countries must report on their emissions and their efforts the reduce them, but allows for some â€œflexibilityâ€ for developing countries.Â¶That was because China and others insisted on softer requirements for developing countries that donâ€™t have the same capacity to measure and report on emissions as rich nations.Â¶Work on the â€œrulebookâ€ will start at a two-week U.N. climate conference starting Monday in Marrakech, Morocco. U.N. climate chief Patricia Espinosa said Friday that it should be completed by 2018 to ensure that â€œeveryone is involved in the effort and is delivering to the best of their abilities.â€Â¶The science is clear: Even if implemented in full, the emissions reductions that countries pledged for the Paris deal wonâ€™t keep global warming below 2 degrees C. Several independent analyses project warming of around 3 degrees C or more.Â¶To stay within reach of the 2-degree goal, countries will have to find ways of cutting an additional 12 billion to 14 billion metric tons from their annual emissions by 2030, according to a U.N. report released this week.Â¶Thatâ€™s why the Paris deal calls for countries to review their individual emissions targets every five years, to see if they can find ways to achieve deeper cuts as renewable energy technologies become better and cheaper. The first review is set for 2018.Â¶The Paris Agreement deals with emissions after 2020. But climate models show that the worldâ€™s emissions curve needs to stop rising before then or itâ€™s going to be really hard to achieve the 2-degree target and virtually impossible to stay below 1.5 degrees.Â¶Therefore, environmental groups and the most vulnerable countries insist that governments in high-polluting countries must deepen their emissions cuts now â€“ not wait until 2020. So far thatâ€™s not happening.Â¶Money is always at the center of the climate talks. The U.S., Europe and other rich parts of the world have promised to collectively raise $100 billion a year by 2020 in so-called climate finance.Â¶The money is meant to help poorer nations shift from fossil fuels to clean energy and adapt to climate impacts that canâ€™t be avoided, such as rising seas in some places and intensifying heat waves and droughts in others.Â¶Last month the rich countries came up with a â€œroad mapâ€ showing they are on track to reach $100 billion in public and private finance. However, critics said the plan doesnâ€™t make sure that existing development aid wonâ€™t be double counted â€“ a key demand by poor countries.Â¶The â€œroad mapâ€ is likely to be one of the most contentious issues in Marrakech.Â¶Itâ€™s not likely to play a major role in Morocco, but given the gap between where emissions are and where they should be to hit the Paris goals, governments will soon have to start paying serious attention to technologies that remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.Â¶Thatâ€™s known as negative emissions in climate lingo.Â¶Most climate models show negative emissions will be required in the latter half of the century to limit warming to 2 degrees. The technologies exist but itâ€™s unclear whether they can be deployed on the massive scale required to make an impact.Â¶Besides the Paris Agreement, there have been several important developments recently in the fight against climate change, including record growth in renewable energy and the number of electric cars worldwide passing the symbolic milestone of one million. Â¶Also, countries reached a deal on phasing out super-potent greenhouse gases used as coolants for refrigerators and freezers and another on limiting aviation emissions.Â¶But the climate system is hitting its own milestones, raising doubts over whether the 2-degree and 1.5-degree targets are even feasible.Â¶Last year was the hottest on record and this year is expected to be even hotter. Meanwhile, carbon dioxide levels in the Earthâ€™s atmosphere have passed the symbolic level of 400 parts per million, which the U.N. weather agency last week said marks the â€œstart of a new era of climate reality.â€

title: Study: 90 miles in your car melts a foot of Arctic sea ice
content: Â¶WASHINGTON -- Driving a gas-powered car about 90 miles â€“ the distance between New York and Philadelphia â€“ melts about a square foot of Arctic sea ice in the critical month of September, according to a new study that directly links carbon pollution to the amount of ice thatâ€™s thawing.Â¶At current carbon emission levels, the Arctic will likely be free of sea ice in September around mid-century, which could make weather even more extreme and strand some polar animals, a study published Thursday in the journal Science finds.Â¶The study calculates that for every ton of carbon dioxide put in the air, thereâ€™s 29 square feet less of sea ice (for every metric ton, thereâ€™s 3 square meters less) during the crucial month when the Arctic region is least frozen. Using observations, statistics and 30 different computer models, the study authors show heat-trapping gases cause warming and the melting of sea ice in a way that can be translated into a simple mathematical formula.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Thereâ€™s â€œa very clear linear relationshipâ€ between carbon dioxide emissions and sea ice retreat in September, especially at the southern boundary edges, said study lead author Dirk Notz, a climate scientist at Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Germany.Â¶â€œItâ€™s very simple. Those emissions from our tailpipes and our coal-fired power plants are all going into the atmosphere,â€ said study co-author Julienne Stroeve, a climate scientist at both the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Boulder, Colorado, and University College, London. â€œIt just increases the warming at the surface. So the ice is going to respond to that. The only way it can do that is to move further north.â€Â¶Rutgers University marine scientist Jennifer Francis, who wasnâ€™t part of the study, said the link is so clear and direct that â€œwe know beyond a shadow of a doubt that Arctic sea ice is disappearing because of increased carbon dioxide.â€Â¶Stroeve and Notz calculated that the average American each year is responsible for carbon emissions that lead to melting around 538 square feet of September sea ice.Â¶â€œIâ€™ve stood on sea ice many times, and the idea that Iâ€™m responsible for 500 square feet of its destruction each year is devastating,â€ University of Washington climate scientist Cecilia Bitz, who wasnâ€™t part of the study but also praised it, said in an email. â€œThat is the size of my front yard!â€Â¶On average, each September, thereâ€™s about 33,670 square miles less Arctic sea ice than the year before, although it varies year to year, according to a 37-year trend line calculated by the National Snow and Ice Data Center.Â¶From 1979 to 2000, the lowest sea ice amount of the year averaged about 2.6 million square miles, but this year it was down to the second lowest ever, 1.6 million square miles. Thatâ€™s a loss about the size of the United States east of the Mississippi River.Â¶Sea ice does build back up over the winter even with man-made warming, although this year Arctic sea ice level set a record low for October. The study focuses on late summer minimum levels, which is what most affects animals and climate further south, Notz and Stroeve said.Â¶Notz and Stroeve calculated that if people put 1,000 billion more metric tons of carbon dioxide in the air, the Arctic will be free of sea ice for pretty much the entire month of September. At the current rate, that means in about 29 years, the Arctic will be ice free during that month.Â¶An increasing number of studies find a connection between shrinking sea ice in the Arctic and extreme weather, including the wandering polar vortex that brings frigid air south in the winter.Â¶â€œItâ€™s not just that we care about polar bears and walruses,â€ Stroeve said. â€œWe all depend on the ice being there for the climate to be the way it is.â€

title: Global warming could turn southern Spain into a desert
content: Â¶BERLIN â€” Southern Spain will become desert and deciduous forests will vanish from much of the Mediterranean basin unless global warming is reined in sharply, according to a study released Thursday.Â¶Researchers used historical data and computer models to forecast the likely impact of climate change on the Mediterranean region, based on the targets for limiting global warming 195 countries agreed to during a summit in France last year.Â¶â€œThe Paris Agreement says itâ€™s necessary to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit), if possible 1.5 degrees,â€ Joel Guiot, a researcher at the National Center of Scientific Research in France who co-wrote the study, said. â€œThat doesnâ€™t seem much to people, but we wanted to see what the difference would be on a sensitive region like the Mediterranean.â€Â¶The authors examined the environmental changes the Mediterranean has undergone during the last 10,000 years, using pollen records to gauge the effect that temperatures had on plant life.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶They came up with four scenarios pegged to different concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Three of the scenarios are already widely used by scientists to model future climate change, while the fourth was designed to predict what would happen if global warming remains at or below 1.5 degrees Celsius this century.Â¶The fourth scenario is particularly ambitious because average global temperatures have already risen by 1 degree Celsius since pre-industrial times. It is, however, the only one under which Mediterranean basin ecosystems would remain within the range of changes seen in the past 10,000 years, the researchers found.Â¶At the other extreme â€“ the scenario in which global warming hits 2 degrees â€“ deserts would expand in Spain, North Africa and the Near East, while vegetation in the region would undergo a significant change from the coasts right up to the mountains, the study states.Â¶The region is considered a hotspot for biodiversity and its landscape also has long been cultivated by humans, making it a particularly interesting case study for the researchers, whose work was published online in the journal Science.Â¶â€œClimate has always been important there,â€ said Guiot, noting that numerous civilizations â€“ from the ancient Egyptians to the Greeks and the Romans â€“ emerged around the Mediterranean over the past millennia.Â¶While their demise probably resulted from social and political changes, climate conditions may have played a role in the past and could do so again in the future, he said.Â¶Current flows of migrants are being driven largely by political unrest, but prolonged periods of drought could spark mass migrations of people due to climate change, Guiot said.Â¶The researchers acknowledged that their study did not factor in the environmental impact of human activity in the Mediterranean basin. Some areas already are experiencing severe water shortages made worse by intensive agriculture and tree clearance.Â¶â€œIf anything, human action will exacerbate what the study projects, and it could turn out to be too optimistic,â€ Guiot said.Â¶The Paris climate agreement comes into effect next week.

title: UN: Heat-trapping gas surges beyond milestone
content: Â¶The World Meteorological Organization says heat-trapping gases in Earthâ€™s atmosphere are growing faster than before, surging permanently beyond a troubling milestone.Â¶The United Nations agency says global carbon dioxide levels, which first reached 400 parts per million last year, are likely to stay above that symbolic 400 milestone all year and for generations to come.Â¶Carbon dioxide levels overall rise because of the burning of fossil fuels; they also fluctuate seasonally, peaking in May and dipping in September. Last monthâ€™s average level at a key Hawaii monitoring station was 401 parts per million, up from 313 in 1958.Â¶U.N. spokesman Stephane Dujarric said Monday that the rise was fueled by El NiÃ±o, a weather pattern caused by the warming of the Pacific Ocean. El NiÃ±o leads to droughts in tropical regions and reduces the capacity of forests and oceans to absorb carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas blamed for global warming.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶Methane and other heat-trapping gases are also spiking. The WMO issues its annual greenhouse gas bulletin, using public data, before international climate talks.

title: Where Trump and Clinton stand on climate change
author: Brian Mastroianni
content: Â¶The third and final presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Wednesday night in Las Vegas covered a wide range of issues from abortion to foreign policy to the national debt, but there was one glaring omission â€” climate change. Â¶Six months after world leaders signed the Paris Agreement, a sweeping accord designed to combat global warming, climate change was only brought up tangentially, in one brief moment, on the debate stage. It was mentioned early on as â€œa real issueâ€ by Clinton in her answer to an unrelated question. Other than that, moderator Chris Wallace, of Fox News, did not pose any questions about climate policy and neither of the candidates brought up specific proposals about how they would handle the challenges it presents â€” despite this being a year of record-breaking temperatures, drought, and destructive storms. Â¶On social media, some observers decried the absence of climate change discussion at any of this yearâ€™s debates. Paul Krugman of the New York Times called the oversight â€œreally disgraceful.â€Â¶So, four debates; four shout-outs by moderators to deficit scolds; not one question about climate change. It's really disgraceful.Â¶We're at the final question of the last debate and climate change has not come up in a serious way once. Criminal negligence. #debatenightÂ¶Itâ€™s been 8 years since a debate question about climate change.Â¶This is bigger than individual moderators. @debates needs new leadership.Â¶Not a single presidential #debate asked a question about #climatechange, which touches all parts of running our country. Disgusting.Â¶Oddly enough, the closest question to touch on the issue of climate change came from the red sweater-wearing, meme-worthy audience member Ken Bone at the second presidential debate. An undecided voter, Bone asked the candidates, â€œWhat steps will your energy policy take to meet our energy needs while at the same time remaining environmentally friendly and minimizing job layoffs?â€Â¶More in Campaign 2016Â¶In response, Trump said: â€œI will bring our energy companies back ... Theyâ€™ll pay off our national debt. Theyâ€™ll pay off our tremendous budget deficits, which are tremendous. But we are putting our energy companies out of business. We have to bring back our workers.â€ Â¶Clinton specifically used the term â€œclimate changeâ€ in her answer: â€œSo I have a comprehensive energy policy, but it really does include fighting climate change, because I think that is a serious problem,â€ she said. â€œAnd I support moving toward more clean, renewable energy as quickly as we can, because I think we can be the 21st century clean energy superpower and create millions of new jobs and businesses.â€Â¶Beyond that exchange, climate change has largely been left out of discussion.Â¶So, with less than three weeks to go until Election Day, where do the two candidates stand on climate change? Hereâ€™s an overview:Â¶Back in a January interview with Fox News, before he clinched the Republican nomination, Trump said, â€œClimate change is just a very, very expensive form of tax. A lot of people are making a lot of money. I know much about climate change.â€ Â¶He added, â€œI often joke that this is done for the benefit of China â€” obviously I joke â€” but this is done for the benefit of China.â€ Â¶On his official campaign website, Trump does not have a section focused on climate change listed under â€œPositions.â€ There is, however, a section on the candidateâ€™s energy policy.Â¶The Trump campaign website says the presidential hopeful will â€œmake America energy independent, create millions of new jobs, and protect clean air and clean water.â€ Â¶It says he â€œwill conserve our natural habitats, reserves and resources,â€ and â€œwill unleash an energy revolution that will bring vast new wealth to our country.â€Â¶Trumpâ€™s team writes that his administration would â€œrescind all job-destroying Obama executive actions,â€ including that â€œMr. Trump will reduce and eliminate all barriers to responsible energy production, creating at least a half million jobs a year, $30 billion in higher wages and cheaper energy.â€Â¶The word climate change appears nowhere on the page.Â¶Trump has previously suggested he considers global warming a hoax â€œcreated by and for the Chinese,â€ as he put it in an oft-referenced 2012 tweet. Â¶The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive.Â¶In March he also told The Washington Post that he is â€œnot a big believer in man-made climate change.â€ Â¶But despite his public skepticism, Trump applied for a permit to build a seawall next to his golf course and hotel in County Clare, Ireland, to prevent erosion, according to a Politico report from earlier this year. In his application, he included an environmental impact statement that mentions â€œglobal warming and its effects.â€ Â¶Trumpâ€™s stance on climate change would make him unique among world leaders if elected. A study from The Sierra Club that compiled statements from leaders of 195 countries found that Trump would be the only head of state to declare climate change a hoax. Â¶â€œI believe in science. I believe that climate change is real and that we can save our planet while creating millions of good-paying clean energy jobs,â€ Clinton said during her acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention in July. Â¶On her official campaign website, Clinton has a section devoted to climate change under â€œIssues.â€ On the page, the campaign writes, â€œClimate change is an urgent threat and a defining challenge of our time. It threatens our economy, our national security, and our childrenâ€™s health and futures.â€ Â¶The page also states that the former secretary of state will â€œdeliver on the pledge President Obama made at the Paris climate conferenceâ€ and will not rely on â€œclimate deniers in Congress to pass new legislation.â€ Her campaign says a Clinton administration would aim to â€œreduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 30 percent in 2025 relative to 2005 levels and put the country on a path to cut emissions more than 80 percent by 2050.â€Â¶Clinton would likely have a lot of high-level help in fulfilling Mr. Obamaâ€™s climate change initiatives, given that one of the key actors on climate in his administration was her own campaign chairman, John Podesta.Â¶Among the policies highlighted on the site, Clinton announces that she will launch a $60 billion â€œClean Energy Challengeâ€ that would partner with rural communities, states, and cities to cut carbon pollution â€œand expand clean energy, including for low-income families.â€ Â¶"I believe that climate change is real and that we can save our planet while creating millions of good-paying clean energy jobs." â€”HillaryÂ¶Clinton supports cutting tax subsidies on oil and gas companies. Â¶The campaign also says she would create an Environmental and Climate Justice Task Force to focus on the â€œhealth, economic, and environmental impacts of pollution and climate change in vulnerable communities.â€

title: Rising seas could threaten $1 billion Air Force radar site
content: Â¶WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- The U.S. Air Force is spending nearly $1 billion to build a radar installation that will help keep astronauts and satellites safe by tracking pieces of space junk as small as a baseball. That is, if global warming doesnâ€™t get in the way.Â¶The Space Fence is being constructed on a tiny atoll in the Marshall Islands that scientists say could be regularly swamped by rising seas within a couple of decades as a result of climate change. The salt water could play havoc with the equipment, the scientists say.Â¶And The Associated Press found that neither the military nor its contractor, Lockheed Martin, gave serious consideration to that threat when designing the installation and choosing a site, despite warnings from the island nationâ€™s environmental agency.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶The future â€œdoes not look good for a lot of these islands,â€ said Curt Storlazzi, an oceanographer with the U.S. Geological Survey who is leading a study at Kwajalein Atoll, where the Space Fence complex is being built.Â¶Dana Whalley, a civilian who is managing the Space Fence program, said that the radar installation has a projected lifespan of 25 years and that he doesnâ€™t expect sea levels to rise enough over that period to cause a problem. But if necessary, he said, the base could take steps to improve its seawalls.Â¶Still, because of budget pressures, military equipment is often used well beyond its projected lifespan. In fact, a key part of the radar tracking system that the Space Fence replaces was built during the dawn of the space age and was badly outdated by the time it was shut down 50 years later in 2013.Â¶Midway between Hawaii and Australia, the Marshall Islands are specks of land that typically poke just a few feet above the Pacific Ocean, making them some of the worldâ€™s most vulnerable places to rising seas.Â¶The U.S. military has a longstanding connection to the islands. Bikini Atoll was used as a nuclear test site after World War II. Kwajalein Atoll, a battle site during the war, is now an Army base, a ballistic missile test site and an important part of the militaryâ€™s space surveillance network.Â¶The growing problem of space debris was highlighted in 2009, when an old Russian satellite smashed into a commercial U.S. satellite, creating hundreds of pieces of orbiting junk. The 2013 movie â€œGravityâ€ dramatized the threat to astronauts, who need to be safe from debris whether theyâ€™re traveling on the International Space Station or in a rocket.Â¶Lockheed Martin won the $915 million Space Fence contract in 2014 and broke ground last year. When the radar system becomes operational in late 2018, it should increase the number of objects that can be tracked tenfold to about 200,000 and provide more precise information on their orbits.Â¶The Space Fence installation will include digital transmitters and receivers as well as power and cooling facilities. About 15 people will operate and maintain it around the clock.Â¶The military chose the Marshall Islands because the Space Fence works best near the equator. But it means the installation is being built just 10 feet above sea level, or the height of a basketball hoop.Â¶Storlazzi said his study explored the point at which storms will cause the sea to wash clear across an island, completely submerging it, at least once a year. He said thatâ€™s when an island will no longer be able to sustain most plant or animal life.Â¶He examined one island within Kwajalein Atoll and found that it will probably reach its tipping point within a few decades. He said the island on which the Space Fence is being built faces a similar threat.Â¶The flooding there will probably damage power cables, sewer lines and other electronics and hardware, he said. The seawater will erode land, he said, and eat away at everything from concrete to cars.Â¶â€œWhen you get to the point where water is going over the top of the island annually, it will affect a lot of daily life, whether itâ€™s related to the Space Fence or other operations, like moving food around,â€ he said.Â¶The study, funded primarily by the Defense Department, has not yet been peer-reviewed or published. But it paints a much more dire future for the atoll than earlier studies.Â¶â€œWe are talking the next couple of decades, not centuries, as previously thought,â€ Storlazzi said.Â¶He said his team studied the underwater contours of the islands and showed how coral reefs will become less effective as breakwaters when sea levels rise.Â¶The Marshall Islands base is among dozens of U.S. military sites threatened by climate change. A July report by the Union of Concerned Scientists analyzed 18 military installations along the U.S. East and Gulf coasts. It found that with just a moderate rise in sea levels, 16 could flood 100 times a year by 2050.Â¶Last October, strong winds and waves battered Kwajalein Atoll. Ferries were canceled and a dock was damaged, forcing the base to take the unprecedented step of hosting 845 Marshallese day workers overnight.Â¶Whalley said the military investigated threats, including ocean flooding, in an environmental assessment of the site before beginning construction. â€œThe over-wash threat, if you will, is built into the government requirements of the site,â€ he said.Â¶Yet that 2014 assessment, which runs over 100 pages and addresses everything from sea turtles to the islandâ€™s archaeological history, makes no mention of climate change, noting only that the Space Fence would be able to withstand a small earthquake-generated tsunami.Â¶A single line reads: â€œBased on historical data, there are no anticipated issues with ocean tide and/or wave flooding.â€Â¶Lockheed Martin did not investigate the issue either. Bruce Schafhauser, Lockheedâ€™s program director for the Space Fence, said the Air Force asked it to design the system to withstand earthquakes but not rising seas.Â¶â€œWe donâ€™t have any insight into that,â€ Schafhauser said. â€œIt has not been something that has been required from the Air Force.â€Â¶Schafhauser said the responsibility for finding a suitable location for the installation fell to the military.Â¶The Marshall Islands Environmental Protection Authority wrote a response to the environmental assessment, describing the U.S. militaryâ€™s overall treatment of the climate change threat to Kwajalein as â€œwholly inadequate.â€ It questioned whether the military was overstating the atollâ€™s elevation and criticized its reliance on historical data when the problem is rising seas, a more recent phenomenon.Â¶The military responded in its final report: â€œDetailed study of sea-level rise risks are beyond the scope of this document.â€Â¶Since then, leaders from the Marshall Islands say they have been working with the U.S. to improve environmental standards and ensure climate effects are seriously addressed in future military projects.Â¶Whalley said he plans to find out more about the USGS research at Kwajalein.Â¶â€œItâ€™s the first Iâ€™ve heard about the study,â€ he said. â€œWhen they give you a billion dollars, you tend to focus on getting the radar built.â€

title: Earth had 16 straight months of record high temperatures
content: Â¶WASHINGTON Earthâ€™s 16-month sizzling streak of record high temperatures is finally over, according to one group of federal meteorologists.Â¶The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said last monthâ€™s 60.6 degrees was merely the second hottest September on record for the globe. Thatâ€™s ever so slightly cooler â€“ a few hundredths of a degree â€“ than the record set in 2015. But it was quite a bit warmer â€“ 1.6 degrees â€“ than the 20th century average.Â¶Global average temperatures include both land and sea surface readings. And while oceans were cooling off a tad, global land temperatures in September still set a record high, NOAA climate scientist Jessica Blunden said. It was an unusually hot month in much of Europe, Asia, Africa and North America.Â¶More in Climate ChangeÂ¶NASA, which averages global temperature differently, considers last month as record hot. But the space agency didnâ€™t have a big consecutive hot streak because it didnâ€™t consider last June as record hot.Â¶â€œItâ€™s kind of nice to see it cool down a little bit even though it will go back up again,â€ Blunden said. â€œIt may not be a record now because we have natural variations in weather and climate. Thereâ€™s always going to be ups and downs but that doesnâ€™t mean global warming isnâ€™t happening.â€Â¶The fact that despite the end of El Nino â€“ a warming of the central Pacific that tends to spike global temperatures â€“ the world came close to setting another heat record â€œis quite a feat and offers evidence that global climate change is contributing to these monthly records/near records,â€ University of Oklahoma meteorology professor Jason Furtado said in an email.Â¶The end of El Nino will â€œjust give us a brief respite, since the global trend will continue mercilessly until we stop it by getting off fossil fuels,â€ said climate scientist Stefan Rahmstorf of the Potsdam Institute in Germany.Â¶Burning coal, oil and gas puts heat-trapping carbon dioxide in the air, a main contributor in climate change.Â¶Blunden said this year is still on pace to be the hottest on record, beating the mark set in 2014 and then broken last year. Meteorologists said three record hot years in a row would be unprecedented.Â¶Through September, this year is 1.6 degrees warmer than the 20th century average and nearly a quarter of a degree warmer than the first nine months of 2015.Â¶Records go back to 1880.
